Title: Perfect!
Review: We really loved our two night stay here at the Mango Home Riverside. I would, hoverever, call it more of a Resort, than a Homestay or a B&B? It provides the rustic charm of working gardens and an active, river traffic location, with a luxurious pool and comfy sitting area - all riverside with views to the constant boat traffic. The room had good AC, a mosquito net if needed and a really cute outdoor bathroom, as well as two different outdoor and covered sitting areas. The pool and riverside cabana, should, however absorb the majority of your lounge time, as both are first rate! The bicycles are plentiful, good quality and available for free at any time of the day. They have some boating excursions as well. We did the 4-6 pm sunset and turned out to be a private ride. The boat was equipped with chairs, lounge chairs and fruit. Pick up a Happy Hour Beer Bucket before you cast off and you will love be it! It almost seems superfluous to mention the extremely high level of customer service, but Mango even exceeded the high standards found throughout Vietnam. The eagerness and friendliness of all the staff is impressive, especially "Bun"! If you are looking to escape the city, relax and enjoy some leisurely activities (boat and bicycle) while seeing some authentic Vietnamese countryside, you will be rewarded with a stay here at the Mango.

Title: Peaceful place...food needs to improve

From the rooms to the restaurant prices. While the food is inherently inexpensive vs western standards, we are in the Mekong Delta, and the corner roadside restaurant that is about a 1km walk from the hotel offers amazing Bo Ko or Hiu Tieu for less than USD1.50 if you don't mind the lack of ambience and the noisy traffic. In the hotel, everything is at least USD5 and its fine if the food is good, but i found the food incredibly salty and the quantities were small. Breakfast was also very limited. Title: Relaxing place for tourists only looking for a resort
Review: The 2 of us stayed at Mango Home for 3 nights after travelling through Vietnam for almost a month. After reading some raving reviews, unfortunately I was a bit underwhelmed. Do let me start with the positives: it is located off the Ben Tre town in a quiet area on the riverside. The sunset lounge and 24-hour swimming pool make a very relaxing environment. The staff is friendly who always has 1 person who speaks descent amount of English. At the same time, there are certainly areas for improvement. For example, despite several reviews criticizing the lack of variety in breakfast, it remained an issue for us as well. (Giving you 4 options to choose how you like your eggs is not a variety!) The same items were served every morning and it'd be great if there was an option for Asian food as well. The food at the restaurant was descent but more pricey. The path from Mango to the main road was 700m where you could find local restaurants for much cheaper. But after sunset, the path became pitch dark and difficult to walk/cycle so we felt that it was safer/easier to eat at the hotel. We were given a map with bicycling routes. My boyfriend asked where we could see coconut processing factories and canals but was not given clear information by the staff. We stuck to the routes suggested but we were mainly biking on busy main roads and rice fields, which was not that impressive if you had seen rices terraces in other parts of Vietnam such as Sapa. Laundry costed $4 USD/kg and definitely the most we paid to have our clothes washed at a hotel in Vietnams. And not even ironing was done. Finally, I did not find it helpful to have all the prices listed in USD and not Dong. It is clear that they try to cater to tourists who prefer western comfort but i think using the local currency is just a normal part of travelling. Overall, it's a nice and comfortable place to relax overlooking the river. The value of what we paid for the room was very reasonable. But cost of food and laundry were big negatives. Plus you don't really see Ben Tre or have an authentic taste of the area by staying there.

Title: A lovely way to see true Vietnam
Review: We enjoyed our 2 day/1 night stay at the Mango Riverside as we really got to see life in Vietnam as it is today whilst enjoying wonderful hospitality. From the time we were met by our guide (Thanh) until we were dropped back to our transport back to Saigon, we had a wonderful time. Despite being drenched as it was raining when we were being driven in a tuk tuk to the sail boat, we had a great time as the tuk tuk wove through some narrow but green paths away from the township towards the harbour. Once onboard the boat, we were treated to fresh tropical fruits and bottled water as we sailed along the Mekong towards the Mango Home. It was a pleasant journey as we passed by fishing boats and factories which were situated along the banks of the Mekong. On arrival at the Mango home, we were shown to our room which was large and comfortable. Fresh fruit was again made available to us in the room. The bathroom was huge with an outdoor shower which we loved. There is no TV in the room but there are hammocks available as well as an outdoor seating for guests to enjoy the tranquility of the resort. Lunch was served in the one and only restaurant and the food was lovely (and plentiful). After lunch, we walked to visit a villager who makes rice paper and had a lovely chat with her husband after we all had an attempt at making rice paper). On our return back to the resort, we relaxed in the lounge area overlooking the Mekong before heading to the pool to relax and cool down. Dinner was a cooking lesson where we got to learn how to cook some Vietnamese dishes (with recipes provided on departure so you can try to recreate the dishes at home). Food was lovely once again. Drinks are not included our package and were a little on the pricey side (which was not a major issue for us). The beds were a bit hard but we had a good night sleep. There is a mosquito net as there are mosquitoes there given its location in the middle of a village along the Mekong. We were bitten but not badly and treated it as part of the overall experience. The next morning, after breakfast - which was a continental breakfast with eggs made to order, we were taken to the village centre to visit a bustling market, a temple, rice noodle factory with a sampan ride back to our boat. The morning tour ended with a visit to a coconut factory where we got to enjoy coconut candy, wine and banana wine (and more tropical fruit). Given the amount of food we had enjoyed that morning ,we chose to skip lunch to head back to Saigon early (to avoid the peak hour rush into Saigon) and were given little takeaway packs of food to enjoy on our trip home. We absolutely enjoyed our stay at the Mango Home and wished we could stay longer. A huge shout out to our guide during our stay (Thanh) and our boat captain. They were friendly and hospitable and looked after us very well (especially me as I had injured my ankle at the start of our trip to Vietnam so needed to take extra precautions when getting on and off the boat and walking). We are looking forward to our return visit back to the Mango Home.

Title: Peaceful Paradise
Review: We arrived late in the evening and were picked up at the main road by staff in a mini van and were warmly welcomed and offered a meal even at the late hour. The setting for Mangos is beautiful alongside the bustling river where you can enjoy watching everyday life as boats deliver their coconuts by boat to be processed. The staff at Mangos go above and beyond, always greet you with a smile and willing to assist with anything. The food was wonderful in flavour and presentation! No need to go anywhere else. We took a boat tour to the coconut processing plant, the brick factory, and side trip in a dugout canoe and a visit to a local family to learn to make rice paper. Ben, our tour guide was wonderful and very knowledgeable. Took extra time to explain things to us, we never felt rushed. He served fresh coconut water and fresh fruit on the boat. All beautifully arranged and presented. It was a hot day and we were greeted with cold wet cloths after each shore excursion! Mangos is the perfect spot to visit the Mekong Delta from. The resort is off the beaten path for sure, but definitely worth the time it takes to get there. We will definitely recommend Mangos to anyone travelling to the Mekong area! Thanks Thonh, Ut, Drung, Ben, Tan and the driver!

Title: Comfortable, clean and well-maintained small riverside resort
Review: Due to travelling along a large section of the Mekong in a short time, we only stayed at the Mango Home Riverside for one night before moving on, but we found the small resort (I'm not really convinced that "homestay" is an accurate term?) to be very comfortable and a very nice introduction to Mekong riverside accommodation. To start with, our hotel transfer from HCMC was well-arranged and comfortable, with a couple of very special boat rides and walking tours on our way to the resort prior and post check in (Optional Separate Extra through Mango Tours). Our Suite Room was comfortable, with a decent bed, basic storage & furnishings (minibar), and a full outdoor bathroom to the rear (large bath, vanity basin, open WC and shower head). It gives the opportunity to see some of the local wildlife from your shower (!!), but it is covered and water pressure/heat etc is fine. The room itself is traditionally furnished but clean and very quiet, and possible to keep "pest free" for the night with a few towels on the ground below the doors. There is also an adjoining outside relaxation area for daytime reading of books etc should you have time. The resort grounds are well maintained but quite uneventful, and unfortunately dont really leave much of a view across the river itself (we parked on the end of one of the hotel boats at the hotel pier to take in the river sights). Given the location, we gather that dining options are essentially limited to the resort kitchen, but we found the dinner options to be adequate and of a reasonable standard. The staff are all very friendly and willing to help, and seem to take pride in the upkeep of the property and their guests happiness and general "Mekong Experience". In general we were actually pleasantly surprised as we are NOT normally "homestay" or "B&B" accommodation users, but we found that the Mango offers very comfortable, clean and pleasant accommodation for a short stay whilst on the Mekong.

Title: Amazing Service, Beautiful Site

Title: Excellent in many ways, lukewarm in others
Review: Before booking at Mango, I read the many rave reviews on this site. While I cannot disagree with any of them, most seem to be written by people on their first tour of Vietnam, so they sound a little starstruck. Let me add some depth from someone who has travelled extensively in SE Asia. First of all...if the word 'home stay' conjures up visions of being at someone's home, seeing how they live, etc...that's not what it means here. Mango Homestay is merely a small resort on the banks of the Mekong, way out of town. The rooms are very nice and the decor is exotic, but less than, say, a nice Thai resort. There is a very nice central building where meals are served (a bit pricy by VN standards, but quite affordable by North American standards. Expect appetizers to be about $3, main dishes to be around $5-8, beers at $1.75). This is about twice what these things cost in most restaurants, so if you are someone who likes a 'good deal', it might bug you a bit. The food is quite nice, but not really exotic. Lots of deep fried things. When we arrived, it was the heat of the day and everyone siestas. However, the resort only has 3 hammocks, so all the best siesta places (hammocks and couches) were occupied by the staff! It felt very uncomfortable to ask them to move, so I sat in a less comfortable spot until the heat passed. They really ought to have hammocks everywhere. Be aware also that, while the buildings are very well maintained and lovely, the grounds feel a bit overgrown and unkempt. Many resorts have manicured lawns with paths and sitting areas, but that's not the case here. So you don't spend much time strolling the grounds. Lastly, you pay for everything except the welcome fruit basket (4 bananas) and the two small bottles of water. All your snacks, bicycle rentals, scooter rentals, meals, beers...everything is priced in US dollars (red flag) and you are pretty much a captive audience. Again, prices are low by US standards, but not by Vietnam standards. Some extras, like the half-day river cruise, is actually a bit dear. But it's also very nice...your call. So enjoy the tranquility, the lovely rooms, the fantastically friendly staff and pretty good food...but if you're at all budget conscious, you'll find yourself just hanging out being a bit over cautious about costs. My recommendation: plan on spending $50 a day on extras (a fortune in Vietnam) and treat yourself.

Title: Authentic experience in Vietnam countryside
Review: We stayed at Mango Homestay as the second stop on our 7 week Vietnam trip. After 5 days in Saigon we really appreciated the peaceful setting of of this hotel. We took the bus from Saigon, we hadn't reserved ahead but when we got to to the bus station the ticket agent knew exactly where we were going and arranged our free minibus transfer as well. After being dropped off by the minibus on the path to the hotel, we chose to just walk in, it was a beautiful walk and only took about 10 minutes. The main attraction for us of this hotel was the setting. Not only are the hotel and grounds beautiful, the surrounding area is residential, in an arrangement that is very unusual to a North American. After leaving the main road, you follow concrete paths that are accessible only by scooter, bicycle or walking. Small plots of land along the paths contain houses, small farms and small commercial operations such as production of rice paper and noodles, coconuts or mangos. You see many people outside of their homes, and they are so friendly, always a big smile and usually a "Hello". I never felt when walking outside of the hotel grounds that I was intruding. We had the same experience when exploring further by bike. My husband and I had a hard time following the map provided by the hotel, but we loved every minute of our cycling adventures. A special treat was when met children bicycling home from school, they seemed delighted to see us on our bikes and always greeted us with cheery hellos. Regarding the hotel, we had one of the larger rooms with partially open air (connected) bathroom. The room also had a private sitting area outside with hammock. The room and especially the bathroom were very well equipped and we had everything we needed to be very comfortable, including a bathtub, it was a great experience to soak in the tub and feel the open air. The air-conditioning and wi-fi worked beautifully. We ate all our meals in the restaurant for two days, the food was excellent and it was a good opportunity to sample some Vietnamese dishes that we hadn't tried yet. We did the half day tour and it was well worthwhile. It included very interesting tours of small local industries (coconut processing, brick making, rice paper making). Also a short bike ride and a trip on a small boat down a beautiful narrow stream surrounded by coconut trees. Sharing the tour was also a great opportunity to get to know the other guests at the hotel. The staff at the hotel were very friendly and helpful. I would recommend this hotel to anyone looking for an authentic Vietnam experience, without having to sacrifice any comforts. I think it is a good example of how tourism can co-exist without any negative impact on the local residents that I could see. The hotel seems to naturally blend in with the surrounding area.

Title: Wonderful location, interesting local excursions, all with a very personal touch
Review: Located at the borders of the Mekong in the countryside outside Ben Tre, the Mango Homestay is a rare pearl in a sea of packaged Mekong Delta tours. Instead of spending hours in minibuses over bumpy roads, expect to discover through the Mango Homestay the immediate surroundings on bike, foot and by boat. Our children (13, 10, 8) loved the different short excursions as they showed the daily life of the people in the Ben Tre countryside; we visited a rice noodle "factory", the local market, a neighbour telling us from his army days and his wife showed us how to make our own rice paper and had a look at the local brick and coconut production. Wifi is a bit on the slow side, don't expect to upload your holiday videos from here. Bottom line, we can highly recommend Mango Homestay to all families with kids that look for a good mix of relaxation and activities in the Mekong delta.

Title: A thanks and a gentle prod!
Review: Mango Home is a place with amazing promise and loads of potential. Its promise is the possibility of a quiet relaxing break from the madness. Its potential, as this area opens up to tourism, is to be the first and best at it. This small resort is a fairly new venture in a distinctly un-touristy area in the delta and in prime position to take advantage as the area develops. The absolute stars of the place are the manager Man and his staff. Man is affable and very much a hands on guy and the staff all equally personable and willing. The food is extremely good, and of note is the individually decorated plates with leaves and carved fruit and veg. One of Mans personal contributions I believe.The menu is perhaps a little sparse for choice, especially if you are used to a western diet but the Vietnamese dishes, particularly the fish, are lovely. I netted and bought fresh live King Prawns at the local market and Man, a fine cook, personally prepared them for me to my requirement. A real plus! Something has to be said regards to the mode of transport into the resort from the main road. This is by small motorcycle and I can fully understand why this may be a frightening experience for some. Now! I am an accomplished motorcyclist having ridden large bikes such as my Harley for many many years, fifty to be precise, and I absolutely detest being a passenger on the rear and would never dream of doing so in the â€œrealâ€ world. I live in Asia and witness the suicidal antics of small bike riders daily and have no wish to become a statistic. I suggest arrival by boat for sanity. Also, unlike previous reviewers, we did not find the resort as quiet as we had hoped. In a Vietnamese context it is, I suppose, quiet. In a South East Asian context where they are familiar with tourist needs, not so much and in an International context, not at all... The staff had a tendency to congregate in the vicinity of our room, and where you have three Asians talking together it sounds like a party, when you have eight it sounds like a football match. This, I know, is a cultural phenomenon as I have lived in the region for years. Asians and Asia are simply loud, this is a given, just the way it is. but it does not help when they are sitting at a table directly at your bedroom window on the adjacent, contiguous terrace. Quality Resorts that have been at it for a long time know this and have strict rules for their staff. Small motorcycles running early in the morning beside the room is also not a good idea. Further, roosters squawking and dogs barking may be quaint and rustic in this rural setting during the day but at five in the morning, perhaps not so charming for many. This was exacerbated by workmen renovating the external rooms in the compound. If we had known this we would have arranged to come on a different date. If it is to be a quiet place to relax and chill, then it must, BE, quiet! I really hope that these issues are dealt with as I would dearly love to be able to return.

Title: Fab place...
Review: We found the Mango Homestay via Trip Advisor and were certainly not disappointed. The house and terrace is set in a garden filled with butterflies on the banks of the Mekong River with its own private jetty where you embark on the boat for your tour (which you must do, trust me). The staff are delightful (Mr Man in particular), the food is delicious and freshly cooked) and the rooms were spotlessly clean and air conditioned - the outside bathroom and shower is particular fun. We stayed for two nights and LOVED it. However, having read the last negative review I would add the following note. This is NOT a luxury hotel and coach trip - this is Vietnam and it's a homestay - a delightful one with a bit of adventure. It is a two hour bus journey from HCMC with a five minute car transfer after that and then a five minute back of motorbike ride for the last half mile down paths through the local hamlet as Mango is not accessible by car. It's remote but that makes it even more delightful. It may seem chaotic but it's actually all very well organised (and that's a metaphor for most of this wonderful country)- take a taxi to the Minh Tam bus company in HCMC (tell them you're going to Ben Tre and Mango) - they get you off at the right stop and then drive you on by car to the transfer point where you're met by Mango stiff on motorbike. Travel light, go with the flow and you'll have a fantastic experience.

Title: A Very Unpleasant Surprise
Review: Whenever I write a negative review I suggest that readers read all of the reviews and form their own opinion. I have thought several days before writing this because it is still hard for me to believe and I continue to ask, â€œHow did we not know?â€. We are in our 70's and this was to be the relaxing culmination of a month long trip to Thailand, Cambodia, and Vietnam. I had had extensive email conversations with Jay and was really looking forward to the wonderful sounding stay at Mango and very special day tour at the end of this amazing but exhausting trip. WE knew we would be picked up by private car in HCMC and taken to Mango Homestay and the pictures were so inviting. The ride there was pleasant until our driver suddenly with no communication (He didn't speak English but this â€œprocessâ€ should have been explained before) pulled to the side of the road, empty except for one of those little huts that sell drinks. We had no idea why he was stopping but then he opened our doors and went to the back and quickly took our bags out. We had no idea where we were or what was happening. This was not Mango. Just a dusty stretch of road! I panicked I climbed out of the van as there was nothing else to do as our luggage was now at the side of the road. Then I turned and a motorbike was directly in front of me and I was told to â€œget on!â€.. No explanation. Where was Mango? I had never ridden a motorbike and hadn't planned to begin at 75. I didn't know where to put my feet or where to hold on, so with discomfort, I put my arms around the waist of the driver. We started down a narrow path with many sharply tilted turns. How long would this be and HOW could it be? By that time I was traumatized. Not knowing where we were going or how long this ride would be and trying to protect my back from the hard bounces, we finally arrived at Mango. That is a blur to me. I arrived at our room in shock. trying to process what had happened.. I was shaken and my husband was confused. Our room, which was next to the kitchen, had no table or any chair and no private patio. One of the dining area tables was directly outside our window. Apparently â€œprivateâ€ as used in the descriptions means for use of all guests only. No TV which was ok except it said there was one.. The bed was in front of the window and it was the only place to sit so unless you stood at the foot of the bed there was no view. We ate in our room using a footstool that was brought in for a table and sat on the end of the bed. The food was indeed well prepared as others have described. I was shaken and did not sleep well. Even if the description at booking dot com had not mentioned that on site parking was available, I had no reason not to expect to arrive at that wonderful scene in the picture. I donâ€™t understand why no one else has mentioned the need to enter by motor bike nor do I understand why Mango does not explain this in their literature or why it was not mentioned in my extensive conversations with Jay. I'm sure for younger folk, that could be part of the adventure but at 75 it was very frightening and awkward. Had we known this was the only way in we would not have stayed there. The next morning we canceled our tour partly because we wondered with all the changes in vehicles what other unpleasant surprises might face us. We had arranged an option instead of the bicycle but now we could not be sure if that was our only obstacle on the tour. Rather than the motorbike we took 20 minutes to walk out to the road. Jay and I had exchanged many emails and I thought coming to Mango would feel like coming home. He had arranged for us not to use bikes on the tour so he certainly knew we had limitations. I never dreamed I would be writing this kind of review, I do think Mango needs to give a more accurate description of the arrival process, the rooms, and the parking situation. For those not our age and not disturbed by the arrival process, this could be a wonderful time I am sure, but for us it turned into a nightmare. and we lost our only time set aside for a river cruise. Any trip of a month will surely have its unpleasant surprises but I never thought it would be this. I know many have had wonderful stays here but this is my experience and that is what TA is for.

Title: Serene and beautiful place
Review: The word 'homestay' is a perfect description for Mango Homestay. Our visit here was like being welcomed into your home as very special guests. It is much more than a B and B and this term does not do it justice. The friendliness, attentiveness and attention to detail by the staff made our stay very comfortable. Mr Man does an excellent job of managing the homestay and it was obvious his staff like and respect him a great deal. The food was magnificent and tastefully presented. Being part of the cooking process was very fun and educational especially for 2 people who enjoy cooking and culinary arts. The setting of beautiful gardens, lots of comfortable spaces to relax and our delightful room with its enclosed outdoor en-suite bathroom put the finishing touches to a wonderful stay. They also offer one, two and three day tours on the Mekong Delta. Unfortunately, we were unable to go on our one day trip because of the typhoon. Some of the boats were moored at the homestay. They looked very comfortable with tables and chairs and not the boats with the low backless seats we had experienced elsewhere in Vietnam and other parts of Asia. Kudos to the owners of Mango Homestay, Mr Man, Terry and all the other staff for creating a tropical paradise. I would highly recommend it. I would advise anybody booking here to contact the homestay first as there are two ways of getting there - by river and by road. Road is a little tricky and you need their guidance.

Title: Best place we stayed in Vietnam

Title: Exactly What We Wanted
Review: I think this is my first tripadvisor review but we are having such a great time that I feel I have to share our experience. We are on a three week trip including Laos, Cambodia and then a quick run from PP back to Saigon via Chau Doc. By chance I discovered Mango and I'm extremely glad we did. All we really understood was that we had a arranged a two night/three day tour of the Mekong Delta but what Mango delivered was something much, much better. I'm typing this from the front porch of their lodge looking out over the river, watching the boats, many loaded with coconuts go by, watching the sun set after a really brilliant day of activities. Frankly its a bit hard to convey but basically they offer what I can only describe as an beautifully choreographed peek into rural life. How shall I say...the gain without the pain. Here is how it went. After getting up very early this morning my wife, my two boy's ages 11 and 13 and myself started the day with a boat ride to the floating market. But what was really special happened next. After a three hour car ride we made our way to a group of three island that are unique in that they don't have any cars and so Mango had set up a series of little events one after the other in which we first walked through the orchards, then went by boat to see brick making, then small cart to see noodle making, dugout boats through narrow channels, to another boat and then to the resort itself. The kids loved it. Each event (and I'm sure I've left out half of them) was just the sort of thing kids really get into. And each was just the right length. Enough time to not feel rushed (we could also adjust set the pace because it was only us) and then off to the next thing via a short walk or ride. But the best were the "surprises." I hate to spoil the effect but here is the part that makes it all work. Just when you think you have walked just the right amount (remember its hot here) you round a corner and...there's a boat. A very nice traditional boat, with cold towels, cool drinks, shade and cross breeze to whisk off to the next part of your adventure. With all the development this is a great (and extremely pleasant) way to peek into a bit of rural life as it was in way that you couldn't possibly put together yourself. I'd highly recommend it for families especially if you have kids that like seeing how people live and things work.

Title: Beautiful Garden Retreat
Review: We really enjoyed our 2 night stay at Mekong Home. We were there during rainy season and initial impressions were poor from the road as we waited for a porter to assist with luggage. The walk down the long path in rain dodging puddles and rubbish was not a great start. But once we arrived at MH our attitudes took an immediate turnaround. The tropical style gardens, pool and pavilions are gorgeous. It felt so peaceful. We were welcomed by the the Khoa the manager and shown to our very stylish bungalow rooms. Beds were very comfortable, air con fantastic and the room spacious. Breakfast and dinners were all very tasty and we loved the foot bath after dinner on our second night. The kitchen staff were very friendly and smiling. I would suggest that they await guests arrival to the pavilion before cooking as some food were cold but were happily reheated by staff. We took the morning boat tour and were lucky with the weather. Our guide had great English and we really enjoyed all stops. We saw coconuts being processed, brooms being woven and finished with being rowed along a arroyo. Khoa was happy to organise other tours around the area if required. His overall management of all guests at all times was impressive to watch. It was clear he would do everything in his power to ensure guests had the best time possible. The hotel is a fair way out of Ben Tre but as this was towards the end of our month long trip we were very happy to relax in the gorgeous surroundings and enjoy the pool. I would totally recommend to others as a good choice for some downtime especially when weather makes other parts of Vietnam not such a good location. Especially as its not that far from HCMC. There was a lack of hot water in the shower but as others have mentioned this is due to the use of solar panels and was something we encountered at every property we stayed at the Mekong Delta and other parts of Vietnam as well. We thought the pricing here was very reasonable for the standard provided and would definitely return.

Title: Wonderful Tranquil Stay
Review: We highly recommend this beautiful tranquil spot on the Mekong River. The rooms are as beautiful as the pictures. Excellent housekeeping and comfortable bed with top notch linens. This is by no means a homestay in the usual sense of the word. The rooms are first class. The way the place is run is highly professional yet casual. It is owned by a family of cousins. The manager, Anh, is ever helpful and speaks English well. Meals are taken in the open air dining room and consist of what the kitchen is cooking that evening, lunches are simple but good. Food is family style cooking and tasty but not ostentatious. We enjoyed it very much. We stayed 5 nights and were not bored. The free bicycles enabled us to take jaunts into the countryside at will and were much appreciated. The boat trip is rather expensive for what it is, and is mainly aimed at those who have not already travelled through the delta as we had. Itâ€™s up to you. Anh booked our onward travel by Futa bus, the most comfortable and efficient, with pick up at the guest house. A quick and painless way to get to HCMC. Be sure to stay here to relax before braving the chaos that is HCMC!!

Title: Great Visit
Review: Vinh was a perfect host. He guided us expertly and easily from Saigon to Ben Tre, and made our stay highly enjoyable. When we arrived at the check-in desk at the public Bus Station in Saigon, the clerk answered the phone and said, "For You" - it was Vinh checking we were OK. When we got off the bus in Ben Tre a couple of motor-cycle taxis were waiting to take us to his home where a chilled and freshly squeezed clementine juice awaited. In the afternoon we took bikes into the local town to explore, read in the hammocks and then ate. The 4 course home-cooked al fresco dinner was excellent, lots of fresh local herbs in addition to being very good value. Great "home-cooking" and one of our favourite meals during our trip. We ground the rice and turmeric for the Banh Xeo in Vinh's grandparent's antique mill, and cooked our own pancakes ahead of the meal. The following day Vinh arranged a private boat for a day-trip which was also good value and fun. As we were leaving he introduced his mother, who had been orchestrating things from inside the house/kitchen, who she gave us some delicious home made vegetable crisps for our journey. Highly recommended.

Title: A proper mekong delta experience
Review: Stayed here for one night during the rainy season. Vinh told us what bus to get from Saigon, and even booked us the tickets in advance. Upon arrival, two people on motorbikes were waiting for us, drove us down a narrow path for 5 minutes to reach the homestay. The place itself is off the beaten track on a small tributary, seemingly quite deep in the jungle. It's a ten minute bicycle ride to the nearest town (with a market, shops, etc.), which Vinh offered to us free of charge, including some rain jackets - which came in handy! As this homestay only includes breakfast and dinner, make sure you load up for lunch before your arrival if necessary, as the location really is remote. The room itself is a little hut just off from the main house, incredibly clean, with a large mosquito net to help protect you from mother nature. Water and tea/coffee are provided, along with towels. The garden surrounding our hut was beautiful, and we sat in the hammock watching chickens and butterflies pass by. The sound of the rain on the roof is amazing. You really do feel a million miles away from everywhere. Dinner was huge, with Vinh very kindly introducing us to his family and how to prepare a traditional Vietnamese dish. Breakfast was equally extensive. Though Vinh 's English was not the strongest, we had few problems communicating with him. He showed us around the area, pointing out the various flora, and also organised our ongoing bus journey, even having his brother sit with us at the bus stop to ensure we got on the right bus. Title: Luxury homestay
Review: What a fantastic surprise. We booked here to see the Mekong Delta but also save a few dollars compared with resort accommodation in the area. Our travel agent booked it and I must admit I didn't expect to find such a great place. After check-in we spent and hour cycling around the local paths on the bikes (included) followed by a pre-dinner cooking lesson. Title: One of the highlights of our holiday
Review: Being discouraged by many reviews of several Mekong Delta tours we decided to organize our own tour. We contacted Vinh who offered us a nice deal including one night, dinner, breakfast, and also a visit to the Cai Be floating market. Getting there wasn't hard but understanding how to do it was tricky, so I was glad a previous reviewer on TA had explained it. You need to go to 826 vÃµ vÄƒn kiá»‡t in HCMC, where you'll find a tiny local bus station. Vinh went out of his way to call the bus station to be sure we made it to the bus and then picked us up at the final stop. The bungalows were lovely, everything is really new but also very charming. All around it's houses and gardens and fruit trees everywhere. Vinh took us for a bike ride and then in the evening we had a cooking demo / class with his family, and then we were served dinner outside. Dinner was truly delicious. My husband doesn't usually like fish but he loved the fish they served to us there. The day after we had a private boat trip, with the usual visits to a candy factory (yes, a bit touristy). When we got to the floating market it was pretty late, so maybe you want to arrange to go there first thing on the tour. After the tour two motor taxis (also arranged by Vinh) drove us to the bus station to go back to HCMC. This was probably the only negative part, the motorbike ride on the highway was pretty scary. Vinh can be a bit shy with his English but he made sure we were comfortable and that the whole experience was unforgettable. His place is a true garden, and a night (or more) there is a great way to experience life on the Mekong delta.

Title: Fantastic find off the beaten track!
Review: We stayed 4 days and 3 nights in this beautiful remote setting. Vinh took excellent care of us. The cottage was very comfortable. The gardens were lovely. The food was gourmet quality. Even in this location though, there is good internet access. Vinh will arrange motorbike or boat tours, if you are interested. But we enjoyed our walks just around the neighborhood. About a 30-40 minute walk away is a market town which we found to be a very pleasant change from the tourist markets of Ho Chi Minh City. All in all, our time here was one of the best experiences in our 7 weeks in Vietnam. There is no nightlife, no "entertainment", but if you are looking for something away far from the standard tourist experience, this will find this your perfect hideaway. Highly recommended.

Title: Lovely bungalows in a real rural setting
Review: We stayed 2 nights in a double bungalow in the lovely garden setting where bananas, pineapples and chillies were all growing and animals roaming around which was nice to see. We arrived by local bus from Saigon and were met by Vinh who had someone take our bags on for us. Vinh's family were lovely and the cooking lesson on the first night was a really good, making pork and shrimp rice pancakes from scratch - so much better than the generic spring roll lesson you usually get! Breakfast and dinner included and there were a lot of courses at dinner! We were only supplied with two small bottles of water in the room on arrival, but there was no fridge and we were not given any on the second day, so make sure you buy lots from the market or bring some with you. We asked Vinh if we could put them in his fridge. On the second day we cycled with Vinh to the local market and he then took us, unexpectedly, to a family party! We turned up to a house in the middle of nowhere, where a group of around 30 men were sat outside eating and drinking. Being the only female I thought it might be a bit awkward but they invited us in with open arms and we continued to eat and drink with them for the morning (this was 10am!). A fantastic way to meet real people and a unique experience we won't forget! All in all we enjoyed our stay but we were there in hot season which made sleeping in the bungalow almost impossible as the heat was unbearable. Perhaps some more strategically placed fans would help and definitely a fridge in the rooms, as the lack of cold water provided turned out to be our main issue.

Title: This is the way to experience the Mekong
Review: I stayed for 2 nights with a group of friends over a Vietnamese holiday. We couldn't have been happier with our experience at Jardin du Mekong. We arrived by local bus, via the guesthouse's main man Vinh's instructions. It wasn't the most luxurious ride, but it was a unique experience nonetheless, and totally bearable (bring headphones and pack light). Talk with Vinh, he may be able to suggest other transport methods. The vast majority of foreign visitors to the Mekong come with a 1-2 day tour from Saigon. They are carted around like cattle, stopping at all the same tourist traps along with all the other suckers from other tour agencies. I could be wrong, but with this route you're sure to miss Delta's most charming parts. The Best Parts: -THE FOOD!! Holy moly. Vinh's mom is the cook, and wow is she a good one. The multi-course meals will not leave you hungry or unsatisfied. The cooking demonstration on our first night was a lovely touch too. -The lush garden landscape and quiet setting -The adorable and comfortable bungalows -The free bicycles -The absolutely magical setting; beautifully quant rural neighborhoods with stunning flowers and fruit trees. The roads around the guesthouse are a bit bigger than a footpath (motobike road), totally flat, and ideal for the most enjoyable early morning or pre-sunset walks and explorative bike rides. -Service. Vinh is great. Friendly people all over. Everything ran smoothly. Can't complain. -The puppies! Advice: -Insects can get nasty. Bring repellent! -Rain...bring a poncho if you're visiting during rainy season -We booked a tour to the floating market..this was pleasant and enjoyable but would fit into the "cattle herding" style as explained above. The best part about it was the long, scenic boat ride to and from the town.

Title: Great place to relax and get away from the tourist trail.
Review: This is a lovely place and Vinh (the man of the house) is a really nice guy who goes out of his way to help you in any way he can. If you want to buy something for lunch while you're at the market, they are happy to cook it for you back at the homestay. The rooms are nice and the overall ambiance of the place is one of peace and relaxation. Getting there from Ho Chi Minh CIty is actually very easy but was a little confusing at first. Vinh sent us the address of the bus station which we couldn't find on google and - being western travelers - instantly panicked. The hotel in HCMC also couldn't help us. The reality is, it's a tiny private bus station with regular minibuses heading into the Mekong. The people are friendly and they charge you the same prices as the locals (about 90,000VND for a 3 hour trip). The address of the bus station is 826 vÃµ vÄƒn kiá»‡t, and any taxi driver will find it easily enough. Just expect to share the bus with plenty of chickens in bags.

Title: Paradise get-a-way from the pandemic
Review: Spent a few days and nights here over Christmas. Checked in the day before Christmas and headed straight to the cafe which is right on the river's edge. We booked in for the special Christmas meal which was only on Christmas Eve and also on Christmas Day night. While the food was good, I think the chef had quite a bit of sweet tooth. The staff were very polite and helpful. There weren't a lot of guests staying at the hotel, however the coffee shop was bustling on Saturday and Sunday. While this would have normally made me quite nervous, everyone appeared to be quite respectful of other tables/patrons and the atmosphere wasn't alarming in any way. The rooms were very large and well appointed, and while the balcony was small, there was enough room for a table and two chairs and of course an ashtray. The breakfast buffet wasn't huge, but certainly not lacking anything either. The egg station was of course the first thing I visited and the omelette with chilli and spring onions was cooked perfectly. I hadn't travelled since the pandemic started so wasn't sure what to expect. There were hand sanitising stations and QR check-in at Reception. There were minimal guests staying in the hotel and they were allocated at various places throughout the hotel. We never had to share the lift with other guests, and there were many reminders about keeping a safe distance and wearing masks and the 5K too. I had a thoroughly relaxing time. We were so happy staying within the confines of the resort that we didn't get a chance to even explore the river or the city. I'm definitely looking forward to my next visit! I'm definitely looking forward to my next visit!

Title: great value, excellent resort
Review: Our first time to Ben Tre and to the Riverside. the only disappointment was that we couldn't stay longer. The staff were all very friendly and accommodating, from check in to check out. Most staff spoke English so it was easy for me to request anything and it was taken care of immediately. Beds were comfortable and rooms quiet. De bediening zijn jongens die van de straat zijn geplukt zonder ervaring. Nog erger is dat de manager ze niet stuurt. Ze ziet ze fouten maken en lacht er om en stuurt ze niet bij. De jongens weten niet bij wie ze welk gerecht moeten neer zetten. Ze halen de menu kaarten niet op, leggen niet bij iedereen bestek neer en nemen niet bij iedereen een gerecht op. Ze spreken geen woord Engels. Als eerste komen de hoofdgerechten, terwijl er ook soep is besteld. Dit wordt goed opgelost. Een soep is echter nooit gekomen, terwijl deze wel is opgeschreven. Manager beweerd dat we liegen en dat deze nooit besteld is. Dat in het midden gelaten. Het eten was koud en taai. Je betaald veel geld voor een klein, koud, taai stukje vlees en 10 frietjes. Wanneer je er iets van zegt tegen de manager lacht ze en zegt ze sorry, maar ze doet er niets mee. Wanneer eten terug gestuurd wordt omdat het koud is, lijkt het in de magnetron opgewarmd te zijn. Het vlees is hierna taai en de sla is lauw. Al met al is het hotel zelf prima, maar het restaurant en de service zijn waardeloos. Ze spreken weinig Engels en doen geen moeite voor de klant.

Title: Come apart and rest a while
Review: This is a lovely property. However, Ben Tre is a sleepy province and there is not a lot to do, so don't go looking. If you want to rest, this is the place. My room overlooked the swimming pool and river, and I found it very modern, well kept and pleasant. There is a swimming pool, and plenty of places on the grounds to sit and relax. The breakfast buffet was quite adequate. I ate dinner in the restaurant twice with mixed results: one dinner was excellent and the other just fair. When I return to Ben Tre, I will stay here again.

Title: Good hotel in lovely lication
Review: We enjoyed our three night stay here. It is a charming hotel with some good features but room for improvement nonetheless. Our check in was quick and we were offered a choice of rooms which was appreciated. We chose one with a balcony with great views over the river. The bed was the largest we have ever seen and very comfortable but it did rather dominate the room leaving little space for anything else! The furniture was, overall, a little tired and the sofa was stained. The bathroom was adequate but slightly awkward as the door opened in front of the shower door. The pool was lovely but there were very few beds. Staff would get extra deck chairs when the beds were taken but they were a little uncomfortable. For two of the three days we were there it was quiet but a large group descended on the pool one day with lots of screaming children but overall it was a lovely place to while away the time. The breakfast was very poor we thought with watery juice, undrinkable coffee, sliced bread and a poorly run egg station. The hygiene standards did not look great either. However, we ate in the restaurant every night (eating outside). Staff members were very obliging, the Vietnamese food was great and the beer ridiculously cheap! There was a birthday party whilst we were there and we were concerned when the PA system was being tested the day before as it was deafening but the party itself started at 9am and seemed to be over by 10.30! Noisy whilst it lasted but then peace returned. There is a variety of handicrafts on sale at the hotel at very good prices. My husband took a bike into town, we also took a taxi in and walked back along the river. There isnâ€™t much to see but we went to the temple and the eclectic museum and sampled a couple of bars including the floating ship which we enjoyed. We also took a Mekong trip with Dinh Ho Echo tours which was good. Overall, we enjoyed our trip. Everyone was helpful and obliging and the location is lovely. With a few improvements this could be a very fine hotel.

Title: Looks great from the outside
Review: Ben Tre as a city has little enough to recommend it, we found, though the views of the Mekong Delta are excellent. First impressions of the hotel are on the "wow!" side of things - it's big and imposing and quietly situated on the banks of the Mekong. On checking in we were told we'd been upgraded to a River View Room (thank you, Ben Tre) and sure enough the room was very nice, on the fourth floor. Huge bathroom, great covered balcony area for the view, good storage for clothing etc. The hotel was very quiet. There's a very large dining room / outside covered bar adjacent to the hotel and this, I think, demonstrates the hotel's main business. Ben Tre not being a tourist haven, we concluded the main business of the hotel was local weddings (an entire outdoor covered area set up for a wedding which had happened a few days prior) and business / conferences (which seemed to be borne out when a dozen or two Vietnamese salarymen appeared at mealtimes in suits and shirts, and later that evening started up on the most horrendous off-key karaoke. Fortunately, none of this is audible from the hotel proper :-) . By the way, while we're on the subject of the dining room, don't let your attention wander to the lightshades on the restaurant ceiling lights; they're filthy and worn out. Food is OK, breakfast could be lots better. Service in the bar in the evening is slow if there are more than half a dozen customers - there's a tendency for the staff to stand around watching one doing all the work. Some of their cocktail mixes are dubious, to say the least; I had a Long Island Tea one evening which arrived in a martini glass and I'm sure was a big shot of gin with some cold green tea in it. Very strange. On the plus side, most of the hotel staff try hard but simply don't have the English for the job. Helpful people on the desk, rooms good, hotel clean, pool good (but only 3 sunloungers??). I think their problem is that there aren't any competing hotels nearby. They trade on weddings and conferences and the tourist trade just isn't enough.

And when the tires were rather flat, they didn't even have a pump, so we had to take a bike without light in the evening. The swimming pool looks great and you can have a relaxed sit, but when I accidentally swallowed some water it tasted disgusting. Last improvement point is the cleanliness. The hotel matts and parts of the bathroom were not clean. So great hotel at first impression, but it can do a lot better in reality.

Title: Satisfied overall
Review: Ben Tre city is one place where you have to go past to get to Mekong Delta so great future potential. It is a good getaway from Ho Chi Minh City for a few days but no beach here only Mekong River. It is only 1.5hr-2hr drive dependent on travel. Cost about 50USD on Taxi from Ho Chi Minh City. There are only a couple of reason to come here from my perspective as it is not really a tourist draw. The city is quiet and out of the way, not much to offer to tourist wise so everything had to be with the resort. Riverside resort is proud to label itself 4 stars so I judge it against what I experience and expect from a typical 4* property. Service - 4* This was very surprising and I know from other experiences in Vietnam that 4* service is hard to find. To found it in this resort in a remote and non touristy city it was a pleasant surprise. Staff from Front office to house keeping and maintenance were all friendly and happy to serve. They were keen to recommend genuine places to go without trying to promote you expensive places that were mediocre. (This was very common in Danang for example).The English level from some staff could improve but I suspect that they are alreay some of the best there is to offer in Ben Tre City so I feel I cannot be critical on that front. In general the service rival most 4* places in Vietnam and almost match the best beachside resorts in Danang area. Room -3* The room was very good. Everything was what you would expect from a good 3* property to 4*. I gave it 3* because it did not have a bath tub, only a nice shower. This was not much of a problem to me but most travellers would expect that a bath tub is fairly standard to a 4* property. We had a great view facing the pool and the Mekong river behind it. It was just great seeing fishing boats going past throughout the day and a sunset to go with it. Nothing to complain about. If you could add the bath tub and get rid of the occasional ants then 4* for sure. Facility -3* Their facility that is most relevant to a guest was the swimming pool and I would give them easily 4* for the pool. Very simply put if the pool was not there I would not have gone to stay at the resort and their pool is as good as one can get. Water clean, temperature right, shallow area for youngsters and up to 1.5m deep on the other end. life vest and towels provided. I went everyday and it is surely one of their biggest asset. Their gym needs some love and care. It's not their forte. I would say firstly invest in a few large mirrors in there, sort the treadmill out as it is one of the basic equipment. Get a few dumbbells in there and finally get air conditioning in there. Wall fans aren't really sufficient for gym on this side of the planet....The hotel has a nice little path around so great for some jogging. They also provide bicycles and tandem bicycle which were popular for young children, couples and family. They unfortunately don't have a spa. That would have made it complete. The outside cafe area by the river is good and the resort may be able to utilize that a bit more in the future. Food and Beverage - 2* This is where the resort is let down. I have only had their breakfast but based on that I was not keen to try anything else. If they sort their breakfast out it would be great as most guests will want to eat the breakfast. The chefs need to be completely retrained on all western food. When the French Fries and bacon are chewy and old then no wonder they end up sitting there. The lady who makes eggs and omelette can't even properly fried eggs or make omelette. Someone who is more critical will ask for a poach egg at a 4* resort to test their capability but these guys in no way will be capable of knowing what one is. When I see another guest go and buy a frying pan and asked to fry their own egg/omelette (are was allowed!), I think that paints the picture. The problem was that there was not much on offer on Vietnamese food side and they were not particularly great either. Bun Bo Hue was way too spicy even without putting any additional chilli and Mien Ga was not cooked enough so the noodles was chewy. They had 2 juices and water which was sufficient but you would expect them to offer 2 other juices on a different day...not so. In fact the food was pretty much identical everyday we were there so that needs addressing. Toast butter and Jam came to the rescue. They didn't offer croissant so can't exactly say they have a continental breakfast option either. Their Bo Kho was reasonably good. Mi Xao was reasonable. I would suggest firstly get the eggs, bacon, fries right. Then without too much additional budget you can add american pancakes and syrup on there, maybe some standard Banh Mi options. Get some croissants and maybe apple and orange juices on a different day to mix it up. Do all those you may just clear 3*. I think it is doable for sure. There is a bar not far from reception but there was never anyone there as if it was never open so I hope they utilize that more in the future. Needless to say I never thought about their in room dining service if they had any....Their outside cafe seemed reasonable but as mentioned before it needs to be utilize more. miscellaneous -They offer a shuttle boat service which I failed to find out near the end so did not take advantage of that. That seems quite an interesting thing to do. -I hope they sort out their outdoor wedding karaoke thing. I understand that it seems a great idea but for the resort guests it isn't really acceptable. If they really are 4* quality then they need to stop that outdoor karaoke from their wedding bookings. Find an alternative please. Overall It is a good choice if you end up in Ben Tre city or just want to have some serenity from Ho Chi Minh City. Happy to stay again if I end up in Ben Tre in the future.

Title: Clean, upscale, but lacking in character
Review: The hotel itself is located about a 15-20 minute walk (or a short drive) to the market on the city-center waterfront. (It's tough to really say city-center with Ben Tre, as there are a couple of significant nodes that are separate from each other, but essentially, the hotel is a long walk from the action or a short drive.) The location was fine, though I wouldn't have minded having it a bit closer. They do have some bikes for rent, which we did, but they're a little heavy (and fixed gear), so it was hard work! The room was clean, the bed was comfortable, and the air-conditioning worked well. The property as a whole was also very clean, but almost too much so. It was very sterile - and we had come to Ben Tre to get away from that kind of feel in Ho Chi Minh. I really can't point to any specific thing that was wrong with the hotel, but just the same, I can't say I'd recommend it for a friend visiting Ben Tre. It would be a good change of pace if you've been doing homestays and are missing the amenities of modern life, like a really nice shower, but otherwise, I'd look elsewhere.

Title: Great setting, good tours, mediocre service
Review: We had mixed feelings about this place. The positive: The setting is excellent. It's a short (10 minute bike ride to town) and the farm rents bikes for 50,000 vnd for the length of your entire stay. There are lots of common areas, hammocks, and nice garden paths for relaxing. As we were looking for relaxation and exploring the country side, it was nice to stay here rather than the city center. The property also offers reasonably priced activities. We took a one hour boat trip (150,000 vnd) and the tour of the brick factory, coconut candy, and country bike ride (the standard offering on toys from Ho Chi Minh but without the transport). The cost on the latter varies depending on the number of people, but we paid approximately $10/person for 4 participants. The guide was good. We especially enjoyed the lovely bike ride at the end (about 1 hour, but can be more or less depending on the group's preference). The downsides were as follows: The standard double bungalows are really small, especially the bathroom. We were not expecting luxury, but it was hard to move around the room or sit normally on the toilet. In the low season there were often no English-speaking staff on site. This made it complicated to try to book tours or bus tickets or ask questions about bike rentals etc. The Wi-Fi stopped working in our room (though it worked elsewhere on the property) and we were told it couldn't be fixed until after we left. Things happen, but the staff made no attempt to make it up. For $17/ night in a very small, rustic room I appreciate it what what amenities there are work. Even a $1-2 discount as a gesture of goodwill would have gone a long way. Finally, a staff member quoted us the wrong price on the drinks. When we objected to the final bill, we were told that the other employee had been wrong and charged full price all the same. This drove home the lack of service.

Title: Worth stopping. Awesome ambiance

Title: What a wonderful homestay !!
Review: We stayed 3 nights in this homestay in the heart of the coconut city of Ben Tre (2h30 from Saigon) and I was sad to leave Huy and his wife who welcomed us so well! If you want to cut yourself off from the modern world and live in slow motion in the South Vietnam countryside then go for it! The house is decorated very nicely and there are 9 bedrooms including 2 communicating rooms (beds for 8 people!), Open bathroom (mosquito but there is a mosquito net for each bed), bathroom. water and greenery everywhere !! Huy offers the best meals of the Mekong Delta (we have not found better since we left), offers bike and boat trips on the Mekong to explore the activities of locals (making best coconut candy, banana candy, brick making, coffee etc ...) Title: Lunch stop for our private tour
Review: My wife and I stopped here for our lunch stop on the way to Can Tho from Saigon with our guide. It made a nice change from the city restaurants, and the food was good overall. We ordered a couple of beers (as usual) to go with our lunch and then tucked into some crispy Banana hearts (at least, I think they were?), followed by Pumpkin Soup (which was greatly improved by a little chilli sauce, but very tasty), and then the Elephant Ear fish, which is a sight to behold! Fortunately, a waitress came and dissected it for us, taking the best flesh (from the back of the fish) and wrapping it in rice paper to form a fish roll. It looks great, it appears to be deep fried with its scales still on (whole), so they form an interesting appearance as they peel off the cooked fish. However, it was overcooked and on the dry side, which was a pity. It's also very bony, the first fillet dissected by the waitress is fine, but attempt to pull any more fish from the body and you will end up with a mouthful of bones! Still, we had plenty of other dishes to eat, and all together the lunch was quite pleasant and it was lovely to eat out in the country with chickens, puppies and birdsong surrounding us and the Mekong river within sight!

Title: Prachtige locatie in de Mekong Delta
Review: Uitstekende kamer gelegen in een prachtige tuin aan het water. De gastheer waarmee wij twee dagen met de bromfiets in de Mekong Delta rondtoerden spreekt zeer goed engels en is een uitstekende gids. Vanuit de Homestay kan je mooie wandelingen of fietstochten maken in de omgeving.( fietsen gratis ter beschikking ) De gastheer en gastvrouw zijn uitstekende koks die elke avond heerlijke maaltijden klaar maakten en zorgden voor een goed en verzorgd ontbijt. Een echte aanrader voor mensen die houden van rust, natuur, lekker eten en ook op een ontspannen manier willen genieten van de omgeving.

Title: Good budget option
Review: This small guesthouse is run by a lovely couple who aim to give their guests a good experience. The place was clean, bedroom a good size and breakfast was excellent . Title: Quirky, cosy and has the best COLD pool !
Review: After many hours of research, we settled on the Oasis Hotel. On arrival, we realised our expectations were way too high BUT ... after 3 nights, we would happily have stayed another night. We settled in and enjoyed what WAS on offer! The rooms are VERY basic so prepare yourself for that. Aircon worked really well. Beds were comfortable. A shower curtain separating the shower and the toilet would have been good but, oh well! Cleanliness was satisfactory. Our room had a small fridge but no tea/coffee making facilities. A thermos of hot water was given to us on request which was great. The very clean, deep, cool pool was wonderful! We were in and out of it all the time. We were glad we chose a room on the ground floor, near to the pool. Kids will love it. Smoking was allowed by the pool which was great for those who smoke! We don't. LOCATION: we estimated a 30 minute walk in to town. It was an easy 10mins on the bikes. It will be much better if you are prepared to get on a bike. They were more than okay. They had gears. The street is quiet and runs parallel to the river. There's a 'beauty' salon 2 mins walk away. It was nice to enjoy a manicure and hair wash. We took the tour that previous reviewers recommended. We've done many tours in Vietnam and this was one of the best. The tour guide, Hong has very good English and this made a big difference as she was easy to understand. If you end up staying somewhere else, I'd recommend trying to get on one of her tours. She indicated that this might be possible. It's surprising that a tourist company hasn't snapped her up! We saw no other tourists whilst riding around Ben Tre. It's not touristy and that's why we liked it. In summary, if you want matching sheets and fluffy towels, keep doing your research but if you are looking for genuine hospitality and want to experience rural Vietnam, this is a good choice. Fish farm was 20km return bike ride. 3D Cafe is very close by and served great food. Always a good idea to eat where the school kids go!

Title: Family Travelling in South Vietnam
Review: We stayed at the Oasis Hotel in Ben Tre as part of a month long trip around SE Asia. I booked the hotel originally for 1 night. The hotel is basis but clean and most importantly it has a pool for the kids. The breakfasts were good and there a few places to eat within walking distance. The thing that really makes this place stand out are the tours and the tour guide Hong. She works at the hotel and does the tours. We booked the tour of the Mekong Delta and visited local businesses and had an amazing lunch before taking another trip up the bamboo lined streams. We enjoyed it so much we stayed and took a motorbike tour, again led by Hong. We visited her home, local businesses and the kids absolutely loved it. This stop was one of the best things we done over the month and I cannot recommend it highly enough if you want to get off the beaten track and see the real country.

Title: Great hospitality
Review: So many great reviews for this place and orur experience was no different. Hong was amazing, friendly and helpful. Arranged a boat trip to Tra Vinh for us, and even packed us a lunch. Ken's an interesting character and enjoyed chatting with him about history of Vietnam. Hotel is in a good location, and Hong does a great job of mapping out the town for you when you arrive, including restaurants and sights. Took the bikes for a spin, and wished we had time to rent the scooters. Would definitely stay here again, no question.

Title: A hotelnight and a oneway trip to Can Tho
Review: A last minute booking turning out to be a great experience. Hong and the other staff were so friendly and helpful. The hotel is peaceful and clean. Hong speaks god english and organised a boattrip for us, one way to Can Tho. It was wounderful! A few stops along the nine hour journey like a fish farm and a great lunch. But most of the time you just sit back and enjoy the scenery and the day to day life in the Mekongdelta.

Title: Really friendly staff!
Review: We stayed one night at the Oasis hotel and had a great time. The Staff was really friendly, especially Hong was the nicest contact! They booked as a fantastic boat-trip to Can Tho and we forgot some bathing suits and Hong managed a delivery to our Apartment in Ho Chi Minh! Thanks again for everything!

Title: Edwards on tour
Review: Fantastic 2 days at the Oasis, like family. Great comfortable rooms with brilliant air con. Excellent breakfast. Cannot beat the company of the wonderful Hung and Ken. Please visit if you are in Ben Tre, not too be missed.

Title: Mixed feelings
Review: I find this a difficult review to write as I have very mixed feelings about our stay there. I must say that I feel the lovely Hong is the glue that holds it all together - she is charming and so helpful (with a great sense of humour!). Her local knowledge is exceptional & she made our morning tour extremely enjoyable and interesting. The other staff are very pleasant and helpful but I found the owner's wife to be more interested in selling us a tour than anything else. As soon as we arrived, before showing us to our rooms or even offering us a welcome drink (which was standard in all other hotels we stayed in), she was talking about the tour they offer. I did not find her to be a very hospitable host, but Hong and the other staff definitely were. The rooms are very basic and the towels were paper-thin and fraying. I know it's a budget hotel, but one would hope for a decent towel, at least. There is a nice pool and what was very handy was a drying area to hang out our laundry. They have basic bikes for rent, which we made use of and had a nice ride in the countryside. It saddens me to report that the owner actually asked us to tip Hong, which I find unacceptable. We tipped Hong because she certainly deserved it and didn't appreciate being asked to do so by her employer!

Title: Great location, stellar hosts & fantastic tour!
Review: We went down to Ben Tre for the weekend and had a great time. Ken is a lovely host and really goes out of his way to help you with anything you might need. We organised a tour through them and Hong our guide was spectacular, it was such a great day out. The rooms are basic, but comfortable and the other amenities are fantastic (loved the pool and bikes!!). Thanks for such a wonderful stay!

Title: Come as guests...leave as friends
Review: Ben Tre Oasis is the perfect spot to unwind - peaceful, unhurried and relaxing! We stayed 2 nights and wished we stayed longer. Ken, his wife, Lieu and her two dogs made us feel so welcome and they are a wealth of information about the region. Little touches such as the detail map painted on the wall are a great help especially for great food and biking. Can highly recommend the Mekong tour with their girl Friday, Hong. This far exceed the one we took in Cantho because she has first hand knowledge of life there. Perfect English, Hong can provide insight on life straddling tradition and modern values. Love visiting and supporting local business so our tourist dollars can help local families. Coconut candies, dried fruit, honey are delicious and make perfect souvenirs cause who doesn't like food??

Title: Great hotel in Ben Tre
Review: We stayed 2 nights at the Oasis. The rooms were comfortable with everything you need. Breakfast was lovely. We enjoyed our Mekong tour with Hong. She is a beautiful lady with great knowledge of the workings of the Mekong delta. This was one of the best and most authentic tours you could do. Ken and his wife Liew were great company and run a very good establishment. There are good restaurants in walking distance from Oasis. We would recommend to anyone wishing for a more layback experience of the Mekong.

Title: Only at the oasis
Review: We stayed for 3 nights . I can say that this is a 5 star 2 star hotel. Yip the room is basic but you pay the price for that. Ken his wife and staff are amazing they will do any thing to help and have a wealth of local knowledge One day we took a trip with Hong from the hotel she lead us on an interesting local tour. On day 2 we took our own cycling trip with all the infomation provided by Hong and Ken's wife. I cant stress enough if you want to see a little of the real Vietnam come to ben tre and stay at the oasis hotel

Title: Much, much better than a standard mid-range hotel
Review: Very well run, and sensibly too, with a thorough briefing (after you've showered and rested, of course) on what to do in the surrounding area, helpfully demonstrated on a map painted on the wall next to the pool. Nice clean pool too, treated with salt water, so no nasty chemicals. After a month in the Delta I can honestly say this was definitely good value for money, and a bit of a haven. This place does things properly, but it also has a personality - it isn't just another bland hotel, and I think most people will appreciate what it's got to offer. And after reading a few other reviews, in hindsight I which I'd taken up the offer of a half day tour with Ms / Miss (?) Hong.

Title: If you want to see the Mekong Delta and have a wonderful trip, stay here.
Review: This was the second time i have stayed at the Oasis Hotel and it lived up all my great memories of the first time. Importantly, this is not a 5 star hotel, but it is comfortable, clean and the staff are great. The pool is great as it is very 'fresh and invigorating' on a hot day! Ms Lieu (wife of Mr Ken) is a lovely welcoming hostess and the rest of the staff, like Summer, are very friendly and helpful. But if you want to see the area, you have to tour with the wonderful Hong. I have done three tours with Hong and all of them have been absolutely the best to see the real Vietnamese life. She takes you on tours where you don't even see another tourist, she is very knowledgable, and lots of fun! A not to be missed experience.

Title: A true adventure in Ben Tre
Review: Like other reviews for this hotel, this is a real taste of the Mekong Delta area of South Vietnam. A true adventure and unforgettable experience. We were greeted at first by Hong who then became our tour guide. She showed us all the great areas to explore with the detailed map painted on the wall in the hotel. We rode motorbikes to the islands nearby and saw the rural life on the Mekong delta. The roads were safe as long as you paid attention to traffic. This was a real taste of adventure that not everyone gets when they travel. We could have rode the bikes forever. We went into town to the local mall/supermarket. Although as Westerners we stood out, the people there were absolutely friendly and wanted to practice their English and speak to us. The next day, Hong accompanied us as we rode the Mekong river delta all the way to Can Tho. Out of our whole trip to SE Asia in 3 weeks, this was by far the biggest highlight and most adventurous. The trip took 9 hours with various stops at fish farms, floating markets, and a quick stop to eat lunch. Hong's knowledge of the her country and Mekong life was truly inspiring and unforgettable. She showed us the true ways of Mekong river life. We really felt like we got to know her and her country. We exchanged great conversation the whole time. She prepared snacks and water for us during our journey. As we rode through the delta, we waved at everyone working and playing near the water. This was a long journey for not only us but the driver Yeoung and Hong too. They immediately went back to Ben Tre after dropping us off right in front of our hotel in Can Tho. We were extremely grateful for the whole experience in Ben Tre. Although we only stayed one night at the hotel, we instantly felt like family. We wish Hong and her twin baby girls the absolute best as well as the whole staff at the Oasis Hotel. Thank you so much for the great experience. We will definitely recommend Ben Tre to anyone going to South Vietnam to get a genuine adventure in Vietnam. Much love, Chase and Dylan from Seattle, Washington

Title: A taste of real Vietnam
Review: If you would rather stay in a soulless hotel in the main town then fair enough, but you're missing out. Missing out on local knowledge, food, stories and an excellent boat tour that takes you to some interesting places. Firstly, we got some advice from the amazing Hong about how to get to Oasis â€“ we took the Thinh Phat bus from Saigon to Ben Tre then the bus company transferred to a minibus and dropped us off right in the courtyard at Oasis. Just show the bus company your hotel details and they'll organise it for you. We let Hong know our estimated arrival time and she was there to greet us and show us the room. She then showed us the useful wall map/mural which I recommend photographing and using when you are out and about. First afternoon, we walked along to the Garden Restaurant (Mai and Tiem) for some great food and drink, then stopped for coffee at Cafe LÃ ng VÄƒn 2 with the lovely gardens. Next day, we booked up with Hong for the boat tour and she took us to the coconut candy factory, weavers, lunch and the rowing boat journey. It was excellent and Hong is lovely, a real inspiration! Second day, we did the cycling loop in the countryside which was knackering but so so interesting. Especially the wee ferry over to the island. The island is gorgeous, I'd have been happy enough to cycle around there all morning. We relaxed on the hammocks all afternoon, having beer and reading. Breakfast each day (included) was super â€“ eggs and fruit, enough to set you up for the day. And the dog is so cute, if you're nice he'll come over and sit under the hammock :) We mentioned to Ken about going to the local cafe (3D Coffee) and he offered me a lift on his homemade bike. If you are asked, go for it! Its so much fun to pootle along on a patio chair! On leaving, Hong was so helpful and arranged a taxi to the bus station for us. Our bus to Can Tho was the local bus and she even asked the driver to take us directly to the bus in the bus station. From start to finish, our experience getting to Ben Tre and being around the town were positive. Its not a touristy place, that's a real bonus. And the local kids who speak a bit of English are so enthused about seeing you, they constantly wave and say Hello! On our cycle back to Oasis, about 200 kids from the school cycled along waving and smiling at us. One thing to avoid though is the floating restaurant which is just a weird, uncomfortable experience. The sight of two staff fighting with each other over you is just bizarre, a kind of Vietnamese Fawlty Towers.

Title: Wonderful, Relaxing Stay
Review: We stayed here for 3 nights and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. The delta tour was very interesting mostly due to Hong's extensive knowledge of the area. Ben TrÃ© is pretty much off the beaten path so local knowledge helps a lot with things like taxis and catching the bus. They have bicycles and motorbikes for rent. I'd go with the motorbike as we got overheated pretty quickly riding the bikes even though it is flat. The cooked to order breakfast is delicious and comes with local tropical fruit.
