Title: Hong does a brilliant tour
Review: Would highly recommend this hotel to those who want to get a bit off the tourist trail and get a feel for village life in the Mekong Delta â€“ the tour run by Hong made it 5 stars. This is a small hotel with a laid-back atmosphere; the pool and communal areas with hammocks were great for relaxing and chatting to the other guests and the owners. Our family room was spacious and clean with one double and two twin beds (in our experience this was unusual in Vietnam and the kids appreciated having their own beds). However, the hotel is not as modern as some. Hong (who also manages the hotel) is lovely and so helpful. She gave us lots of info about the local area and we could hire bikes too. She also emailed us before we arrived with details of the Thinh Phat bus from Ho Chi Minh City which has a shuttle bus that will take you directly to the hotel. Breakfast was fine but the hotel does not do food throughout the day and restaurants around the area are not the best in Vietnam. The best thing about our stay was the half-day tour run by Hong â€“ perhaps the best tour we did out of half a dozen or so in our 3 week trip in Vietnam. She took us off the beaten-track on two boats and a tuk tuk and was great to chat to about her life and the locality; lunch was delicious in a fairly remote part of a nearby village. With only the four of us and two others on the trip it made it a great experience.

Title: Fabulous stay
Review: Only stayed 2 nights. Could have stayed longer. Took the Thinh Phat bus from Saigon. Excellent trip of 2 hours with a rest stop after 1 hour. They transfer to a smaller van and drop you at the door. Cost 75,000 dong. We did the self guided bike tour across to the island....easy ride of 30 or so kms. Flat and very interesting trip with 2 ferry rides. Roads no problem as traffic is light and you are on backroads. Pizzas from supermarket were surprisingly good especially in a down pour...they deliver for free and Wed is 2 for 1 deal. A private boat can be organised to Tra Vinh...not cheap so best to have more than just 2 people. Tea, coffee, biscuits and fruit were provided. Trip is 3 to 3 1/2 hours and a lovely way to see life on the delta. Rooms are good...it's a nice quite location...no traffic noise. Breakfast plenty of choices and Hong makes a great iced coffee....with fresh beans. All staff and "boss lady" were wonderful and make you feel very welcome. Special mention to the pocket rocket Hong...excellent English and full of helpful information and tips. We didn't do the boat trip but heard very good reports. Hong kept in touch with the boat skipper on our trip to Tra Vinh to make sure all was ok. Highly recommend.

Title: Riverside escape, a true oasis
Review: We stayed in this hotel for one night after catching the local bus from Ho Chi Minh City to Ben Tre and finding no hotels in the main part of town. Oasis was featured in the Lonely Planet guide book as one of the few English speaking hotels in the area, which is why we chose it. The room was nice and quiet with a TV, air conditioning, but no hairdryer or fridge. There's a pretty, shaded poolside area with hammocks and the front of the hotel faces onto the river, so it's very quiet. The owners are (I think) an Aussie and Vietnamese couple, but our main interaction was with receptionist, Hong. Her English is very good, she explained the attractions in the local area to us and recommended coffee shops and places to eat. We had a dip in the pool (unheated, but a relief from the heat of the day) and rented bikes from the hotel to explore the local area. It's not a very touristy area, so westerners appear to be quite a novelty - everyone we passed on the bikes waved and called "hello" to us and were delighted when we waved and called back. We took Hong's recommendation to have a massage at a local place staffed by blind women. Hong also helped us arrange a private cruise the next morning at sunrise back up the river to the floating markets at Can Be and dropping us off at our next destination, including a picnic breakfast on the boat ($50 USD each for the 4h trip) The staff here were very friendly and helpful, with a particular mention to Hong, who kept in touch with our boat captain by phone and translated for us after we'd left the hotel. An excellent stay, and I'd definitely stay here again.

Title: Good Overall Experience

The other plusses for staying here and the bike rentals, the scooter rentals, the free breakfast, the pool, cold beers, pickup at the dock for the cargo boat to Tra Vinh (a wow experience but it's not for everyone - 5 hours on the slo boat with no rest room, no cold drinks, no communication from the crew - we loved it) and it's fairly close to downtown (not walkable, but bike able). Honestly, if we go to Vietnam again I will skip Ben Tre, there isn't too much here except this is where we picked up the cargo boat. So the Oasis was a good experience, we met some other travelers who were fun, there was lots of shade, helpful staff. Only negative is that the kiwi side of the couple that owns the place has like a workshop annex right in the middle of everything, including oily towels that are a HUGE turnoff and he sits at his computer like he's in his private living room. Title: A real oasis away from HCMC.
Review: I decided to visit Ben Tre on a bit of a whim as I had a friend visiting me in HCMC and I didn't have the time to go all the way to Can Tho. I'm really glad I decided on Ben Tre as in many ways it was a much more pleasant experience. We arrived at lunch time and after some easy to follow instructions from Mrs Lieu we took a motorbike out for a few hours to explore the area, which is picturesque and easy to navigate. We had an early night and after enjoying a decent breakfast (something of a rarity in Vietnamese hotels) we went on a private boat trip with Hong. This was the real highlight of our short trip. Hong is knowledgeable, extremely friendly and her English is very good. She obviously cares a great deal about the people in her home town (see the way her face lights up when she talks) and has designed a tour that attempts to at least follow a route away from the bigger tours where possible. We visited the coconut farmers (who had actually finished for the morning, but still let us look around and gave us a quick demonstration) went to see coconut candy being made (admittedly part of most tours but we got there early before the place was over run with tourists). After that we went for lunch at a lovely spot in the village. We felt bad that we couldn't buy any souvenirs here (stupidly hadn't brought enough cash, so I advise anyone to budget a couple of hundred thousand to be able to contribute to the local community). After riding our bikes around the village a little we got on a small boat where we were able to get the classic 'jungle shots' reminiscent of many a war movie, before getting the boat back to the Oasis's private jetty. We then had a chance for a ride on Ken's crazy bike cum chair contraption and a quick chat before our arranged free transfer for the bus back to HCMC. I will certainly be recommending this place to friends here in HCMC and hope to bring any other visitors along in the future.

Best bet is to ring them when you arrive in Ben Tre town

Title: Our Favourite Kind of Place - Perfect Getaway From HCMC
Review: We have just returned from a wonderful long weekend in Ben Tre and an amazing stay at the Oasis Hotel. It is one of those special kind of hotels that is run by friendly staff and owners who make everyone feel welcome. From the minute we walked in, we knew we had chosen well. A map of the surrounding area is on a wall and it is explained with all those tidbits of information that travellers like... a good local restaurant and coffee shop close by, a hair wash place, the day and night markets etc. We immediately rented bicycles from them (they have motos as well) and explored the side of the river where the hotel is located (just across from Ben Tre) which is quaint, friendly and all those charming describing words you can think of. We had been worried that it was too far to get to Ben Tre but it is not at all. At night, we walked across the bridge and went to the night market and walked backed easily. We took our bikes to a ferry crossing as well to explore a near by island one morning as well. The hotel has a refreshing pool and yummy breakfasts as well that are included. Don't think twice about it... a perfect affordable retreat from HCMC and a taste of rural life in Vietnam that is not overrun by tourism. We will be returning for sure. Title: Great for the price, nice staff
Review: Oasis is a great hotel situated a bit outside of the "downtown" area of Ben Tre. We arrived during the off season, so for most of our stay we were basically the only people there! The owners (a married couple -wife from Vietnam and husband from New Zealand) were really nice and helpful. with their usual helpers off for the day, they allowed us to use their washing machine free of charge (this was about halfway through our trip and we desperately needed to do a wash). The owners nephew was also kind enough to show me the surrounding neighborhood on the back of his bike (though I think the point was to practice a bit of English with me. I'm an English teacher, so I didn't mind!) They were also kind enough to schedule and setup a tour for us around the Mekong. Since it was off season it was just the 4 of us and our guide, but I imagine during peak months they pack the boats as much as they can. Either way, the tour was totally worth it! Highly recommended. PS Be advised: they don't accept credit cards for the tours (or for rooms, I believe?) and you will want to buy some stuff on the tour as well so bring plenty of cash! The tour guide will bring you to an ATM in town if you run short (as we did), but don't expect easy access to money changers.

Title: A most awesome experience
Review: Ben Che was an interesting and unique town, with its main industry being coconut. What made the whole experience incredible, started and ended with Oasis Hotel. For breakfast I had the standard omlette and baquette but it was filled with a delicous sauce, which was a unique twist on most uninspired omelette breakfasts you get in Vietnam. The tours that Oasis leads, give both an understanding of the importance of the coconut industry, and allow you to experience the culture of the region. Overall I would say that Oasis made a possibly mediocre visit to a remote region of the Vietnamese Delta into and brilliantly fascinating, and entertaining experience. Title: Great place to explore Ben Tre and the Delta
Review: For 30 USD, rooms are quite modest but comfortable. The kindness of the owners and the manager, as well as the swimming pool and filling free breakfast still provide good value for the price. We could borrow a cellphone in case anything happened and we were even offered snacks for free when we learnt that the boat would not stop for lunch as planned initially (to make sure we would catch our bus back on time). Bikes can be rent for 60 000 VND per day and the staff will inform you on the many fun bike rides you can do to explore the surroundings. The town center is about a 5 minutes bike ride away and features a nice market. Last reco, oasis can be hard to reach since the bus station is about 5 km away from the center and often buses from Ho Chi Minh city will drop you even further on random spots along the road, where taxis are scarce. Just contact oasis before getting there and they will give you advice on how to get there without too much hassle. Overall great and fun stay. We would definitely return if we go back to Ben Tre.

Title: Good value, clean & friendly. Make sure you do the boat trip
Review: Unlike Can Tho, Ben Tre is a distinctly quieter Mekong Delta town and that's one of the best reasons to visits. You won't see hordes of tourists here. And Oasis is a really great place to explore the region from -- something the staff will happily help you do. It's run by a Kiwi guy, Ken, and his Vietnamese wife, Lieu, who are chatty, knowledgeable and warm. They also have an amazing employee Hong who organises superb tours through nearby Mekong villages via boat and bicycle. She speaks superb English and is unflappably friendly. The hotel itself is mid-range, simple but clean. Rooms decent sized, good hot water showers, comfortable beds and TVs. Wifi works well. There's a small pool to cool down if the weather is hot and a nice outdoor area with hammocks for relaxing. Oasis is a little way out of town, on the other side of the river from the main market but I really wouldn't let that put you off. For a start, you have a quiet street and a nice view of the main town from where the hotel is. Plus there are bikes that you can hire to get into town within 10 mins. Behind the hotel is a network of concrete paths and canals that can also be explored on bikes. There's a fantastic local restaurant within walking distance and a newly opened care selling ice cream. Ken or Hong will tell you how to get there. The main reason I came was to see a slice of life in the Mekong and Hong's tour was fantastic. I got lucky, I was the only person staying in the hotel at the time. We took two bikes onto a motorised boat down the main river and then turned into smaller tributaries, stopping along the way at a brick factory, a small coconut factory and a family run mat making business. Nothing felt pressured or faked, these are real factories with real people in them. They're not set up for tourists, but tourists are welcome. The work is hard and Hong doesn't sugar coat it, she shows you what Mekong manual labour looks like and boy does it make you feel lucky. Later we switched to the bikes to explore more of the inland villages for lunch before placing them back on a small paddle boat and then rejoining the bigger motorised one. The whole tour, which was from 8-1pm cost $40 not including tips which felt entirely reasonable. I think if there are bigger groups the price is $30. So if you want a clean, comfortable, affordable stay in Ben Tre that lets you see some of the real Mekong Delta, Oasis is a good recommendation.

Title: helpful & welcoming budget hotel
Review: Ken and Lieu (the owners) are friendly and welcoming, but never overbearing. The rooms and bathrooms have everything you need and are clean and well presented, but a little small. The decor and fixtures are a little dated. The pool and outdoor spaces are great. Reviews suggest that accommodation options in the Mekong region are not decadent. I was undecided about where to stay, Ben Tre or My Tho. Ben Tre was great and the hotel has good restaurant options nearby. The real deal breaker however is the excellent communication and service offered by Hong, the charming young lady at the hotel. Hong arranged three trips on the Mekong for us during our stay. A seven (yes 7) hour boat transfer from Can Tho to Ben Tre (including an additional round trip to the floating market at Can Tho); evening fire flies tour; and finally a tour of local industries and canals around Ben Tre. Title: My stay at Oasis Ben Tre
Review: The Oasis is a small hotel situated just on the other side of the river from the main town. We caught a taxi from the main bus station expecting a trip of around 1km. (we caught a local very cheap bus from Can Tho.........never again, take the vip bus or an equivalent) The hotel advertises that this is the approx distance from the city centre. The trip was actually around 5 km as the bus station is not near the city centre and my partner was starting to wonder if we were being taken for a ride. This was not the case so don;t worry if you are watching the taxi meter and the km's start to clock up. Once there the owner Ken originally from NZ made us feel very welcome indeed and we immediately started to feel at home. From an English speaking point of view it was a breath of fresh air to be able to communicate clearly with Ken who knows the town and the people very well. Ken is very laid back and to the point, he will sometimes sit there as guests come in and not introduce himself as the owner. Quite the comedian and gentleman he is light hearted and engaging. The tour that is run from his hotel was simply amazing and an experience i will never forget and highly recommend. We had done a few other small tours within Vietnam with extremely friendly and competent guides but i would say this was the better. You can hire motor bikes and cycles or swing the day away in hammocks by the (covered) pool. The Oasis hotel is close to the city centre with a short walk over the bridge, the rooms are clean and with hot water that actually runs hot (unlike most of the hotels we managed to find ourselves in) On a personnel level i would like to thank the staff and especially Ken who went out of his way to ensure I found what i needed in Ben Tre. Putting me on the back of his bike we scoured the city for provisions. Ben Tre is a town with money and it is an up and coming destination. The town markets located under the bridge are a must to visit. Riding no more than 2-3 minutes on a motorbike from the hotel you are in the country with local villages and small local bars. I would return to Ben Tre and the Oasis Hotel in a heart beat. Thank you for a great stay and good luck in the future. Barry (Kiwi) and Michele

Title: The warmest of welcomes
Review: My stay at the Oasis Hotel, Ben Tre was one of the highlights of 6 months on the road. Located on a quiet stretch of the river opposite the main part of Ben Tre, the hotel, replete with hammocks, a pool and bar, is the perfect place to chill out and a base from which to explore the beauty of the Mekong Delta. The rooms are better appointed than other hotels I have stayed at in Vietnam and the wifi signal is constantly strong. However, the real pleasure in staying at the Oasis derives from the genuine friendliness and impeccable service from the owners and staff. Ken and Lieu are the perfect hosts and I spent much time enjoying a chat with Ken over an icecold Saigon. Nothing is too much for the owners and staff, and they go far above and beyond expected service standards (whether this be offering running guests into town to go to the ATM on their mopeds, inviting them for a beer or an impromptu nautical adventure). The Oasis runs a fascinating tour of the local waterways and industries - conducted by the vastly knowledgable Ms Hong - who's passion for her local area is manifest. Don't let the fact that it has lunch provided at a local restaurant put you off: this is both delicious and huge! Ken's gregarious nature purveys the hotel and it is the most sociable place I have stayed, with guests and staff chatting round the bar area and the pool. If you want privacy though, this is respected too. The fact that many of the guests staying, while I was there were returning visitors, is testament to the hotel's qualities. I look forward to visiting again soon, to visit my new friends. Believe the reviews, believe the hype and experience the Oasis hotel yourself is you are in the area.

Title: Excellent experience
Review: One of the highlights of my 2013 August /September trip to the Mekong was a night at Ken's Oasis in Ben Tre. From NYC I arranged for a cargo boat transit from Oasis to Tra Vinh. Ken is a mechanic in an old world way building next to anything from scrap, as a veteran and mechanically inclined myself I appreciated his approach to the landscape and people. I rented a motorbike from a hotel in town and rode 1,600 km with what Ken agreed to be an "excellent" map (International Travel Map Mekong Delta 1 : 500,000) bought online from North Carolina's OmniMap). Third night in south VN and final night in delta and I would recommend Oasis to any veteran trying to reclaim his root; semi-adventure travelers getting off their tours; mindful people who despise tours; and whackos who like canopied pools to bookend long solo rides through the lower four states of the beautiful geography comprising the terminus of the twelfth longest river in the world. there's really only one reason not to go directly from that layover in Taipei to Ben Tre- that's that the Oasis is booked full.

Title: OK
Review: Based on all the very positive reviews we decided to stay here for two nights. In general, our stay was OK but honestly we did not really understand why everyone is so over the moon about this hotel. It is not really in a nice spot: a not too attractive area which is remote from the city of Ben Tre and another small town (about 20 minutes walking over a bridge which is not really intended to be crossed by foot, so it seems (not unsafe but just not nice to walk on)). Because of its location we ended up at the hotel premises rather early after dinner again (there is nowhere else to go so it seems) and we did not like the public areas: it is basically the living room of the owner and there was only one soft drink available even though the list of drinks showed several options. There were plenty of beers but my wife does not drink that so we ended up going to a nearby shop to get our own supply. The swimming pool is right next to this area so I have to agree with another comment that it does lack intimacy. Good to refresh though. The rooms are basic but OK: nothing special but also nothing to complain. The offered breakfast was simple but tasted good. We did get some recommendations for excursions and decided to rent bikes. For Vietnam these were a bit expensive (60k VND per bike/day (we paid only 20k in Hoi An...)) but good and we were able to see the local villages and some factories. Regarding dinner options: we'd suggest you skip the Floating Restaurant if you want to have a proper Vietnamese experience: we went there but ended up sitting next to two big groups of Dutch tourists. Not really what you go to Ben Tre for! We really like the restaurant which is in the nearby small village (I think it was called Mai Vang). Our general feeling at the end was that is was OK, nothing more but also nothing less.

Title: A unique charm
Review: Basic accommodation but all the necessities are provided and the cost reflects what you get which makes The Oasis really good value for money. What makes it exceptional value is what money cannot buy; just by being themselves everybody here contributed in a positive way to making our too short stay wonderful and relaxed. Booking direct with the hotel was a simple process with emails being replied to promptly and efficiently by either Ken the owner or Hong who also arranged our cars to and from HCMC at better prices than we could find elsewhere. On our first day we rented bicycles from Oasis and did a bit of getting out and about by ourselves. Easy to find your away around and to explore little tracks as the rivers and bridges act as points of reference. On our second day was the 'piece de resistance', Hong took us on a guided tour of their part of the Mekong Delta during which we used a small motorised boat and smaller rowed boat and bicycles. Just travelling around this, as yet, relatively unspoiled part of the world was a delightful, educational and wonderful experience. Visiting a brick factory, coconut sweet making factory and other notable local industries was cream on the cake. While taking lunch at a restaurant during the tour we saw a steady stream of tourists heading past us through the jungle, we asked Hong where they were going, she told us that they were going to a restaurant that is specially for tourists and isn't very good. Our food however was excellent with a number of local dishes and fresh spring rolls made with Elephant ear fish as the main ingredient. All in all the tour was one of the highlights of our time in SE Asia. Recommend you get to visit here before demand from Chinese, Korean and Russian tourism spreads this way and completely ruins Ben Tre, I asked Ken over an evening beer what his plan was when the inevitable occurs, his reply was mostly unprintable. At night we took our bicycles and headed into Ben Tre which is charming yet unremarkable and that in itself makes time spent here worthwhile. The market caters for local consumers with dignified stallholders and as yet is not flooded with overpriced tourist memorabilia. There was very little of interest that we had not already seen elsewhere and nothing in my size but is still worthy of a visit. Not much English is spoken here and my wife thinks that the sight of 6'1", blonde (going grey) Englishman cycling around with a tiger balloon tied to the back of his bike stopping at food stalls and miming what he wanted to eat will live in local memory for a while. In other cities it is probably an every day occurrence but here that is not the case. All in all Ben Tre was a very worthwhile part of our trip and I really wish we had stayed longer here. Oasis hotel is wonderful, welcoming, friendly and excellent value for money.

Title: Lovely place in a nice, quiet town
Review: Seriously, I'm just finishing my breakfast at Oasis Hotel. It's a really nice place with hospitable owners and helpful staff. Ben Tre is absolutely off the beaten track, but easy to reach. When in Saigon (HCMC) just get to Thin Phat bus company near District 1, the address is on the website of the Oasis Hotel. Title: well-named, well-done!
Review: After spending the previous week in Hanoi and HCMC, I was ready to get away from the noise and stress of the city. Oasis Hotel at Ben Tre turned out to be the perfect choice. It was only 2 1/2 hours and about 75000 dong away by local bus, which leaves something like 7 times a day from HCMC and drops you off right in front of the hotel. While I was there, they were able to arrange a tour for me last minute, even though I was traveling alone. The tour was made to order. I said I wanted a small boat, to see some nice scenery. I left at 8am with Mr. Liem and his dog, and he took us into ever smaller waterways until I had to sit on the floor of the boat because the canopy was so low overhead and the palm fronds brushed both sides of the boat! In the meantime, there was plenty of river life to photograph. We also stopped at a large hut where a group of ladies were sitting on the floor weaving brooms and where Mr. Liem bought some fresh coconut and chopped at it with a hatchet so that we could each have a coconut juice to drink on the boat. It was very pictureseque and exactly what I was hoping to see in the Mekong delta. For only an extra 50000 dong, Mr. Liem also took me on a mini-tour on land afterwards, which included visits to the coconut candy "factory" and brick "factory" as well as a visit to his favorite vegetarian restaurant, which was quite good and cheap. I wasn't all that interested in visiting the factories, especially the brick one, at first. The word "factory" is a bit of a turn-off, as it made me expect something industrial and depressing. But I'm so glad I ended up going, because they are nothing like how westerners think of factories. The coconut candy factory in particular was really just a few workers sitting around a table making everything by hand. It was a great place to buy gifts and souvenirs, as they let me sample everything, and had many homemade coconut-related products for sale, besides the candy. Kiwi Ken, his wife, and the other people I met at the hotel (friends of Ken and other guests) were wonderfully down-to-earth, friendly, and interesting. The vibe by the pristinely clean pool was very relaxing. Comfy hammocks were scattered everywhere. Cold beer was always available. Both pool and hammocks were covered from the sun. It seemed easy to either keep to yourselves, if you wanted privacy, or join Ken & company at the long picnic table in the evening for a bit of socializing and meeting new people, if that's what you were after. It's true that the hotel is not in the center of town, but you can walk across the bridge to a market, some stores, and restaurants in about 10-15 minutes, or to a nice restaurant around the corner in about 5. As others have said, bikes are on loan. And Ken himself was nice enough to offer rides into town on the back of his motorbike. So I didn't find myself at all inconvenienced at any point during my stay. Ah, Oasis Hotel, I miss you already, and I hope to be back soon!

Title: Not the Hilton ... A very Good Thing
Review: Before going to the Oasis in Ben Tre, the owner Ken downplayed this charming little hotel in an email to me, telling me not to expect the Hilton. But what this charming little hotel has is everything a chain or large hotel doesn't: mainly that personal touch coupled with a real family and friends atmosphere. The Oasis is owned by an expat Kiwi and his lovely wife Lieu. Staffed with a very friendly group of young workers and located in the heart of the heart of Vietnam, this is the place to stay. The rooms are basic but super clean, there is a pool and there is good cold beer and iced coffee (the included breakfast is good - the Vietnamese coffee is of course superb). There are friends of the hotel that come around, expats from other countries mostly, who are all nice and extremely interesting to talk to. The hotel is also quite family friendly. We rented bicycles each day during our three night stay and traveled the back roads leading in and around the various tiny villages along the river. This province has not been tainted by tourism yet. There isn't a two tier system on prices, for instance, the smiles are genuine and you will be warmly welcomed at every little coffee shop or restaurant you happen to stop at. Indeed, as we pedaled along the little roads and paths we heard innumerable children calling out "hello" as we passed. The hotel also rents motor bikes (the little 125 cc's you see everywhere in Vietnam) which appear to be in good condition. The bicycles could use some work - but bicycles in Vietnam are pretty crummy everywhere. The market in town is easy to get to (just across the bridge) and there is an indoor market catering to Vietnamese with numerous clothes and other shops. Both enjoyable and worth a visit. There is a pretty young woman selling fruit smoothies down on the left outside of an appliance type store, usually with a young girl helping her. Recommended and the folks sitting around her are all fun. If you have any questions or need ideas about what to do or see - just talk to Ken or Lieu or one of the staff. There is lots of information available from them on what to do and where to go. They can arrange local guide trips at reasonable prices or just give great suggestions. There is no pressure here to use their services. We rented their bikes one day and pedaled to an island (with ferry service) for lunch and a cruise around the river. Great time. A local walk to a dinner restaurant that I highly recommended is Mai Vung. Excellent food, spectacular dÃ©cor and feel, really superb service and very reasonable Vietnamese prices to boot. We went there twice we liked it so much. They actually have two menus â€“ the one in English is shorter and there is a longer mostly, indecipherable one, in Vietnamese (and I had a Vietnamese food guide to help - the excellent "Fat Noodle Guide to Vietnamese Street Food"). After Mai Vung walk further along to the 3D Cafe for some incredible ice cream and very nice servers and atmosphere. The various cafes and street restaurants in and around Ben Tre are all very good as well. There is a bia hoi place (daily fresh beer at about 25 cents a glass) (easy bicycle ride and longer walk) from the Oasis. The Bia Hoi place is highly recommended. Very cheap but very good fresh beer and homemade snacks prepared by the very nice family that runs it. This province of the Mekong and Ben Tre were my personal favorites traveling around Vietnam. Beautiful, lush, great food, wonderful friendly local people, basic amenities and most importantly, few tourists. I wish I was there now having a cold one with Ken.

It's an easy walk or ride across the river to the main town where the busy market is and well as restaurants and a large supermarket. There is a local restaurant nearby, from which we ordered takeaway with the hotel staff's help. It was a rainy night, so having dinner delivered and eating under the covered patio was a treat - they arrived on a motor bike, carrying a tray with our food on china dishes and set it all up, complete with little dishes of sauces, napkins, the chopsticks across the bowl. Later they returned to pick up the dishes. Great service. We thoroughly enjoyed our stay at the Oasis and found Ken and Lieu to be welcoming hosts and all the staff helpful and friendly.

Title: Escape the tourist-trap and explore the real Mekong Delta
Review: We have just arrived home after a great 2 weeks traveling around Vietnam. Two nights on the Mekong Delta was our last stop and we were desperate to escape the well-worn tourist path, so we chose Ben Tre and stayed at Oasis Hotel. We arrived late, so Ken quickly showed us to our rooms (we had the choice of one by the pool or a quieter room around the back)- we chose the Pool side room. The room had great aircon, a very comfy bed (not hard like many of the budget hotels in Vietnam) and great shower pressure. Basic but very clean and comfortable. At the price you couldn't ask for more! Ken then gave us a quick overview of the Ben Tre area and set us in the direction of the restaurant around the corner armed with a Torch. The menu was very extensive and we over-ordered but very reasonable prices. The next day we wanted to explore the surrounding villages so Ken set us up with a motorbike and a great explanation of areas to see. It was a fabulous day- not a tourist in site! (Apart from ourselves). No one spoke English and no one tried to sell us anything. We were greeted at every corner with a smile and a big 'Hello!' I would suggest to anyone wanting to venture off the beaten track as we did, having a phone with a GPS map is very very handy. No one in the area will understand Maps (a lot of people are not educated and would never have seen a map before) plus the language barrier makes it difficult if you do get lost. We rode to Ba Tri, another rural town South-East of Ben Tre. From there we followed the water line and hopped on a ferry to one of the tiny islands in the fingers of the Mekong. The island was great- no cars, barely any people or houses-only a narrow concrete and dirt path. We had a ball weaving our way through palm forests. We caught two ferries during the day, the first cost 3000D and the second 5000D (charged per bike, not per person). We then returned to Ben Tre by the main rode. The day trip took us about 6hrs but we had many breaks along the way. On our return, Ken asked my partner if he'd like to join him for a drink at their local waterhouse. Ken is very welcoming and such an interesting character! Our final day we jumped on a halfday tour with two other Aussie ladies. We ate lots of coconut products, listened to some local music and had a great lunch. We traveled by boat and by bikes. During the tour we did see a couple of other large tour groups (8-12 people all traveling together by boat and open-air buses). We went to different places to them that were much quieter, where we four were the only ones there, and I preferred the bike riding down small tracks rather than taking a bus! Back at Oasis, Ken let us shower in our room (even though we had officially checked out) and had a final beer by the pool with him and some of the other guests. Ken and his wife are such warm people and their generosity filters down to their guests- so it is a more communal experience than in other hotels/b&bs. Ken then booked us our bus back home with a free pick up service from the door of the hotel. A great experience! Anyone wanting to stay away from the package tour floating market/overcrowded mass of Can Tho should definitely check out Ben Tre and stay with Ken at Oasis!

If you want to get off the standard tourist trail, Ben Tre is worth a stop. People are friendly and don't pester you incessantly to buy. It reminded me of rural areas I ran across in Cambodia several years ago.

Title: Great value for money.
Review: Some of the other reviewers have rated the rooms "sober" - I must be accustomed to more meagre Hotels, because I thought our room was superb. I think we paid around $30 a night, and it was a really comfy bed, nice clean bathroom, spacious room, with a nice big window. Over-all the staff were friendly, though Ken was away, and the chap in charge was friendly in a mildly 'officious' manner. Once you got past that front he was nice enough. The breakfast to me is disappointing as there are no Asian choices. Unfortunately though that seems to be common in Vietnam. Having said that, the omelette was very nice. The coffee was horrendous - but I should have thought of asking for some more hot water. The pool is a great touch, and you are protected from the burning sun by a full roof cover. Unfortunately this makes the water very cold, but I guess you can't have everything! At least you are protected from sunburn! Tips on what to do in the area; Rent the Hotel bicycles and ask them to show you the route to the little ferry that goes across to a tiny island. It's a great experience - we caught the ferry with children on their way to school. Also ride the bicycles into town to the supermarket where you can pick up your supplies. The local Restaurant around the corner from the Oasis has some great meals but avoid the chicken! We had chicken and it was a tough old boiler we could barely chew. We nearly didn't go back there until some other Guests at the Hotel recommended some other dishes, so we went back and had some other really nice meals including clams in ginger, and huge shrimp. For dinner we went to Chuon Chuon Restaurant which I can't speak highly enough of. The menu is all in Vietnamese so ask at the Oasis to write down what sort of meals you'd like before you go. You can ride a bicycle there or catch a taxi. The food is outstanding. The Hotel will arrange tours for you if you ask but we chose just to wander the town and relax. It's a great place for that. The locals don't see huge numbers of tourists so they often smile and say hello! So we will definitely return to the Oasis in the future to unwind and enjoy the slower pace!

Title: A home away from home

They even tried to arrange for me to visit the hospital in town to see the labor unit as I work as a labor RN in the states. Phoung, the owner's son, spent time with us poolside with a cold beer, offered us insight into life in Vietnam, in Ben Tre, in the Mekong Delta. On our last day, they took us to the local market to buy prawns and then cooked them up for us, along with a huge lunch that we shared before boarding the local bus back to Saigon which they arranged for us. The only thing I can think to advise people about is that no one is going to come in your room and pick up after you. Personally, I was perfectly happy finding my room the way I left it; it always seems strange to me to make someone else responsible for cleaning up after me. If you aren't into keeping your room neat, either deal with it, or stay at the other places that will not nearly give you the same personable attention. The ONLY reason I bring this up is because some people might get bent out of shape about stuff like that, and I would hate to see the genuine customer care and regard be replaced by seemingly insignificant details due to complaints. Please don't ruin it for everyone else. We absolutely loved staying at the Oasis Hotel, and wish Ken and his incredibly kind family the best; they absolutely deserve it.

Title: A good place to get sick!
Review: After we stayed for more than two weeks in and around Hanoi and northern Vietnam, we flew to Saigon. In Saigon we took a taxi to the Oasis Hotel in Ben Tre where we stayed for a couple of nights. After spending some time in northern Vietnam, where people can't hardly speak or understand English, it was a pleasant surprise that the hotel owner comes from New Zealand and the rest of the family and staff speaks/understands English as well. They have a good knowledge of the local environment and people and can help and arrange tours for you. Unfortunately I got sick and had to stay at the hotel. While the always friendly staff and family members supported me a bit while I was sick, they also helped my girlfriend planning some daily trips she could do on here own (and took her out for dinner ;-)). Bottomline; if your going to Ben Tre, this should be your first pick!

Title: What an amazing stay..
Review: I have just returned to Saigon from a wonderful three days staying at the oasis hotel in Ben Tre. What a friendly bunch of people! It is run by a Kiwi named Ken and his family, and you couldn't ask for a better host away from the chaos of saigon. Perfectly situated just metres away from the Mekong River, it is a quiet location at night allowing for a restful sleep but only minutes away from the centre of Ben Tre and all its resturants and sights. The staff of th hottel are very easy to get along with, full of helpful information about the local area, things to do and places to see. Many a good conversation was had over beers at sundown, with Ken even hooking up the screen to watch the world cup rugby with us (shame he was an all blacks supporter, but you cant have everything right?). The pool was also a fantastic way to cool off after a warm day sightseeing. The Mekong Delta tour that the owner put us onto was fantastic, such good sights along the river stopping in at places to see the ways in which the locals work and live. If you are in Ben Tre, I suggest doing this trip, especially as the boat picked us up from the Mekong Delta only 20 metres from the hotels front gate! All in all, an excellent place to stay, friendly and great value for money. I will defintely return to the oasis and use it as my base for further travels throughout Vietnam. Cam

Title: A true Oasis!
Review: I stayed at Hotel Oasis with friends and ended up spending much longer in Ben Tre than we had originally planned. Title: Excellent choice - like a homestay, but with all the comforts
Review: We stayed here as part of our 'Come & Go Vietnam' Mekong Delta tour. We had to specifically ask to stay at this hotel and by all reports poor Ken & Lieu were put through the wringer by the company. We were however, extremely glad we did stay here. Ken & Lieu welcomed us like part of the family and even though our stay was for only one night, we certainly made the most of their wonderful hospitality. Ben Tre is a beautiful spot and with the new bridges in place much more accessible to Ho Chi Minh. The city is thriving with construction going up everywhere. We were still the only westerners (and we provided endless amounts of enjoyment to the locals) at the wet market the next morning though.. Ken & Lieu provided us with some insight into the region - how things are progressing rapidly now that applications for development are considered locally rather than going up to the Party officials in Hanoi for consideration as was previously the case. This stay was one the absolute standouts in our 7 week holiday in Asia (Indochina). As mentioned in the heading with only 9 rooms it is almost like a homestay, but with aircon, hot showers and comfy beds and at about $16 per double per night, it represents great value for money. I would recommend this hotel to anyone and certainly hope to go back again and stay for a lot longer than one night next time. Thank you Ken & Lieu and family for a wonderful stay.

Title: Highly recommend it, We loved it.
Review: We stayed here (as a family of 4) and loved it. The rooms are big, there is a lovely area with tables and hammocks (roofed so protected from rain and sun) just to chill out it. Ken is working on a translated menu though so things might be ok when you get there.)

Title: The highlight of our visit to the Mekong !
Review: What a wonderful experience it was to stay at Hong Thai Homestay. Thai and his wife were most hospitable and generous hosts. If you prefer to be away from the popular tourist destinations, this is the place to come. You will see, experience and hear about life in this part of the Mekong Delta...amazing! Mr Thai is passionate about the environment, the Delta and the local people and is more than happy to share his wealth of knowledge and experience. His 76 year old friend Mr Huong took us on a 3 hour trip... on bikes, in boats, visiting a small coconut candy factory,and to his own home to meet his wife (who gave us a platter of fresh fruit and made tea for us) Such beautiful, kind people ! This excursion with Mr Huong was extra and optional but we were so pleased to have done it and would certainly consider it a must do ! Another highlight was Thai's wife's home cooked meals... all included ! Lunch and dinner were always fresh local fish, beautifully cooked and presented. If you're not a big lover of fish...you only need to mention it and you'll be given delicious vegetable dishes. If you like all the creature comforts of a five star hotel this definitely isn't the place for you... but to experience the charm and hospitality of rural Vietnam (a pond, chooks & fruit trees right outside the open air window)... don't miss out ! PS - Keep a look out for Mr Thai's new project "Hong Thai Homestay Riverfront"...looks amazing and not far off completion !

Title: Amazing experience
Review: This place is absolutely amazing, and i would wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone who wants to see the Mekong Delta "off the beaten track". When we arrived, we were a little sceptical of the other good reviews. We were initially put in a wooden cabin above the water which was very basic, but Thai (the owner) was very happy to move us to one of the other rooms. The room is still fairly basic, but gave us everything we needed. And the rooms aren't the reason to visit! Throughout our stay, Thai was the perfect host - nothing was too much trouble. The food (which is all included in the price) was delicious - freshly cooked fish cooked by Thai's wife. We were also plied with seemingly endless amounts of local fruit from Thai's own gardens. Thai arranged tours for us (at additional cost) which were a great way to see the local area, and with very engaging tour guides - ask for Huong's love story and language lessons! Thai is currently developing some new accommodation right on the Mekong river, which could be spectacular once completed. If you're looking for a luxury hotel, then this isn't the place for you. But if you want to see the real Mekong Delta, with a first class host, then you won't find a better place!

Title: Can not recommend
Review: Of all the homestay experiences I have had in the Mekong Delta, this is the only one I would never return to. The common practice of the homestay owner is to send his employee to nab unsuspecting travelers when they step off the bus and take them to his homestay. We actually had a reservation at a completely different place, but his motorbike "nabber" waylaid us and even posed as the guy we were meant to stay with. We trusted him and only started to suspect that we had been tricked when we were charged almost double what we had agreed to at the original place. They would not let us leave and insisted we join the boat tour (which was a series of stops at tourist trap gardens and honey farms - not the usual pleasant boat ride in Mekong backwater). Our friends drove down from Saigon to rescue us, but still were not able to get back the full amount of money we were overcharge. Mr Thai runs a dis-honest business and is a poor representation of the usually kind and generous people of the Mekong Delta. As a long-time resident of Vietnam, I was doubly disappointed to read the reviews of how many other unsuspecting travelers he has duped. Stay away!

Title: Secret homestay in authentical Mekong Delta
Review: We wanted to enjoy the Mekong Delta the authentic and non-touristic way and we could not wish for anything better! We had to take the early bus from Ho Chi Minh City to Ben Tre where we were picked up by scooter drivers who brought us to the lonely homestay of Thai. It was paradise! In the middle of his little garden full of mango and papaya trees he welcomed us with a cool coconut drink! After showing us our cozy bungalow on the water, an ealderly neighbour picked us up for a bicycle ride through the wunderful Mekong Delta!he explained us in english what every plant was and what the people use it for. We were invited to drink a tea at his house where he teached us some vietnamese words. After a great homemade lunch at the homestay we were picked up for a private boat trip through the narrow water canals and visited Turtle Island. During the little trip we were invited to try so many different and interesting fruits of the Delta region -just delicious!!We also visited a coconut candy manufacture before watching the sunset from the boat. It was just the perfect tour to get a real impression of the land and people of the Mekong Delta! In the evening we had a wonderful dinner prepared by Thai's wife. Though we were not hungry after all the fruit tasting, we had to try everything!it was delicious! The second day, we were picked up after an early breakfast to go on a scooter tour. The guides where very friendly and spoke very good english.they took us to real local markets where foreigners had never been seen before(!) and again we were invited to try all the food. We visited farms and rice fields as well as a very local spot where we had very good vietnamese lunch. Last stop was XY where a private boat would take us to the floating markets!our guide explained everything so good that we learned so much and I think we will remember that day for very,very long!! The bus ride back to Ho Chi Minh was organized by Thai so that we did not need to care about anything. It was a real highlight of our trip through Vietnam!!probably the most authentic experience!

Title: Peaceful Garden in the Delta
Review: I really enjoyed speaking with Thai about the projects he's undertaken for the good of his neighbors and community; he really cares about his home and the people he shares it with. Thai's wife (I apologize for forgetting names) was all too generous as a chef, and the food (and local produce) was by far the best I had over the course of five days in the delta. It was perhaps a bit difficult to speak to anyone but Thai himself in English, but it's all the more reason to learn a few words of Vietnamese, and I can't say I hold it against the family for maintaining living spaces apart from the guest's areas. What interactions I was able to have with the rest of the family were all very positive. Free use of the bicycles was fabulous, and I had my best experiences in Ben Tre by bike. Be sure to explore. My only complaint would be that you need to do some checks on the bikes before you take your pick. Most of them are in disrepair in one way or another, so be sure to test each. The beds and bathrooms don't compare to nicer hostels or hotels, but I didn't expect them to. They were adequate; fans were amply available, and you'll want to spend your time outside the rooms anyway; lounging in a hammock or simply sitting in the peaceful garden. A final word with regards to getting references to tours and hotels from locals: I think it's usual for family and friends to send customers each other's way, so simply take recommendations with a grain of salt; they will seldom be objective. I did not book a tour through Thai, but then I only discovered him through one of his friends in My Tho. I also didn't take him up on his recommendation for another hotel in Can Tho (which was my onward destination). I've found it not uncommon to get conflicting recommendations about a place from different people in Vietnam: one local in Can Tho steered me away from Thai's recommended hotel with some negative comments about it. I don't mean to accuse anybody of anything - just be aware that there's often a conflict of interest with references from locals.

Title: Basic accommodation but well worth it for the tours!
Review: We stayed at Mr Thai's home for two nights and had a great time. His house is far from any tourist areas and only accessible from Ben Tre centre by bike/motorbike. His house & grounds are quiet and relaxing. Rooms are very basic - no aircon and very hard beds but we had expected this from other reviews. There is also no mirrors in the rooms and the sink is communal outside by the pond. Food that was cooked was simple but tasty (cooked fish from the pond, rice, veggies, fruit). We also had some interesting food we'd not tried before! When you stay at Mr Thai's, he will arrange tours for you. As we only had a couple of days this suited us. We would recommend a tour with Hoa (an older gentlemen) who was really friendly, knowledgeable and has an interesting life story - we did a boat tour and a nature walk and was probably the best day of our two week holiday. Another day, a tour was arranged where we went to the rice fields (beware: very muddy!!) and Cai Be floating market. In the 2 days we saw a lot of the area and learned a lot about the Mekong Delta life. The cost for both tours was $60 each which we thought was good value for money. 2 days at Mr Thai's was ideal for us and personally wouldn't stay longer due to the basic accommodation.

Title: Mr Thai's Homestay
Review: I travelled with friends to Vietnam on a motorcycle trip around the Mekong Delta. One of the stop overs was at the home of Mr Thai. Let us make this clear from the start, this is someone's home with a basic set of units attached to it. Nestled in a nice garden setting with a large pond from which your dinner will be caught. It is basic accommodation, but it was the experience and not necessarily the comfort that made this visit most memorable. This included the Vietnamese karaoke heard through the quiet night air from the "coffee shop" in the nearby village. As said the rooms are basic, clean but there power but there is no air conditioning, only wall fans to keep the air moving. We had been warned that the Vietnamese homestay beds were hard, but that didn't quite prepare us for how hard they actually are :) Our host, Mr Thai was a wonderful man who entertained us with the story of his life and prepared us a delicious and memorable meal of fresh Elephant Ear Fish caught from his pond. The following morning we were treated to a breakfast feast of noodles and fresh fruit One of the more memorable moments from our Vietnam visit, highly recommended as long as looking for a taste of traditional Vietnam.and not expecting 5 star luxury.

Title: For tours, ask for Mr. Y (pronounced 'Eee' in english)
Review: We had 4 nights at Mr. Thai's place a couple of week's ago - we really enjoyed the peace and quiet and after 3 weeks in other areas of Vietnam, it was nice to experience life out of the main tracks. As in other reviews, Thuy's (Mr. Thai's wife) cooking was great, and we enjoyed the breakfasts, fruits, lunch (when we were there) and dinners - including the fish caught in the home pond. As you can see in the photos, accommodation and amenities are basic - so make sure you're going for the experience. Regarding the tours, take your time now (before you go) to consider what other recent reviewers have said in terms of pricing etc. Know that you'll be out in the country and Mr. Thai's tours are the most convenient (as one reviewer said, how else are you going to do any?), and take your time going through the arrangements with him when you arrive and start discussing options and prices. Our initial tour with the older gent was a little rushed as it was later in the afternoon when we arrived, raining a bit and dusk was approaching. But it was great to walk the little tracks, experience the boat ride and the fireflies, and ask about his experiences during and post the american war. The next day we had a huge tour of all the fruit farms, 3 islands and ferries, animal market, small floating market and more. Mr. Thai drove one bike and his colleague Mr. Y drove the other, both great ... I noticed my wife chatting non-stop with Mr. Y the whole day - GREAT english, and a great conversationalist, sharing all sorts of information and everyday stuff. So definitely ask for him as a guide!!! The next day we went with Mr. Y and Thai's young brother-in-law (who was pretty quiet and doesn't speak english) to the Khmer area of the Mekong and the Khmer Buddhist temples and monasteries around Tra Vinh area. Again another huge day out, heaps of impressions to process, great lunch along the way, Mr. Y awesome and chatted with my wife again the entire day. The next day, Mr. Thai had arranged a car, driver and the older gent to take us out to the coastal area of the Mekong and sites along the way - it didn't work out so well as he got lost, we didn't get to the coast ... On our last morning, we had a great breakfast, packed up and were dropped off at the bus back to HoChiMinh by Mr. Thai ready to get our flight home. He also organised a few purchases for me including packaged coffee beans which was much appreciated. As in all these experiences, ask for what you want/need ... and yoou may need to negotiate a bit - overall very helpful.

Title: Probably the best place in the beautiful Ben Tre
Review: This place is the only place you need to stay if you are visiting Ben Tre or My Tho. We actually had plans to stay at Mango riverside prior to reaching Vietnam. But due to the attitude of the staff and extremely late replies to emails, we cancelled our booking and a quick searching in the web took us to this wonderful place. Initially we were skeptical about this place since the photos were not that attractive. But I blindly trusted all the positive reviews and booked. And it turned out to be much higher than our expectations. First of all no other place in Mekong delta can match the charm and beauty of the pristine Ben Tre. It has almost zero foreigners and the land is so fertile that you find fruit orchards and other trees everywhere. The vegetation is so dense here which I have never seen in other parts of Vietnam. Secondly, Mr. Thai is such an awesome person. We were surprised when we came to know that the lady at Thinh Phat bus booking office in Saigon district 5 told that she knows this person. She called Mr. Thai to inform about our arrival. And he was there waiting for us. He and another person took us in motorbike (for free) to his house which is a 15 minute ride. That 15 minute we were awestruck by the beauty of Ben Tre. Even his house is surrounded by a lot of trees with fruits in it. It also has a small pond where you can fish. Thai gave us enough fruits during our stay and we also had the freedom to pluck whatever we need. The best part is, he arranged another great man, who was our boating trip guide. I highly recommend you to take at least one of the boat trip or the motor bike trip. We had time only for the boat ride. And the 74 year old man who was our guide was the best guide we ever had in Vietnam. It was almost a 6 hour trip and he took us to the most awesome places in Ben Tre. The best part was the coconut candy place where we were served plates full of mangoes, jackfruit, papaya, sapota and the most delicious honey tea. They also let us taste snake wine. He also took us to several villages and we really enjoyed the charm that Ben Tre is. Around 7pm before the trip ended, he even took us to a place where there is a tree full of fireflies. It looked just like a christmas tree. While leaving this place, Thai even gave us a few mangoes and one big dragon fruit. It was really tough to leave this place. Thank you Mr. Thai for the wonderful stay. If ever there is a place in Vietnam we will visit again, this will be the first in our list.

Title: Fantastic overall, not for everybody.
Review: We had a great stay here, thanks to the tours offered by the friendly owner. On a boat as well as a motorbike, it was a very good way to see the Mekong Delta. The (almost private) tours weren't cheap for local standards but well worth it. It was nice to see the way local people live in the area. The food that was prepared for us was nice, as well as the garden. What could be a 'downside' for some, is the basic accomodation and sanitary conditions. A bed that consists of a concrete base with a matrass, a permeable concrete floor around the toilet, a shower with cold water and very low pressure, to give an impression. The place can't be reached by car, just motorbike and we wouldn't have found it on our own. Overall, we're very glad we stayed here due to the great adventure of the beautiful tours. We saw and experienced the Mekong Delta in a way we never could have by ourselves!

Title: One of the highlights of our stay in Vietnam!
Review: We were planning to stay 1 or 2 nights but ended up staying 3 and would have stayed even longer if we could! The homestay is such a great place and the fact that it only has 2 rooms ensures that it is never too crowded. The food was super amazing and we've helped to prepare it as well so it was a great culinary school. Also, it's plentiful - there wasn't a dinner we could finish! We went on a motorbike tour with Mr Thai and it was a worthy investment - we have learnt so much about Mekong Delta, it's people and the gorgeous fruit that grows there, no wonder why people call it the snake tour - you really go via the smallest paths that no tourist agency would take you! If you are travelling from HCMC, do you research on how to reach Ben Tre with the public bus, there is one going directly every 30 mins or so and Mr will pick you up once in Ben Tre, but finding the bus agency where the bus departs in HCMC is a bit tricky. And make sure that the bus goes to Ben Tre as the girl who stayed with us got a bus that goes 'somewhere nearby' and was dropped off in the middle of nowhere...

Title: Lovely family, great food, relaxed location
Review: Three of us stayed at the homestay for two nights. The room is basic but has its own bathroom with Western toilet and a cold shower. The patio where meals are served is lovely, there is also a very comfortable hammock and a gorgeous wooden reclining armchair you can rest in. The meals were prepared by Mr Thai's wife using local ingredients and were absolutely gorgeous and plentiful. We bought two trips Mr Thai arranged: half a day's boat ride including a walk around a village with an English speaking guide, one of Mr Thai's friends. The following day we were taken on a full day bike ride around the fruit orchards in the Mekong delta, including a boat ride to the floating market, although it is possibly best to visit first thing in the morning and we got there around lunchtime when very little was going on. If you don't want to buy tours, you can also hire motorbikes from Mr Thai. Mr Thai is a very warm and enthusiastic person, who will do his best to make your stay enjoyable. It is probably best to try and book in advance, you can contact him directly, to ensure that he can make preparations for your stay, otherwise, he might have to improvise some of the services. If you go to his place by bus, make sure you show the bus driver the name of the homestay and the address to ensure that he tells you where to get off.

Title: authentic vietnamese vibes
Review: What an amazing place! We spent 2 nights with Thai and his family and everything has been absolutely outstanding: perfect hospitality, nice food and really cool and authentic vietnamese vibes. Highly recommended, we're looking forward to come back asap!

In the Mekong delta he seems to know everything and everybody (everybody loves him), which also makes him the perfect guide. On our motorbike tour we saw so many interesting spots and didn't see a lot of other tourists. Enjoy your stay!

Title: Best experience in our 4 week trip
Review: We arrived sort of last minute, by coincidence, at Mr. Thai's homestay. We were picked up by motorbike (great!) and transferred to the homestay. This is located in the middle of nowhere, right in the heart of the delta, hidden in tropical vegatation. Excellent! Drinks and fruit all the time, the bedroom and bathroom were basic but clean (for luxury I'll stay at home :) ). Food was great, with fish out of the private pond (the garden is wonderful!) even samplers of riversnake and frog! Next day mister Thai and a friend took us on a 160 km, custom arranged motor trip (with our bags!!!) all through the delta with many stops and (inside) stories, ferries over the great rivers, lunch, drinks (sugar cane lime juice, the best!) to finally drop us of in Can Tho at a home stay he recommended. Price for all of this really, really fair!!! JUST DO IT, best experience so far!!!!!

Title: Be carefuel of agent/"brother"
Review: We ended up at this homestay after getting off the bus at Ben Tre. We were supposed to be staying with another homestay but we very stupidly got misguided by the man who 'met' us at the bus (he basically was waiting for busses to arrive from HCMC so be careful of this) and took us back to his 'family' (not his family, he was an agent) after us also getting massively stitched on the price (this was our 2nd day in Vietnam and we clearly did not have our heads screwed on right!). The homestay itself is rather lovely, pretty garden with hammocks and the lunch and dinner was very good (breakfast a little less exciting) and basic room (windows but no screen - they provide mosquito net). The family is very nice, but the other guest there also had a poor experience with the agent and I'm not sure they will actually do anything about it...a shame for them as they will lose the customers. We also got ripped off on our 2nd day, we didn't get lunch that we paid for, the floating market of Cai Be is NOT what we expected, nothing like what I imagined, a little disappointing after seeing photos of Can Tho. We were then chucked on a bus back to HCMC (after our motorbike drivers getting lost) which was nothing like the bus we had gotten ourselves from HCMC, and they only paid the driver enough to the very edge of HCMC and we were kicked off there! The saving grace of the trip was having a lovely guide on the afternoon tour down the canals, to the coconut candy place etc. He was a local friend of the family who was incredibly interesting. All in all - although this is quite a nice homestay, I would avoid it if they are still using the same agent or you get a very good rate...with him, you are not promised to get what you pay for. OR, just book the homestay directly and organise everything yourselves independent of the family and agent.

Title: Interesting

Title: It was a pleasure
Review: I very rarely give hotels or guesthouses full marks.. usually there's a little something which frustrates me and lets the accommodation down. However let me tell you about the exception. Nguyet Que is wonderful. Lovely place, lovely food and above all lovely hosts. Title: All boxes ticked or atmosphere, you choose!!
Review: ON PAPER this hotel ticks all the boxes. Rooms are large & clean, appliances all work, a/c quiet, rooftop bar, conference facilities, banquet room, pool, large breakfast area. Staff are polite, distant & seemingly efficient. There's a security motorbike carpark. It's apparently a 3star rated hotel, I know the room rate was very reasonable. There's a list of the fines you will incur if you break the hotel's rules, including vomiting ( for real! check the photos). Buffet breakfast was barely adequate. Many dishes had run out by 8am, a couple got replenished. The eggs both omlette & fried were leathery even when fresh. Coffee was run out, only 1 juice; evil looking green swamp water tasting stuff. Reasonable selection of asian food, the pho sat premade & you ladled in your own stock. 1 fruit choice. Maybe we've been spoiled at other hotels with freshness, quality & quantity. If you're into the streetfood scene there's some decent ones immediately to the left as you walk out the front gate. We enjoyed a fun night at Lamen ( no english spoken) eating with the locals. And the night markets extend from the city out to the front of the hotel if you don't feel like the 10 min walk into town. That's the positives & if you're a business travellor or someone who just wants all the boxes ticked you'll love it. In reality the place is HUGE compared to most hotels. The public spaces are vast with monumental furniture set up to receive guests for coffee. But no-one was around. We saw the odd guest but never more than 1 at a time & they seemed to be forever scurrying into their rooms. Our voices echoed eerily down wide empty marble corridors as we wandered lost on the various floors. Our room was on the 4th floor but the lift doesn't REALLY go to the 4th floor rooms, you also have to go up a staircase & along a corridor. If you get the staircase wrong you end up on the 5th. Then you have to find a different staircase to take you back to the REAL 4th floor or the lift on the 5th back to the dummy 4th and try again. Made me feel like I was at Hogwarts, or worse, Hotel California! We know the governmental system here is different from ours but until now we never felt its presence. Perhaps this hotel had a previous use (east german embassy?) & being a hotel doesn't sit comfortably, maybe it was the lack of guests, or just our imagination. But I prefer my hotels to have some life & atmosphere about them as well as clean sheets.

Title: OK if nothing else
Review: The hotel is in front of the river with a nice views. There is a lot of street food options very close and one large boat restaurant but nothing else easy to reach by foot. The hotel seems to be managed by the Vietnamese administration with a very confusing list of rules and service pricing document, also displayed in each elevator. For instance, it mentions that customers will be charged 50,000 VND per hour and per person for the swimming pool! We decided to use it but were not charged... not sure why. The rooms and common areas are very clean but with limited (low quality) furniture. We had 4 bedrooms and the safety box in 3 of them were not functioning. Got upgraded to suite for free, fantastic, clean spacious room with huge beds, A/C, tea making stuff, seating area, etc for only 35 US$! Staff very friendly, got to use pool even half day after we'd checked out and they brought us to bus station for free. On boulevard approx 400m from town centre, so location good in principle, but Ben Tre itself hasn't got enormous amount to offer outside of island tour.

Title: Went the extra yard
Review: . Were in our early 60â€™s. Our prerequisites and not necessary in this order are; Location; (âˆš) clean; (âˆš) quiet; (âˆš) Wi-Fi; (âˆš) being able to communicate with staff. (âˆš). Location is good, being on the river and we had asked for and got a room with a river view and it sure is a busy little tributary. There are few very local eating places in the street, which requires local taste to enjoy. We got lucky at  because the owners sister (A San Francisco resident) was visiting and could translate. We had a very nice Pho there. It was clean; all the plumbing worked. Had Wi-Fi in the room with no problems. A buffet breakfast was supplied and again it was for local tastes. (I can survive on fruit, toast and marmalade for a day or 2) Being able to communicate with staff. Sure a few of the younger, more inexperienced girls were not that forth coming, probably because my Vietnamese language skills are lacking and I suspect vice versa, as Ben Tre is not a tourist Mecca for Westerners, but the boss lady was extremely helpful, so long as you spoke slowly and not Australian by running all of our words together. Our problem was, we wanted to get to Vinh Long next. She explained a couple of alternatives and we chose to go by public bus  which passes the hotel. On the morning we left, she sent the bell hop out with us to the kerb, who waited with us some 20 minutes for the bus and then told the driver and conductor where we had to go. While we were waiting for the bus, she sent out the security guard with a phone number of a taxi company, just in case there was no transport when we got off the ferry, which came in very handy indeed. Yes there was some occasional noise, but none of it affected our sleep, unless you wanted a nanna nap at 4pm

Title: Need some serious changes with menue and some waiter/waitress staff
Review: I was there for volunteer work so I stayed for almost a month at the hotel. Most of the time the crew and I stayed and ate at the hotel because there was not many restaurants. Food was not so so bad but it was the same old thing everyday AND majority of the things we ordered from the menu they did not have. Some dishes had to be ordered in advanced. We ate a lot of the same thing. Services from waiters were not very good and they get our menu wrong EVERYDAY. The people worked there are very nice and friendly though. Title: Great choice for Ben Tre
Review: We stayed at this hotel for two nights in September with our two teenage sons in a family room. We stayed here completely by accident as the hotel we were originally booked in at across the river had a death in the family and were in mourning. :( But we were very happy with our stay here. :) Our room was very large, very clean and very comfortable. The kids loved the pool. We hired bikes from the hotel and rode up along the river and through town. The hotel also had their own little travel agent at the front of the hotel, which we booked a "Mekong Delta" full-day tour through (not expensive). This tour was one of our best days while in Vietnam. We had our own tour guide for the day, Dean (pronounced: Dee-ann), and he was fantastic. He made the day. Ben Tre is a great place to visit if you like to get away from the tourist crowd. Lovely and quite, and nice for a couple of days after Ho Chi Minh. Only saw a couple of other Westeren tourists for our entire stay. The rest of the hotel patrons were from Ho Chi Mnh city. We were the centre of attention when wandering around the streets. Especially the kids. Nothing much to do here, and only a couple of eateries, but if you do a tour, that fills in a whole day and is all you need. It was great. The hotel owner of the hotel (very helpful man) also booked us onto a local bus back to Ho Chi Minh city (easy), as we had a flight to DaNang to catch.

Title: Very good local hotel on the river
Review: If you want western 'luxury' then this isn't the place for you. This is a very respectable but large local hotel which caters very well for Vietnamese tastes. So if you want a flavour of the real Vietnam ( not the Disney version) then you'd do well to stay here Top tip: take one of the front rooms (101,201 etc) as these are large with jacuzzi & separate dressing room. Sounds grand but is all rather dated in a quaint kind of way Fantastically cheap for what you get & there are great views from the 4th floor cafe

Title: Very large suite, very cheap, buffet breakfast and juice bar on roof
Review: We arrived without a reservation they showed us the rooms including the suite to choose. The suite room was very large with sitting area desk and spa with balcony overlooking the river. Bike hire was cheap and there is a small pool. Ben tre has a great promenade area straight outside with a night market and lots of street food options. The juicebar upstairs was great with free wifi. I agree with other reviewers that the Ben tre news loudspeakers were fine though they started very early and yes there is a lot of chair scraping as part of pack up of the bar if you are underneath. Staff were great and organised our bus to HCMC with a pickup from the hotel. The 'local sweets' on the very good buffet breakfast were a favourite.

Title: Not bad for where it is
Review: Bearing in mind that Ben Tre does not yet see too many "westerners" we found this hotel acceptable. Rooms were clean and the hotel is well located. We had the same experience as previous reviewer when dining at the in house restaurant. We were the only people in the room and the waiters English was very limited. The meal was edible but well below the quality of what we experienced elsewhere in Vietnam. Maybe that was due to communication. Breakfast was ok and the room fairly full.I.m not sure where else in the area you could eat. When booking try and ensure that you are not located below the rooftop bar area because it is noisy and when it closed at night they spent a fairly long time moving the chairs around and sleep was impossible. Expect to be woken up reasonably early by nearby street loudspeakers announcing the news.I didn't find that annoying, it just added local flavour to the place. I doubt there are many other sleeping options in Ben Tre apart from homestays. In hindsight we would have given the Mekong area a miss and spent more time in Mai Chau or Sapa. You could get a far better river experience in Hoi An which we all found to be a far nicer environment.

Title: Disappointed with the hotel although loved Ben Tre
Review: We stayed here as part of a 2 day / 1 night tour. Initial impressions were good but delve a little deeper and the cracks appear. Perhaps we were just unlucky but our overall experience was very disappointing. The staff speak very little English and although this is not uncommon in Vietnam, it does make requests (if you have them) difficult. The issues we had with our room - poor air conditioning, only two drinks in our mini bar, no pool towels (they simply don't have them), no hot water. We are used to the hard style of Asian beds but these were like concrete slabs. This is a non smoking hotel but the foyer and hallways smelt strongly of cigarette smoke and the fire alarm kept going off which was funny to start with but then became annoying. We were also unfortunate to have a noisy occupant above who moved furniture around for 3 hours straight. We were advised by our guide to eat in the restaurant but when we turned up it was in darkness. We ventured in to find two Vietnamese men behind the bar. Once they finally understood we had come for dinner, they turned the lights and air-conditioner on for us, how bizarre. We were the only occupants that night and in the morning when we returned for breakfast there was standing room only. I could hardly believe it and had to wonder where everyone had come from. Sadly, there was nothing on the buffet we could identify/eat other than stale baguettes and I could not even stomach their coffee which I normally love. Perhaps over time and with more western tourists, the hotel will improve its overall services. I really hope so as the Mekong is a lovely destination well worthy of a visit.
