Title: Things have changed
Review: We just checked into the ham luong turist hotel today. Some things have definetely changed since the raving reviews below. Lets start with the good stuff, the rooms are big and the view from the bar is nice. There is a pool which you can use free of charge. There is free ADSL in the rooms. (no wifi though) But I definetely dont think that they deserve any where near 4.5 stars here at TripAdvisor. First of a few ammendenments to the info below. A suite is now double the price of a superior room, not a few dollars more. A standard room has no windows. The superior rooms have windows which look into a concrete wall 2 meters away. If you want a view, the rooms are now called deluxe and is more expensive. All the rooms have a bathtub, but ours wasent cleaned. The prices on the homepage of the hotel was also outdated, the suite doubled in price. We also went to have lunch at the roof bar at the 4 floor. The prices here are exuberant, 260.000 Dong for a filet of chicken. Nothing under 100.000 Dong. We ordered duck a la orange and beef in safran. After waiting 50 minutes (one other guest in the cafe) we where served our meal. Cold orange sauce with a film on top on my duck. Horrible tast. My fiancees safran beef was served with no safran but with a healthy dose of pepper as a replacement. For the first time here in Vietnam there was no rice or anything besides meat. So we had to order rice on the side (30.000 dong pr serving). That took 10 minutes to cook. Also, it seems that only the check in staff knew any english. It took me 5 minutes to order a bottle of water, and I only succeded by pulling up a bottle from our bag and pointing to it frantically. The same happened when I tried to order rice, a group of 4 waiters looked at my wonderingly and could not understand any of my attempts to order: boiled, steamed or any type of rice. Finally I was brought the menu and found cooked rice on the very last page. When the hotel is called "tourist hotel" you would expect the staff to know atleast the words "rice" and "water" in english. Its probably the most civilised hotel here in Ben Tre town, but please dont come expecting a good deal or any type of service. You will be dissapointed.

Title: The best of Ben Tre
Review: We very much enjoyed our stay at Ham Luong. Staff were very accommodating and friendly. Our first room was nice, at the front of the hotel facing the river, with a balcony (although the air conditioner's back end was blowing out onto the balcony). The second room was cheaper and absolutely *enormous* with three beds, a small dining area and bathroom. This room opened onto the back of the hotel--no balcony but nice big windows, and the view had its own more down-to-earth charm, looking out onto neighborhoods and backyards. I'd recommend asking to see the rooms before choosing. The hotel has a pool, small spa and decent restaurant with pretty good free breakfast. On the top floor there is a bar/cafe, which was a nice place to have coffee in the late morning or hang out at night. They have a large menu of specialty cocktails as well, some featuring local fruits. We had a decent lunch in the hotel restaurant one day as well. There are certainly better spots in the city, but sometimes it's nice to have something so close by.

Title: Great location !
Review: Really enjoyed our stay at Viet Uc Hotel. The room was very clean, the beds were super comfortable and we had a great view over the river.... and it was walking distance to everything we wanted to do in Ben Tre. Very little English is spoken in the hotel or anywhere in BenTre for that matter, as it is not a popular tourist destination... but that's what we like ! We were surprised and puzzled to see the Australian flag flying out the front of the hotel.... and a kangaroo on their logo? On enquiring, we eventually found out that the hotel is actually owned by an Aussie. If we were ever in the city of Ben Tre again, this is certainly where we'd be staying. .... but I would find somewhere else to dine at night.

Title: Great river side hotel
Review: My husband and I visited in March 2016 (not May), we found the hotel on foot after leaving another place across the river. The room was quiet, comfortable and spacious and had a huge window with a great side view of the river, which meant we had a stunning sunset view each evening. The hotel was close to many restaurants and shops, and just across the road from the prom where families would gather every evening to fly kites and talk. Breakfast was included, with obligatory pho and omelette stations and a range of other foods to keep anyone from going hungry. The coffee was good too. Would definitely recommend.

Title: Viet Uc Hotel
Review: This modern hotel is very pleasant to stay in. The town however is what can only be described as grubby. Litter all over the place which detracts from the general view of the river and the interesting things to do in the area. The hotel is nicely appointed with good facilities. It is located overlooking the river, which is interesting as life is all about the water down here in the Delta. The staff are not as comfortable with English, but it is a small town. The breakfast included in the room rate is quite extensive, and geared mainly towards Asian tourists. The computer available in the lobby was appreciated, as was assistance with transport when leaving. A nice location but in a town in need of a cleanup.

Title: Definitely recommend - good hotel that can help with tours and transport in the Mekong
Review: I stayed here for two nights while exploring the Mekong and was very pleasantly surprised. Ben Tre and surrounding areas are not very touristy or developed and this hotel stood out as being the newest and largest hotel in the region. It is very clean with decent sized rooms. The have a massage centre and spa although it is nothing special. The staff do not speak much English but they were still able to organise an excellent tour for us and a bus back to Saigon for only $4 US dollars instead of a taxi for 1.5 million dong that we paid of the way in. The breakfast was good - a buffet of different asian breakfast food, as well as toast, fruit and a chef that would cook eggs however you want. Centrally located near the river and local markets. All in all very good value.

Title: NEW HOTEL
Review: Hotel Viet Uc (Vietnam Australia) is only 3 years old and is a great place to stay in Ben Tre. It is centrally located on the river. Title: Good hotel, excellent location
Review: We have just spent one night at the Viet Uc hotel and found it very pleasant. The most important thing to stress is the eager friendliness of the staff on the front desk, in the bar and in the restaurant. From information on bus timetables for travel further into the Delta, through producing a pen when the waiter noticed we needed to mark something in our travel guide to another waiter offering to heat up the coffee if we didn't find it hot enough. There was also the waitress keen to improve her English and taking her serving duties so seriously and the door man who gave much helpful information. Our room was bright, fresh, spacious and comfortable and, being on a high floor overlooking the river, we had wonderful views of the river craft and the coconut plantation beyond. There are no English language news programmes on the television, but we have found that elsewhere in the Delta, even in a city with far more foreign tourists. The wifi only works in the public areas on the ground floor and, even there, it was a bit sporadic. We had a good dinner in the restaurant, squid, steamed with ginger and prawns deep fried in coconut batter were the highlights, together with a reasonable bottle of Dalat wine. Breakfast was a little short on fresh fruits, juice or fresh bread, but the Vietnamese offerings were varied and there were good omelettes The hotel is right beside the main market, which is well worth a visit.

Title: Great hotel. Great price.
Review: The Viet Uc hotel opened two months ago, so it is brand new and not yet on the map for travelers. We made the reservation through the hotel's own website. The first thing you notice when you walk into the hotel is that it is probably the fanciest building in Ben Tre. In fact, if the hotel would be in the US/Canada, it would be the equivalent of a Marriott or Sheraton -- huge rooms, king size beds, big flat screen TVs, a really hot shower, room service, mini bar, and a strong AC. In addition there are two bars (one on the roof), a restaurant, and even a small gym. Back home this would cost more than $150/night. Here, however, it costs $25/night for the "standard room," which is far more than standard for rooms in South East Asia at this price range. The rate also came with a buffet breakfast which was made up of Vietnamese dishes and omelets made to order. There are some kinks that need to be worked out, given that this is a new hotel. For example, only the front desk staff speaks English. Also, there were some ants in our room. Overall, given the price and quality of other hotels in Ben Tre, this is a great find!

Title: Beautiful, friendly and romantic resort
Review: I stayed here for 3 nights together with some 35 volunteers, organizing an "Vision Screening" Lions service project to some 1,400 villagers at Ben Tre Province. The room was clean and neat, I can watch TV with many international channels available, fee wifi in room and lobby. The resort environment is great, peaceful and romantic (good for married couples). The staff were very friendly, and you can always call a buggy to roam around the resort. We had breakfasts and dinners at the resort, and it compares to international 4 to 5 stars standard. My friends went for body massage (about US$40 for 1 hour) and found it was fairly good.

Title: FIREFLY Attraction
Review: If you love peace and quiet, fireflies at night, fishing and seafood by Mekong River owns by the same establishment founder... then this is the place for you. I was informed that this resort was built by the founder as a give back to provide jobs for the hometown. Hence if you support CSR, this might be a place for you to consider. They even have KTV inside here to boot! This resort has lots of empty space and its ideal for a group yoga retreat or company budget teambuilding. The rooms are spread out but buggy service is available. Go for the standard rooms, its enough and will do the trick.

Title: Very Enjoyable Stay
Review: We stayed here for 4 nights and loved it. It is very much geared for the Vietnamese tourist but that's what we liked so much. The rooms are clean and well equipped and the staff very helpful but English is not spoken by all not that this posed a problem. It is set in beautifully landscaped grounds and would recommend you explore on the hotel bikes. The place reminded me a bit of the village in the sixties TV series 'The Prisoner' with white painted bandstands, hanging chairs and people riding around in golf buggies. Half expected to see Patrick McGoohan in his piped blazer saying 'be seeing you'. We would love to go back especially when the swimming pool is complete.

Title: Experience a real Vietnamese hotel
Review: We stayed for 4 nights and had a huge, spotlessly clean room with a veranda overlooking the gardens. The bathroom was well equipped and huge too. This hotel is popular with the Vietnamese and so things are not necessarily to Western tastes (although the staff will do everything they can to be accommodating) but we prefer to be somewhere with local influence. The meals in the vast dining room were excellent. Again, truly Vietnamese. The cost was reasonable (and for drinks and outings). A "small" food portion does for 2 people. The breakfasts again reflected Vietnamese taste, so the juices were a bit sugary for us. I expect if we had asked our excellent waiter he would have arranged freshly squeezed. However, the Vietnamese options (soup, cold meats, etc) were delicious. The management worked really hard to make our stay enjoyable and some speak good English. We enjoyed boat trips out to see fire flies at night, an evening trip to watch the kingfishers and taxi rides to Ben Tre market (about Â£10 to get into town). If you want a standard international resort this is not for you. As a previous writer said, it is a little rough around the edges but it offers a real Vietnamese experience. Once the swimming pool is built (currently under construction) it will offer more appeal as the rooms are not full. Beautiful new bungalows are being constructed on the Mekong itself. We would stay here again and wish the managers success.

Title: The best landscape in Vietnam
Review: I stayed in the beautiful resort on Saturday night and we reached in this resort late night at around 9,30pm and found the place was so quiet and great ambiance for someone looking for a quiet and relaxing resort. The rooms are good but the most amazing feature of this resort is the landscaping. It is certainly lush green and no place in the whole 22 hectares you find an empty space without green. Righ in the middle of the resort a canal is running through and which connect to the main river Mekong. Early morning when you wake up, you feel that you are right in the heart of the beautiful village and one can easily spend a week and relax. They have great spa and meeting facilities. I would take my loved ones there for my next trip and it is only 80 kms away from Ho Chi Minh city, less than 2 hours you are there.

Title: Diamond in the Rough
Review: My wife and I have traveled to Vietnam frequently the last few years. I visit family in Ben Tre and usually stay at the Viet Uc. We skipped last year and returned this year and traveled with some of our closest friends. We needed several rooms and the Viet Uc could not accommodate our party. We found this resort online and elected to give it try, and my review is as titled. Here are the "rough edges". The resort advertised a pool, sorry no pool, but one will be coming in 2016 and the resort is remote. The check-in process was a fiasco, but I will say that we had four (4) groups trying to check-in and our group was tired, exhausted, and hot (from a day long bike tour). Regardless, all of the reservations were incorrect (booked online through Agoda). In addition, there was a severe language barrier that added to the confusion. Here are the moments of "shining brilliance". The rooms were clean, roomy, and nicely equipped to be cool. The food and food service was really good especially the rice porridge and Pho. The karaoke bar was amazing and the bikes with their pedaling generating lights were cool in the evening. The concrete paths were nice to walk or ride a bike. The resort was well maintained and well manicured. Overall, the resort had its challenges, but in the end we enjoyed the resort and we are planning to return next year.

Title: Staying with locals
Review: We had a lovely stay in Nam Binh homestay. It is located on a small island in the river. You can reach it with a grab and the ferry (5 kVDN for motorbike on the ferry). At the homestay they served us a lot of food and some rice wine. Although they didn't speak english we had a nice evening with them. The room itself was primitive but sufficient, with a normal toilet, but no real shower or sink and there is no WIFI at the homestay. We also got some fresh cocunuts and dragonfruit from the garden and played with the puppies and dogs that walked around.

Title: Feels luke an holiday in the countryside

The owner is a nice lady, willing to make your staying as good as possible while she speaks fluent English and French, having a long residence in Switzerland in her history. I didnt order the dinner, just went by foot 100 meters to the near by junction and ordered planty of Vietnamese local meet for 2$. Bottom line: a great hotel for a very low price.

Title: Pretty setting, remote location, severe service issues
Review: The good stuff: rooms are large and clean, and the garden setting is nice and peaceful, if a bit smoky from the proprietors burning coconut shells to keep the mosquitoes away. If you are looking for a more remote setting, this is nice place to relax in peace and quiet. Beware, there is NOTHING to eat around here but a big Pho place on the side of a major highway. The guest does house offer dinner, but it's a menu they choose and seemed pricey for Vietnam (price $5-8pp). The bad stuff: we booked on Agoda, and when we arrived, the owner refused to honor the rate. She claimed that Agoda didn't have her rates correct, and that we would have to pay $5 more for the room we booked, which had AC. Given that she had our passports, that we'd already paid Agoda, and that there weren't any other options around due to the remote location, we felt very uncomfortable, with no choice but to accept. Frankly, if Agoda has her rates wrong, that is up to her to fix with Agoda and is not the customer's problem. I am also fairly certain this violates the contractual obligations she has to us and Agoda. Second issue was that we were kicked out of our room so that they could hang a mirror in there. They just showed up at the door and said, "you need to get out so we can hang this mirror." They didn't even give us a minute to change, use the restroom, or grab some stuff before barging in. I have no idea why that couldn't have been done before we arrived, or after we checked out. Finally, the breakfast: there was fruit (some of it not ripe), cheese, butter, jam ... and no bread. We had to wait almost 20 minutes for bread to arrive. There were also ants all over the can of condensed milk served with coffee. The breakfast issues were rather small on their own and not worthy of a bad score, but taken with the big issues, there is much room for improvement here. The owner seems like nice lady and is proud to have visitors from all over the world, but I can't in good faith give a good score here when we've had so many other truly wonderful experiences in Vietnam that far surpass this place.

Title: Oase van rust
Review: Het regende pijpenstelen toen we per bus aankwamen uit Saigon. Net over de brug, richting Ben Tre stond de Chalet Suisse duidelijk aangegeven. We stapten uit aan het kruispunt en belden met de eigenares die er onmiddellijk voor zorgde dat we werden afgehaald per motorfiets. Ze spreekt voortreffelijk Frans, wat dan ook zeer behulpzaam is. De motorfietschauffeur bleek uiteindelijk een gids te zijn, die ons meteen na aankomst overviel met aanbiedingen om een trip te maken. Aangezien we vermoeid waren hadden we weinig oor naar zijn voorstellen, en dat is meteen een advies naar de eigenares toe om de gasten eerst wat op adem te laten komen vooraleer ze te bestoken met allerlei voorstellen om trips te maken. De Chalet Suisse biedt geen mogelijkheid tot eten, maar de eigenares gaf ons tal van praktische tips om de verschillende gelegenheden in de buurt te bezoeken. Tot onze volstrekte tevredenheid trouwens. De kamers zijn eenvoudig uitgerust, voorzien van een plafondventilator en muskietennet. Dat laatste is bijzonder nuttig gezien de vochtige omgeving en dito aanwezigheid van muggen en andere insecten. Het ontbijt was correct. Bij ons vertrek heeft de eigenares onze taxi gebeld en duidelijk instructies gegeven om onze reis per bus verder te zetten. Niettemin hebben we hier kunnen genieten van volstrekte rust. En het is een aanrader voor wie even op adem wil komen. Het centrum van Ben Tre is weliswaar 9 km verder, wat niet echt in de buurt is. Maar de eigenares zorgt er voor dat je op een vlotte manier weg kan. Proficiat.

Title: Good experience
Review: We stayed here as part of a tour in August. Our families all had their own rooms which was great. You are able to help yourself to drinks, alcoholic and non alcoholic, and simply make a note of what you have and pay prior to leaving. The toilets/showers are at the back of the homestay. Don't go for a shower in the dark, as I did, or you will have plenty of unwelcome visitors. This wasn't great during the night as no-one told us which door you would need to use and we spent time trying to find the right way. Dogs also roam around the property so if you don't like dogs....... One issue I had was if mosquito nets are to be supplied then surely there shouldn't be any holes in them? There was a fan in the room which was sufficient during our one night stay. Now, I realise this all sounds negative and it certainly wasn't the case. I can laugh at these things now and I was out of my comfort zone. You are in a beautiful place but you just need to be prepared. We had lunch, dinner and breakfast at the property and every meal was delicious. There are seating areas around the property. The kids loved the hammocks (my daughter now wants one for her room). Our group played cards and darts and just had a good, relaxing time. I probably wouldn't return but would recommend it. I've no idea of cost, as I said it was part of a tour.

Title: Speechless
Review: OMG! This stay was the best! I will always remember this! Ok. First. It is not for everybody. Yes, you are in the middle of nowhere and yes there are bugs and spiders outside your bedroom door. Yes, the owner laughs at you and nods when you ask if there are snakes. However, if you are not ready for all of that, think a bit about why you want to do a homestay in Mekong. If you are fine with all of this - You will have the time of your life at this place! The owner, Tan, was not present and his parents who live here do not speak English. However Tan was very accessible both by phone and e-mail. So everything went just fine. We went for a walk the first day and met a family, how didn't speak English either, but took us in to eat some fruits and pray with them. It was a experience you'll have for a life time. After we came back we fell asleep in the hammocks while reading. There are super cute puppies and kittens playing all over. Then the best dinner we had in Vietnam. And so much food!!! We where the only ones there and the mother (I think) kept bringing dish after dish. Pork, fish, chicken, rice, vegetables, fruit. She could seriously win MasterChef or something!! They even helped us with further travel to Can Tho. Wrote everything down in Vietnamese so we could show the bus drivers and so. Really helpful and really friendly!

Title: Excellent homestay in authentic Vietnam
Review: The Mekong Cycle Rest is a wonderful place for an excellent price. If you want to be part of an authentic piece of Vietnam, you should really go there. It is not only a wonderful homestay, it's the family that makes your stay really special and unique! Lovely people, amazing nature, delicious traditional food. Highly recommended if you want to visit the Mekong Delta on your own! ----- (For more information, read below) ----- Mekong Cycle Rest is very easy to get to. It's an hour busdrive from Ben Tre (which is a 2hour bus drive from HCMC). We took the bus from HCM City with bus company Minh TÃ¢m (AC and WiFi). In Ben Tre we decided to leave our luggage at the company and visit the city centre of Ben Tre. If you come from HCM city, their is nothing really new to find here, except for the experience that Western people seem to be rather uncommon here. The locals were suprised and happy to see us, which encouraged us in our joy of having found a spot that is not coverred with tourism. You also witness the fact that the markets with all the clothes, electronics, etc., in short, the markets with all the stuff, exist independently from tourists. From Ben Tre you can take the public bus, line number 8 (it's a white bus with yellow and red) that goes to the Cho Lac region (where the homestay is located). Don't waste time on searching for a bus stop. Just make sure to be on a good and visible spot on the side of the road and when your bus approaches, start waving, cheering and jumping until the bus comes in your direction. Don't expect Western public transportation. We loved the seemingly chaotic but actually well-managed world inside the (what Vietnamese call) 'chickenbus'. Bicycles, bags with food, us as Western backpackers, elderly, young families, everybody and everything was stuffed on that bus. Oh and don't worry, just sit down and wait until the 'bus-manager' comes to you and shows you how much you should pay. On our first ride we paid 20.000 VND per person, our second ride 40.000 VND (the bus manager charged extra for our luggage). Enjoy your view as you drive further and further into the Mekong Delta. Tan, our contact of the homestay, talked to the busdriver (through our telephone) so he could drop us of at the right spot. Two motorbikes were already waiting for us to pick us up. We arrived, had a warm welcome, took a shower and were guided to a feast of traditional Vietnamese food! The mother of the family kept bringing new dishes, all well balanced in taste, all prepared with care. As hungry as we were after our trip, we could not possibly eat it all! And just when you thought no more dishes would follow, some fresh and sweet pineapple was brought to loosen up our stomaches. WOW! Next day we borrowed two Vietnamese bicycles and just got lost in the Mekong Delta. What we already witnessed in Ben Tre was intensified here. Every motorbike that passed us looked back, smiled, waved, children called their parents, and we could only laugh, smile back and fall deeper and deeper in love with Vietnam. We biked and biked, through palm trees, lime trees, banana trees, every road brought new senses. Suddenly you stumble upon a catholic church, then again you hit the main road that enables you to shortly orientate before diving under again in the narrow streets and Vietnamese houses. There are plenty of small shops that are glad to sell you food and water, so you should not worry about that. Moreover, our host wrote a small note for us, that we treasured in our pocket for when we would like to return home. Everybody in the neighborhood knows the proud, noble and gentle former farmer that he is. A bit past noon, when the rising temperature started to weigh on us, we returned home, only to find the entire family united. We played foot-shuttlecock, tried to learn some Vietnamese, played cards, laughed together, ate together and drank together. Our days in heaven were complete! When we left, Tan made sure we could continue our trip safely. He called Minh TÃ¢m for us and told them where to pick us up so we could get to HCM City on schedule. Also during the trip he stayed in touch, to make sure everything was going well.

Title: Great homestay in rural Vietnam
Review: This is a great homestay that is located off the beaten tourist path. I think most people say there as part of a cycle tour. I got there after checking the online reviews - though I didn't realised how far it was from Ben Tre (the town I wanted to visit). I was slightly shocked when I realised it, but in the end I was glad I found this place instead. It really is a place to explore rural Vietnam. - The room is simple (bed, desk, chair and fan), but the bed is very comfortable. - Shared toilets and showers are outside the rooms. - The food is great - the potions for lunch and dinners were big, and very tasty. The surrounding area is lovely, and a great way to explore the real rural Vietnam, without being touristy. Either walk the little path or ask for a bike - I got one of their bikes to cycle around. It was fun and a great experience. Finally, the family who owns the homestay is just so friendly. I felt welcome, and while no one spoke English as their son Tan was away, we still managed to communicate using phones. After my first dinner we were trying to teach each other some English and Vietnamese. It was a great experience, and loved my stay. In the end I was lucky to get there - without contacting them to book the place I would have never ever stopped in this beautiful area. Saying that, if you take the bus from Ben Tre make sure the conductor speaks to Tan so you can get off the bus at the right stop (approximate an hour from Ben Tre).

Title: Wonderful food with clean and inviting accommodations
Review: The Mekong Delta is an excellent place to cycle and it is even better if you find a great place to stay. If possible stay at the Mekong Cycle Rest. When we were there a few months ago after it had just opened. Mrs Hai served us a great variety of local food that was superb. All the dishes were home cooked, well presented and delicious. Title: Great Mekong Home Stay
Review: We stayed at Mekong Cycle Rest over night, whilst on a 3 day bicycle tour of the Mekong region. This area is very pretty and interesting with lots of small canals and irrigation channels growing loads of coconuts, rice, and local fruits. The family who own and run the place are extemely friendly (but thankfully not constantly in your face), and provide some wonderful local food and hospitality. There are clean, comfortable and simple bedroom arrangments with fans and mosquito netting. The toilets are clean standard western toilets, with a great shower. 'Mr Hai' may even show you around the plentiful orchard they have and allow you to sample some of the great local produce that he has growing there - guava, oranges, coconuts, rambutan, pepper vines, chillies etc. 'Mrs Hai' cooked up a feast for dinner including local fish, pork and banana flower salad (my favourite), chicken curry, green mango and prawn salad, and fruit. Its a great authentic, and friendly feeling home stay with a few of the simple comforts you may not get off the beaten track. organised by Indochina Countryside Travel.

Title: Most authentic Ben Tre experience
Review: This was the highlight of our four week trip in vietnam. We were picked up by our host family on skooters from where the taxi dropped us in Ben Tre out of the town noisy area into the coconut fields (peaceful green jungle) and to us this was exactly what we were looking for. The Room we had was a local wooden vietnamese house which gave us the real local experience. The food was amazing and had a little bit of everything but you could feel it was made with love ,you can see for yourself in the pictures if your reading this. Hoa Dua is ideal for travellers not looking for crowded noisy towns and with nature all around you. Our host Dueyl was so so so helpful and very kind understanding patient and well informed about everything.she was really hardworking and professional when we were there and we did a local tour with her around the area and later cycled and scooted on our own which was fun and thrilling for us. Title: Awesome place for an authentic experience in the Mekong Delta
Review: This is really a family-owned business - we got to meet the 3 generations and they were all so genuinely kind and helpful, always smiling. The grandma cooked us the best meals (so much food!), the Mom (who's a tour guide) took us on the most beautiful and interesting boat and bike tours. The place is not easy to find (small village 6km south from Ben Tre) - the best is to book in advance or call the host when you arrive in Ben Tre (tel: 0945619395 or 0982816752) and they'll come get you in moto bike. The rooms/bungalows are basic but it's all you need for a few days in nature - and you pay less than $15 per night per person for the room, dinner and breakfast! We had the whole place for ourselves and just loved it - it's just so peaceful and the family so sweet. Highly recommended - way better than staying in the city center and probably our most authentic experience in the Mekong Delta.

Title: Ben Tre Boat Tour
Review: We haven't stayed in this house, but met the family during our 3-hour boat tour around Ben Tre. We randomly met the father around the night market, who offered us a boat tour for the next day, led by his daughter. The tour was great, she was super nice and informative. We sailed along the main canal for a while, then visited a coconut factory, where she explained how people work there. Later we entered a smaller canal and done a 15min walk on the shore along small canals, gardens and coconut trees. It was really beautiful. That's when we visited this homestay on our way, where we got a coconut drink for refreshment (we were offered lunch as well at the booking, but we didn't want to eat that early). It turned out that our tour guide's mother served us and this was their house. They were both super nice and the home looked awesome too! After the break, we walked back to an even smaller little canal, where we were picked up by paddling boats and cruised along the tiny canal, back to our boat on the bigger one. It was really beautiful and peaceful, no other tourists, just local fishermen and lots of coconut trees. The tour ended where we started, next to the main bridge in the city. We all loved the tour and recommend it to anyone who wants to discover Ben Tre in private. (Their contacts: Ms Duyen 0945.619.395 or Ms Dung 0982.816.752)

Title: Rondvaart Mekong Delta Phu Qock
Review: Had hier meer van verwacht. Wel interessant te zien hoe de boten hier hun waren verhandelen. Is wel anders dan ik in gedachte had. Het os niet als in Bangladesh of India waar veel lage boten toegankelijk zijn. Ook is te zien hoe sommige ook hun huislijk leven op de boot hebben.

Title: Great experience
Review: My boyfriend and I stayed at the floating houses for 3 nights. During our stay in June we were the only guests which was nice in a way but quite isolating too. The huts themselves are really set in beautiful surrounding away from the hustle and bustle of my tho. They are pretty basic but have some space to sit outside and watch the sunset. The bed seemed a little dirty at times but all in all we were expecting quite a simple room so were happy. Next we decided to organise some tours and the hotel manager put us in touch with a recommended tour guide. We then set about bartering a price for trips to the floating markets and exploring the mekong. Having travelled around a lot of south east Asia we were to haggling for a good price but being in such an isolated setting without any alternative means of transport we were forced to accept. There was a bad feeling about the whole deal. My boyfriend also requested to try snake traditionally prepared as part of our tour deal but this request was completely ignored and instead we were taken to a zoo to see snaked kept in very small cages.. Something neither of us enjoyed in the slightest! The tour took place on motorbike and fortunately my boyfriend had some experience of this as the trips were rather long passing through very busy towns which were not warned of. The guide spoke little to no English and despite being promised excellent food we were taken to a cheap local restaurant where meals cost a couple of dollars (we wouldn't mind this normally but given the amount of money paid we expected more). As part of the tour price we were arrange a bus to our next stop in mui ne. That morning the guide arrived late and separated my boyfriend and I on different bikes along with our massive bags and we were driven several km to the side of a motorway. Earlier in the morning our hotel owner served us no breakfast promising us that our guide would provide it. This never materialised. We were put on a public bus for hours next to a bag of chickens. In the end the bus only took us to phan thiet and we made a very frustrating journey to mui ne. All in all this would be a great stay for one night but avoid the tours and organise you own transport to leave!

Title: We will never go there again
Review: The owner gives hardly any information upon arrival and gives misstatement. It ones was a nice place, but it's slowly falling apart, due to lack of maintenance. The cleaning was very poor. Dirty toilet, moldy bathroom floor, mold in the ice box, moldy pillows. The dinner table was not cleaned the 5 days we were there and it was dirty when we arrived. The madress is very thin. Taking overprice for bottled water and your are not allowed to bring your own water on the premises. Far to expensive compared with Vietnam prices, you would certainly expect better service for this price. Every time you ask the owner for something he gives you the feeling you disturb him (in lying in his hammock all day!) You have no influence on the contents of the meals. The owner decides the menu (tastes mostly all right though). He only tell you what it is when he is asked. All in all we can't recommend the place.

Title: Not worth the (even small) money
Review: The Mekong Floating House is the nice idea to stay in huts on the river and there might have been good times for that venture. The interior is good enough and might be enough, but it was dirty and neglected. When we arrived there was still garbage from other guests in the bin. And the tea can which was served for breakfast never saw a sink. The bed did not look too inviting. We were glad having brought our travel sheets. The ice box in which were stored some cold drinks was really dirty and we did not even touch it. Also annoying, an owner who tries to get as much money as possible out of his visitors. Even when you organize the boat trip to the floating house by yourself, he wants the cash to receive his commission. First thing he told us was the price for the boat taxi (250000 Dong) - nice welcome. Might be, that his prices are not absolutely overdone, but the manner was disgusting.

Title: Unforgettable experience on the Mekong river!
Review: My girlfriend and I stayed at the Mekong floating house for two nights in December during our trip in South Vietnam. The place consists of 5 bamboo houses with bedroom, bathroom, shower and terrace, away from the chaotic traffic and the noise of the city of My Tho. You'll need a boat to take you from My Tho's pier and the transfer takes just about 15 minutes. As some other reviews say, there are not many comforts or things to do there but that's exactly the concept behind a place so peaceful and secluded. The host is great and can help you arrange trips on the main land as well as give you good advice on your itinerary. We suggest you ask for a motorbike trip to Tra Vihn: the scenery is wonderful and you won't meet other tourists along the road. The host is also so kind he would bargain the price for you when booking boats or trips and you pay directly to him thus reducing the chances of a rip off. Breakfast and dinner are served on the terrace: the food is very good and plenty while the sunset on the River gives you the best background you could ask for. The landscape is stunning and if you go for a walk on the island you'll have the chance to see real life. The price is a bit higher when compared to other accommodations but it's totally worth it and we both agree we would definitely recommend it to everyone!

Title: A great escape - if that's what you are looking for.

Title: The most amazing sunrise I have ever seen !
Review: I was quite excited by the prospect of the Floating House... My husband a bit less, as he thought we would get bored (we stayed three nights) but he ended up loving it and the kids did too ! Mekong Floating house offer a unique experience, something that your rarely get when you travel these days: you feel like you are all alone and that you are living the life of Robinson Crusoe on his desert island ! The house is only made of bamboos and yet feels very confortable, clean and cool (as it benefits from the wind coming from the Mekong river). Beds were a bit unconfortable and the owner should think of investing in new mattresses. Also, our two kids had to sleep together on a single mattress. No other mattress were available we were told: a bit disappointed on that point. For the rest, it was like living a dream: waking up in the morning (very early, thanks to the numerous roosters around) but discovering the most amazing sunrise I have ever seen: the colours were simply stunning and the peacefulness was owe inspiring. Eating on our patio, just above the river, a delicous and copious meal every night, walking on Turtle Island with the kids and discovering the most exotic fruits including Jack fruits, cocao tree and pomelos... We also did a boat tour (a bit too touristy for my taste but the kids loved it) and a bike tour (which we all loved). The manager is very nice and helpful and arranged all our tours and proposed different activities for the kids, like fishing). Overall, a true unique experience which was great for two and a half days (more would have been stretching it in terms of things to do). Funnily enough, the kids absolutly loved it: it was a true family holidays and a true travel experience.

Title: Not at all like the lovely photos
Review: Based on the great reviews and photos, we booked into this place. Only once we got there, we were informed of all the limitations/restrictions: - Hot water only from 8am to 5pm (forget about a quick shower before bed after a hot day - this is the Mekong and it gets hot...) - once you are in the cabin, you are basically confined there - forget about going for a walk other than about 2 minutes to the restaurant, which probably will not be open anyway. The path which goes along the water edge of the island is less than 1m/3ft wide and you'll be constantly running into barking dogs and people watching you from their yards which are right beside the trail. - As for water sports, the only thing you can do is swim in the brown water... - If you want to sleep, bring along ear plugs AND sound reduction ear protectors as the river boats run all night long, and they are VERY LOUD, often with shouting and banging happening right outside your floating cabin. You'll need double hearing protection if you want to sleep. - Confirm in advance that the special (and rather over-priced) food is actually available. You may discover that they did not stock up enough and the menu is limited to some instant noodles. And, bring your own water unless you enjoy paying 3x the normal price for hotel bottled water. It looks lovely, but you really need to know what you are getting into...

Title: Very nice and enjoyable
Review: I've stayed at a handful of hotels in Vietnam and sometimes in the smaller cities it's hard to find a place that shares the same comforts of home. The Hoang Ngoc hotel has been one of the nicer places I've stayed. When I arrived I had reserved a cheaper room which I wanted a bigger bed so got a different room with no hassle. The manager Ngoc was very helpful and a pleasure. The cafe had free breakfast included and was very tasty. The sitting area and kitchen were very clean. The room I stayed in was the deluxe king bed which was fabulous. It had a small sitting area and a very large bed with extra pillows and large duvet. The bathroom was very clean and the shower worked perfect. I have found in other hotels the shower not working easily and after a long day of riding I feel the shower is the most important thing at the end of the day. Overall i had a great 2 day stay and will definitely be staying here on my next trek! Thank you Ngoc!

Title: Acceptable - good base to visit the beautiful area
Review: We stayed there one night as part of a tour in the area. We had no expectations and were neither disappointed nor thrilled. Location: good - on main road in town (unfortunate if your room faces the street) Service: Staff speak almost no English (nor French) but try their best to communicate. Room: spacious, reasonably clean. Beds are hard (as in most places). A/C, WI-FI and a fridge. Old-fashioned. Bathroom: basic but enough hot water for both of us to shower...warning: as in most places we went to in the area:just a shower head and no receiver so expect to flood the whole bathroom. The sink has no drain tube - everything goes directly to the floor... No meals served. There is a restaurant across the street that serves "hot pot" a typical and popular dish. For breakfast there is a "bakery" right next door and coffee shops close to the market. There are also a number of simple restaurant serving vietnamese breakfast within walking distance. Definitely not a "nice" hotel but acceptable in northern Vietnam standards. Serves its purpose if you only plan to stay in the room to sleep and shower.

Title: Start looking here
Review: Welcome to Ha Giang province folks.You'll be glad you made the effort. You don't need a guide for the walks around Dong Van! Read below. This hotel had the best, friendliest, knowledgeable and helpful staff in the whole town. For trekking information they have maps on the wall which explain everything so you can self guide and explore without a local 'guide'. All information is in the entrance. This hotel is a fantastic place to start. Back to the guides in the town. If you meet one and think that the fees are higher than a guide in your own country - you are probably right. So, you can self guide. Try this revolutionary process... 1. Googlle maps 2. Type Dong Van, Ha Giang 3. Zoom in. 4. Print. Now you can enjoy 2 great walks. Anyone can EASILY walk either in a day. The circle track to the north is a wide and open path through 5-6 villages, more if you deviate. You'll see incredible views, i really mean incredible. The canyonous gorge on China.s border is quite spectacular. There are lots of locals around to point the way and interact with. It's safe, interesting and rewarding. You could try to 'homestay' but we had zero regrets sleeping back in Dong Van. You'll see. The second walk is to the south west of Dong Van. Walk the main road toward Ha Giang town, turn left after 2 or 3 k's at the small lake/dam up the hill. Use your map. This walk passes a surreal valley and village at the end. You can double back or loops if you follow the workers mountain train.Enjoy your hikes. Dong Van is booming and won't be the retreat it is for long. This hotel was often booked. We also stayed in a private house. There are many in town but we got lucky and scored our own full house. On the street to THE coffee shop there was a CHEAP!! dorm like place above a clothes shop. You get what you pay for. The motorbike - scooter ride to Meo Vac was glorious. The Hmong palace is unique stop. The Sunday markets in Dong Van and MeoVac.... wow!

Title: Clean and comfortable
Review: We stayed here on the top floor, twin room, each bed double size, one with mosquito net. Staff were helpful but spoke little English, which is to be expected in a non-touristy town like Dong Van. Beds were comfortable (certainly a lot softer than the typical Vietnamese bed), bathroom basic, clean enough, though a little dusty. Make sure you get a room with balcony overlooking the main street, the street life and view of the town is amazing. The review comparatively with other accommodation in this area would be above average. Recommended.

Title: Perfect stay!
Review: I stayed with my friend for one night while doing the motorbike loop. We got beds in a ''dorm'' which is more like a family room :) Giant beds and confortable linens. It was perfect. Title: The most silent sleep in whole Vietnam
Review: Traveling through Vietnam for 2 months, the utmost challenge was constant noise that disrupted our sleep - from roosters crowing way before sunrise through all day long honking sound from the road then to karaoke singing in public at night. We stayed for two nights on 6th fl of this hotel and had zero noise in the room. The air-conditioning was good and silent. All noise from outside was completely blocked. We had great sleep and rested well for onward motorbike travel. Wifi in the room and lobby was strong. Elevator is large and quick to up and down from 6th fl to 2nd fl where the lobby was. The owner and staff speak good English. When we arrived the hotel, we just had had a motorbike accident where one of my knees were banged up pretty bad. The owner observed our state and offered hands to clean up the wound. She brought an ex-nurse who is the owner of Green Karst restaurant across the street, to our room to help us with wrapping up the wound. Dong Van is a small town and cared much about travelers especially who are in need. I felt like being home surrounded by relatives.

Title: Smiley staff who do their best
Review: Some things seems to be constant about the hotels in Ha Giang. Hard beds, dirty kettles and the occasional blackout. When I asked if I could change my kettle to a clean one, the hapless staff realised that all their kettles were plagued with the same layer of unknown white muck. After which they suggested me to get my hot water from the lobby drink directly. The lobby was just a short walk from my room so I did just that a couple of times. During my stay in Dong Van, the power went out two times in quick succession. Both times, I heard some shouts in the lobby and the sound of a generator starting up, a good sign that at least the hotel is on top of blackout situations. Even though they speak little English, the staff are always ready to smile and ready to help. The hotel is actually situated on top of a mini mart so you have to go up some stairs to reach the hotel lobby. Sharing shopfront space with a shop on the first floor, bike parking tends to get a bit squeezy at times. For snacks, just walk out to the main road and turn right to find some good BBQ street food! My room is big and have a heat insulated bathroom, although it can get noise from any commotion in the lobby, a nearby ktv at night and a construction site in the morning. Okay, that is actually not as bad as it sounds XD

Title: As good as it gets in Dong Van
Review: Our 11 person group enjoyed our stay here. Dong Van is bit like Vietnam's Dodge City - a real frontier town which is not surprising as it was flattened during the war with China in 1979. The hotel is quite new, located next to the market place. It is clean, tidy and everything works. The staff are friendly and helpful. Dong Van is a worthy alternative to Sapa which has become overly crowded with tourists. I am not surprised that this is the No.1 hotel in Dong Van. Recommended.

Title: Best in Dong Van
Review: This is a small modern hotel in the center of Dong Van just steps from the market. If you are a westerner and want to stay there you probably came to visit the colorful market with all the ethnic minorities. I can assure you it is worth the trip. The hotel serves the purpose and is clean. Dong Van is high on the mountains at about 1,000m and it can get very cold during the night. Most rooms do not have glass windows, but wooden panels instead. We had a VIP room for 19$ :) and I was amazed that there were no windows. I asked for another room and I've been teached that wooden panels instead of windows is considered luxury. They have a few rooms with windows too, but they also have the wooden panels to a balcony, so you end up with the same problem that the thermal insulation does not work. Anyways, the A/C in the room was really quiet and they also gave us a radiator so we could balance a little the cold air coming from outside. In the end it has been a good night, even though we could not see what happens outside. The rooms are clean and so is the bathroom. There is no restaurant.

Title: What makes this hotel special, and warrants a five star rating, is the staff.
Review: The Xuan Thu Guesthouse, sometimes incorrectly referred to as a hostel, is in fact a typical Vietnamese two star budget hotel. Nothing special about the hotel itself, but for 200,000 VND it is perfectly acceptable choice travelers on a budget. What makes this hotel special, and warrants a five star rating, is the staff. They are the nicest and friendliest group of people that you would ever want to meet. In addition to being incredibly helpful, the staff all speaks English to some degree, some of them quite fluently. Trust me; you will not meet very many English speaking people in Ha Giang province, particularly outside of Dong Va. Then there is Mr. Hung; a fluent English speaker, restaurateur and tour guide. Mr. Hung is extremely helpful, can organize all means of transportation and tours and promptly replies to e-mails. To travel independently in Ha Giang province, visitors who do not speak Vietnamese will need some help from time to time organizing transportation. On my recent 16 day tour of the province Mr. Hung helped me out on a number of occasions and I would not hesitate to recommend his services.

Title: This is not Rocky Plateau Hotel
Review: The title of this hotel is misleading - the name of this hotel is "Hoa Cuong Hotel" and not "Rocky Plateau Hotel". Hoa Cuong Hotel is the most modern hotel in Dong Van and was opened earlier in 2016. "Rocky Plateau Hotel" - on the other side - is a crappy place in Dong Van with terrible comments in other travel guides. Despite the fact that Hoa Cuong Hotel and Rocky Plateau Hotel are based at the same street, they should not be mixed up. Hoa Cuong Hotel offers very spacious rooms. However, the atmospehre is rather "cold" - the architecture of the hotel would better fit into a big city like Hanoi (but not the old town!) or Saigon but not to a rural place like Dong Van. Not sure what the architect thought while planning this hotel The quality of the rooms was good. The personnel spoke a little bit of English. There is a restaurant offering dinner and breakfast. However, I would rather go out to eat in town which is only a 5 - 10 minute walk away. Hoa Cuong Hotel is definitely a place to spend a night, especially since Dong Van is not offering a large selection of hotels. However, backpackers may prefer to stay at a homestay in order to see the traditional atmosphere of this beautiful place in northern Vietnam.

Title: The most modern hotel right in the centre of ancient town
Review: This is so far the most modern and the best hotel in Dong Van town. It is located right in the heart of the ancient town. The room is splendid, spacious, very clean and provides all amenities. The bed is very comfortable which gave us the first good sleep after 3 days traveling over mountainous provinces. There is heater as well which is very needed during winter time in this town. We stayed in 7th floor and the view from our window is like in a paint, very beautiful. The breakfast is free but it's not a buffet, you can only choose one meal in a limited menu and the restaurant only serves breakfast. The meal is just average but we did not ask more as we were happy with our room and the price is reasonable (the price is not available in booking websites but you can find it in the hotel homepage).

Title: A real "local" experience
Review: While the other newer hotels in Dong Van are run by Viets from down on the plains, this hotel is run by mountain people. It is more traditional and better reflects the time warp town that you are staying in. The bed was the softest we have ever experienced in 8 years and 5 trips to Viet Nam - it was a "memory foam" mattress exactly the same as we have at home! It would have made for the best night sleep in our 4 weeks on the road except that the construction site next door started at sun up! A highlight was the wakening to the loud speakers in the street telling us to plant trees, don't harm your children pick up litter and try to grow more corn! (or something like that) WiFi was good in the foyer lounge If you are seeking a true cultural experience then this hotel is the place to stay - the others could be in any town in Viet Nam

Title: Below-average two/three star Vietnamese hotel, to be avoided.
Review: My wife and I stayed here one night as part of a group of 20 on a three day geological field trip to the Dong Van Stone Plateau. A relatively modern hotel. We were told by the trip organizers that this was the best hotel in town. Perhaps it is the only one that could accommodate a group of our size. An average room with a reasonable bed, AC that worked, but a poorly maintained bathroom - shower controls did not work properly and water on the floor after flushing the toilet. We had a mediocre group dinner with mostly cold food. Only the fish (quite good) and the soup were hot. The restaurant has amazingly noisy acoustics due to a tiled floor and bare walls. Our room (303) was directly up the stairs from the lobby and restaurant (level 2) and was noisy as a consequence. Like a lot of rooms in smaller Vietnamese hotels, our room had no external window, but at least it had a window onto the corridor. I don't know what the room price was so I cannot comment on value. Recommendation: Only stay there if there is no other choice. Would I stay there again? No.

Title: Very basic. Not great if you
Review: This is a motel, not hotel and accommodation is very basic. But for the little money that we paid, we got a decent sized room with twin king sized beds and an en suite bath and toilet. Rooms have a kettle, meagre toiletry ammeties, but is clean and in good state of upkeep. We came in the depths of the winter and on one particularly cold night when temperatures plunged to 2 degrees C, heating was woefully inadequate leaving us frozen to the bone. Property itself is quiet since it is located off the main thoroughfare, and facing the fields, so a very decent view of mountains and paddy fields through the windows.

Title: Good place to stay while in the area on business
Review: First off, as others have mentioned this is not a 5-star hotel but it is not for a lack of trying by the staff. The service here is outstanding and they do try to add little things that a five-star hotel would like a nightly sweet and (since I was here over Valentines day) a Valentines card. The building is beat up a bit and old. There was some minor water damage on the wall in my bathroom. Little things, yes but not 5-star. Second, no, this place is not in HCMC and if you are planning to visit Dist. 1 this is not the place for you. Don't get upset that they don't offer transportation to a location 1.5 hours away. This is still a nice stay when on business in the area. The bed in the room is extremely comfortable. It's a memory foam mattress. The AC is great and so is the wifi. No real issues while I was there and will definitely stay there again when I return. And, I also ate at restaurant for dinner while there and found the food to be very good.

Title: Good Hotel but not for families wanting to Tour.
Review: This hotel is by no means a five star hotel. The rooms have a TV but there is no aerial reception to get the TV working. There is no room clock anywhere to be seen, which we had to rely on our mobile phones to tell the time. Next there is no tour desk or any information of finding local attractions. We had to rely on the doorman to give us tips. There is no shuttle bus to Ho Chi Min City. The hotel is actually located roughly 40 minutes outside of the city. The cost of commuting to the city via taxi quickly starts to add up. Passports were taken on checkin or they will charge to a credit card around 150 US dollars per guest. Could be an issue for some but we gave them our passports. No issues as such when checking out and the Hotel Staff handed them over. There was a discrepsency when we were checking in that my son was an extra unpaid guest but that was resolved when I showed them my reservation. Now that we got the negatives aside. The good points of the hotel is that the staff were extremely curteous to our family of 5. The buffet which is located on the 14 floor is excellent and we had no problems with the food being served which is Western, Vietnamese and Chinese cuisine. Its a credit to the Restaurant Manager Xoan who was extremely attentive in explaining the local cuisine and customs. The rooms were comfortable and clean but lacking in a few areas mentioned above. By staying in this Hotel you will be supporting the local community as all the staff live locally. On Saturday nights there is a bbq seafood buffet for 4400 dong ($27.00 Australian) which also includes unlimited beer and wine which was great but could have included a better selection of seafood such as squid/calamari and scallops which on our occasion was missing. Overall I am all for supporting the locals and the Vietnamese people are a peaceful race given their past history. This hotels major clientele are businessman as its located in the business district. However having said that I would recommend a city hotel for families considering on touring or getting better access to tour operators as the The Mira Hotel just does not make it convenient at all to get to where you want. Overall it was a pleasant stay but needs more facilities to get to five star standards. Take not that there is no Airport pickup service offered by this hotel. Only a drop off which cost our family around 1 million Vietnamese Dong.

Title: Wasn't really feeling it...
Review: Perhaps in this area of Vietnam this may be one of the better hotel choices but I didn't really care for it. It wasn't real dated but it wasn't really with modern hotel standards either. Rooms were very dim which gave a somewhat creepy vibe. The hallways and common areas throughout the hotel were extremely hot and also very dimly lit. The dim hallways, upon close inspection, were not real clean. Carpets had a lot of lint and fuzz on them so the clearly don't get vacuumed often. Furniture was a little worn. This may be one of the better choices for the area and that may be why it has a better rating but it is not a 4 or 5 star hotel by any stretch. Breakfast buffet was decent. I guess it all comes down to your expectations. I get the sense that many people use this hotel for business and it may be ok for those type of stays but it just made me uncomfortable. Better lighting may go a long way to eliminate the creepy factor.

Title: Not 5-Star Hotel - Yet
Review: The Mira Hotel advertises itself as a 5-star hotel and in many respects, it could be. But it is not there yet. I have stayed here several times while visiting a factory nearby. The rooms are huge and comfortable. The bathrooms are large with separate shower and tub. Water pressure is excellent. The A/C works GREAT! Seriously great! Which one needs while in Vietnam. ;-) As mentioned by others, corridors are dark and there is no signage to places like the pool and gym. You have to stumble along until you find what you're looking for. However, the pool is very nice if you can get it at a time when people aren't partying in it. ;-) The room has a separate desk area, which I really like. The free WiFi is very fast. However, there is only one outlet available in which to plug a laptop. It is already being used by the desk lamp. So one must unplug the lamp to plug in the laptop, which is very annoying. I would like to see the hotel add another outlet over there - it only makes sense. Room rates are very reasonable and breakfast is included. However, I found the food to be a little bland. The staff at the front desk is very friendly and tries hard. Their English gets a little better each time I come. The beds are incredibly soft and comfortable. I have always slept well when I've been here. Until this last time and this is my big complaint: The pillows for the beds are HUGE and firm. You cannot lie on them (even one of them) without your neck being at almost a 90 degree angle from your back. Very uncomfortable. The hotel offers a soft, foam lumbar pillow upon request. These pillows are wonderful and provide a good night's sleep. We always request them upon check in. However, this last visit (3 nights) they had run out of available pillows before we checked in. We asked every day. They never had any available. Clearly they either don't have many or a lot of other people want them because their regular pillows are SO UNCOMFORTABLY AWFUL! A 5-Star Hotel (which they want to be) does not have this issue. They need to either get more of these "soft pillows" or replace their horrifically huge pillows with something more comfortable. I know this may seem like a silly complaint but my favorite thing about The Mira up until this visit has been their incredible beds and having a good night's sleep, which is important when you're traveling. My colleague and I were extremely disappointed about the pillow situation and neither of us slept well our entire visit. I have only given them three stars for this visit because of the pillow debacle. I hope they rectify the situation before my next visit.

Title: Form is better than Substance
Review: If you are staying for many days to service a client in this in the industrial part of HCM city, then read on. The rooms facing the main road should be avoided. The traffic noise will keep you up with horns that can blast like a artillery shell, often suddently. Right up to 2am and then it starts again at 5 am. Enter the lobby, be mindful that the clocks showing the times in different city are not working. For some reason they are all at 6.45 AM. The only restaurant is on the 4th floor. You may have trouble finding the Bar that is supposed to be on 12B floor. Go up there and you see a quiet corridor, with exits to nowhere. No sign posts. Let me know if you ever find the 12B Bar. Gym is on the 5th floor that is sparse. No cups for drinking water. Bring Your Own. Breakfast is decent but coffee lovers have to settle for the common coffee. The coffee machine that makes actual coffee latter, cappuchino etc is broke (I don't know since when). Dinner items - keep clear of fried stuff includinh noodles because they are bathed in oil. Probably best to go next door where a shopping centre fast food outlet will do better. Corridors of floors is dimly lit and may offer a romantic feel. But bright corridors leading to my rfoom is what offers me a sense of security. Let's not forget the swimming pool and the sauna that needs to be searched - again no sign posts. They are on the 5th floor and you need to get through an obscure metal door, then let your nose guide you to the gym and swimming pool. It seems that this the best hotel in the vicinity - so you have to settle for this or take an hour commute to and from HCM city. By the way change the pillows as you come in. They do have a strange odour.

Title: 3 Week stay March 2015
Review: My wife and I just returned from a long stay at the Mira. Our son married a local lady from Binh Duong and we selected the Mira to host the wedding party as well as our place of residence for 21 days. The party was hosted by us but the Mira took care of every detail including food/drink/MC/music/flowers/etc.....for a party of 600 local friends and family. We met with the GM and the Manager of Food services on several occasions to go over all of the details. And in every case the staff was prepared, on time, and had all of the right answers. The day of the wedding came the Party came off without a single problem. In fact as so often happens we had an additional 80 people show up that had not been planned for and the staff set up tables and brought in food with hardly any conversation. I'm sure that "behind the curtain" there was some real scrambling going on to get everything pulled together but out front the event was totally flawless. Truly a 5 star performance from the first meeting to the departure of the last guest. The accommodation, the service, the food temperature/taste/quantity, the serving of the tables, the attire of the staff, the room acoustics, the temperature, the noise level,.....in short all of the details that I had been obsessing about were handled absolutely perfectly. My wife and I stayed in a suite at the hotel for 1 week before and 2 weeks after the wedding. In the process we got to know the owner quite well as well as most of the staff. Our room was an excellent room by any any standards. Certainly not a true 5 star but a solid 4 star accommodations. Beds were outstanding. A/C was super. Breakfast buffet was top shelf. The only shortfall came in evening dining room experience. Food was good but service was not up to standards of the rest of the place. Front door and front desk personnel were good. English was weak but functional. Managers all had very good english. Security was always present and there was never a moment of safety concern during out entire stay. For sure we were very satisfied and felt very good about our decision to hold our event at the Mira. Great Job !!

The bell boy then spent time with us explaining all the features of the room, the TV, the bath and the mini bar. Our room had a full bath and a half bath in the living room. We over looked the main road which could be noisy at times but for the most part no different than any other city hotel. I read the previous reviews here and don't understand them. Perhaps they were talking about a different hotel as certainly the practice of supplying 'company' in the form of a women for $17USD is outrageous. There must have been another explanation for the charge. Also the other nice hotel in thu dau mot is the Becamex which is a state owned company hotel. There is a breakfast buffet included in the room price that is extraordinary both for taste and variety of both European and local cuisine and with a delicious coffee. It is on the fourth floor along with some meeting rooms. All in all a great hotel experience. .

Title: I slept like a baby! :-)
Review: This is a very new hotel and as such, it has much room for improvement. But first, the good things: my room was quite large and comfortable with a separate desk area, which I liked. There was fruit in the room when I arrived which I appreciated because I checked in between meal times and I was hungry! :-) The free WiFi worked very well and the shower had great water pressure. The A/C worked perfectly all day and night. Best of all, the bed was amazing, with a pillow top mattress. I got the best sleep here that I got in my three weeks in Asia. TIP: the pillows that come with the bed are too large and too firm. Ask the front desk to send up a "smaller soft pillow". They will bring up a smaller, squishier, foam-like pillow (but not hot like foam). It is really comfortable. Breakfast was decent and the service in the breakfast room was excellent. Now for the things that need improvement: No guest directory in the room explaining where anything is, what the hours for breakfast, pool, and gym are. No signage to guide guests to the pool and gym. No shower mat to stand on and the shower floor is very smooth and slick marble. I had to throw a towel on the shower floor to keep from slipping when the floor was wet. The only hangers in my closet were shirt/jacket hangers. In other rooms, the only hangers were skirt/pant hangers. They need to get this organized. I supposedly got a room on a non smoking floor but whenever the A/C ran, it smelled like I was on a smoking floor. Chairs and couch in the room are not very comfortable. The only place you can use their hair dryer is at the desk. Fortunately, they have installed a big mirror there so the desk becomes a dressing table. But it's not where I like to dry my hair. And finally, while they tried very hard to give good service, their staff had very little English-speaking ability. I think that is the biggest drawback to this hotel for English-speaking guests. Overall, the price was excellent and I will go back, if only for the bed! In my opinion, they have a ways to go to get up to a three or four star status but I do think they're working on it.

Title: Some life in ghost town
Review: This hotel is good for attending a meeting at the next door Binh Duong conference centre or for other work related purpose. I cannot imagine anyone to stay in the fairly empty Becamex New City for any other reason. (As if the planners did not learn anything from the 20th century: you are supposed to design cities for people, not for cars!) The hotel is very big and divided into hotel rooms and apartments, while the restaurant, a gym and a great outdoor pool are in the middle. For an unknown reason I got the apartment. It was clean, but quite sparse and not a great design. My colleague got a hotel room which looked comfortable. The restaurant was ok. I particularly liked the gym and the pool. The service was kind and attentive.

Title: New hotel, but not quite up to 100% yet
Review: It's all new and rooms are big and clean. There were a lot of design flaws that they need to weed out. One was the table and the chair. I had 2 chairs with a table in my room, perfect for my computer, I thought at first. But the table had a very big drawer underneath, so my legs could not get under the table. Even with the chair in the lowest position, it was not possible to sit at the table and work. The light switches took a lot of getting used to. Normally when you put the room card in the holder, the lights will turn on. Here i had to not just torn on the light, but first turn it off and then on, before the lights went on. It turned off in the bathroom automatically, which is good for power saving. But it would be more logical to just push the light switch once, to turn the light back on. Not much to choose from in the restaurant, it was also mostly empty. Only some sandwiches, if you wanted Vietnamese food, you had to ask for the additional menu. Quite in the middle of nowhere. but good if you are in the industrial area. Really nothing happening around the hotel, except from a few restaurants and luckily a family mart. Funny thing at the pool. They don't have a lifeguard, but they have staff all the time, to make sure you sign your name on a paper, before you use the pool. It's a really nice pool, but they had a party one day at the pool, and there was loud music and drunk people, when i just wanted a quiet swim.

Title: Reliable No Nonsense Business Hotel
Review: South Vietnam is growing rapidly, and Binh Duong is really a clear example of that. With so many industries in this area, unfortunately service is lack behind, thus this boom province certainly lacks of good quality accommodations. This hotel is located in considerably nicer area of Binh Duong, convenience enough to visit many factories in this area. There are restaurants in hotel's vicinity, so you could go and dine out after work. I've stayed in this hotel several times in last 2 years. This is a no nonsense hotel, with simple modern design. If you're looking for sophistication, certainly you couldn't find there. Check in is always handled professionally, quick and efficient, although sometimes there was a misunderstanding caused by language barrier. I think their lifts are slow for a business hotel. This hotel has a restaurant which is used as breakfast place with a large patio, which is quite enjoyable with nice weather. There is also a swimming pool, but unfortunately I never had a chance to use. They have 2 room category, but I usually stay in the entry level. Actually, there is not much difference between the two. Each has a bedroom, bathroom and living quarter with kitchen set and a folded bed. The folded bed's mattress is really hard and firm. Room design is functional without touch of sophistication. TV selection is quite good, with plenty of international channels. Wifi connection is reliable and fast. Room is kept clean, but not in its sparkling condition. I think its modern furniture will look tired in next 5 years without proper maintenance. Breakfast buffet is adequate, with quite good quality. It has a few Western food (bacon, egg, bread), some Vietnamese/ Asian dishes like pho, congee, fried rice/ noodle and stir fried items. Overall, it is a dependable business hotel in Binh Duong, one hour away from HCMC.

Not too much options if you are not used to vietnamise breakfest. The surroundings are OK. From there to the airport takes between 30 to 60 minutes depending of the traffic.

Title: Good value in Vietnam
Review: Vietnam is generally very inexpensive. I was housed in this hotel for 2 weeks by my company prior to moving to a local home. The room was a suite, with living room, TV, kitchenette and included breakfast. Rooms were clean, bed was comfortable, great view of the city from the 14th floor, especially during monsoon season; nice to step out on the balcony and watch the rain. Room amenities were average. Linen very nice. Front desk and reception helpful. A pool and very average workout room; breakfast buffet was okay/good; chef would fix fresh eggs if you asked; white bread but nice baguettes and plenty of fresh fruit. Coffee of the very strong Vietnamese type which I watered down with hot water. I think the price was about 35.00 US a night, so for what you are getting it was quite reasonable. I would stay there again.

Title: Splendid Staff and comfy beds

Title: Faulty Towers
Review: While the gardens of this 'resort' are majestic and the ambiance quaint, that is where the appeal ends. It is a long way from Ho Chi Minh City, the service is terrible, the aircon doesn't work and the food is ordinary at best- there weren't even towels in our room. The ad that made us book completely misrepresented the reality of the venue. After one night we actually left even though we had paid for five nights and were very happy with that decision. I would advise you run a mile from ever considering staying here.

Title: OUTSTANDING VISIT
Review: Several months ago I stayed at the Saigon Park Resort for a month. It is a wonderful hotel. The level of service is outstanding from the manager to the maids. They are only too happy to help you with whatever your needs may be. From arrival to checkout, they will always be there for you. The facility itself is very new, beautiful and well kept. One can tell that the staff takes pride in there place of employment, but more importantly they take pride in doing the best job that they can do for the guests. Most amenities are available there and if your not sure, just ask and they will help you. This would be a wonderful place to get married and me and my new wife discussed it but we could not because of geographic matters. It would have been wonderful though with its banquet facilities and the very beautiful garden. In fact, after talking to Tommy the manager I learned that the cost of having a wedding there is very competitive with other facilities. However, having viewed them also, they cannot offer the same luxury and convenience as this place does. In conclusion, I have stayed at many hotels, some better some worse, but only at this one did I feel that the staff really cares about the guest. I highly recommend it and I will be certain to visit there again, this time for pleasure and relaxation though.

Title: A welcome break from the hustle and bustle
Review: We decided to stay at this hotel as we wanted to chill out away from the cities for two nights. The hotel is quite far from Ho Chi Minh City so expect to pay about $25 for a taxi from the airport. We arrived in the late evening and were greeted by friendly staff who were eager to help and even brought us a meal even though the kitchen was closed. The pool is large and kept very clean. I had the pleasure of meeting the manager who was very friendly and helped us out with travel advice. The food, breakfast could of been better (which is is my only negative about our stay), the evening meal was excellent and so was the service. I would recommend this hotel if you want some peace and quiet away from the city for a few days.

Title: Business Only
