Title: Ups and downs
Review: So I stayed at this hotel for 2.5 months so I feel I have a lot to say. Since I stayed a long time they gave me a very good discount on the room. Once they charged me less one month just to be nice. Staff extremely helpful. Rooms were nice in a nice area. Lets talk about the many cons. 1. The cleaning ladies are absolutely worthless at their jobs. After every cleaning day I stood baffled at how terrible of a job they have done. Even laundry was often returned to me so wrinkled I couldn't even iron it and had to return items to laundry bin(probably left in washing machine overnight). After one cleaning day my tie clip and little pocket pen(wasn't cheap AND it was a gift) went missing after the once a week cleaning. I have an undressing ritual where everything goes in the same place, I didn't misplace it. I went and got another tie clip but could not find a fancy new pen. Next cleaning day that tie clip also went missing. I also had some personal towels I didnt use since the hotel supplied towels. Those went missing too. No chance they mixed them up with the hotel towels, the hotel towels have the hotel name on them... mine didnt. My girlfriend also claimed some of her more fashionable blouses went missing. Sometimes we got clothes that wasn't ours. Laundry was free... but I would have preferred to pay if it meant they would do half a decent job. So the cleaning ladies were banned from my room. Front desk guys are awesome, super friendly and nice, however if you need something you have to ask numerous times because they forget or are too lazy. Location is only good if you have personal transport, its REALLY on the city outer limits so you need a motorbike. Being on built on the edge of the wilderness there is an abundance of insects, I moved up one floor from ground level and it solved the problem for the most part. After 5 days on ground level I eradicated 100 centipedes, 2 cockroaches and a few flyers. No problems after going to second floor.. except for ants which I dealt with. They have a mini fridge but it was rarely stocked appropriately so on the rare occasions I needed something, they didn't have it or it wasn't cold. Last thing, AC took a long time to cool down the room, even when it had been running all day I slept with blankets at ankles. It was a close call between 2 and 3 stars. For the price I paid for the room I got, Id say it was a good deal. Just don't let cleaning ladies in unattended and don't be afraid to tell them they forgot to change towels... again or you didn't even sweep... again.... or they left the trash... again or any other variety of things they are bound to forget. Wow was this a rant or a review?

Title: Clean, Modern, Good Location
Review: I am giving this hotel 4 stars because of what the hotel is - not what it isn't. No, there is no restaurant. This chain of hotels is a bit odd in that they are generally the most up-scale in their market (I've now stayed in two-both in Lam Dong province). And yet they don't offer food (no breakfast, no restaurant). Another review mentioned a 55k voucher you can buy or get for breakfast. I didn't know about that option. Perhaps it's a special deal for certain room rates. While the rooms are modern, they are not all bright. Your best option is a room off the back of the hotel. Title: Very good
Review: Hotel is about 1,5km from centre and there is a big grocery store in between them. Breakfast was reasonable priced (about 1 euro per dish) but there is a fridge in the room so you can buy your own. Very clean room with good wifi and ac, very comfortable bed, clean sheets and towels. Hot water and good-sized bathroom. Closed parkinglot and a quiet area. Near-by a cafe with excellent view (bike&photo cafe). Friendly staff who helped us get a good deal with a taxi going to see the Dambri falls. Nothing bad to say so definitely worth the money!

Title: Noisy at night!!!
Review: 2 star hotel I think, but I am told one of the better ones for the area. It was certainly clean enough. We did not have a choice of room and ended up with a room without a window. This, I believe was a blessing, as every moron driving either a bus or truck spends most of his time driving on the highway outside leaning on his horn. The hotel was very noisy during the night, slamming doors people shouting etc. etc. It certainly didn't stop until I had, eventually fallen to sleep. Staff, as always in Vietnam, receive no training and are not as polite as one might wish for. I am not complaining about the lack of English, this is my problem, not theirs. Best points were the cleanliness considering it is 2*. Reasonably priced too.

Title: Quiet place for family, good choice
Review: Located in a small alley on Vo Van Tan street, Bao Loc city. About 250m from Highway 20, Vu Gia is a villa (not really a hotel) with extremely quiet space and spacious campus, covered motorbike parking area. In the yard, there are many kinds of flowers and trees (roses, avocado trees ...). The receptionist (also the owner of the villa) is very enthusiastic and friendly, providing necessary information as well as sharing interesting things for visitors to stay. Check-in procedure is quite simple and fast (takes less than 2 minutes). Spacious, new, clean, bright, equipment works very well, the air conditioner only takes about 5 minutes to cool the room over 30 square meters, hot water works very well (be careful when adjusting) . The bed is spacious and the mattress very soft for a good night's sleep. There is a balcony area for relaxing or smoking on the edge of the corridor with nice views. In short, this is a great place with family if you want to relax and have a good sleep with very reasonable prices.

Title: Comfortable, value for money

Title: Just Average
Review: The rooms and the bathroom were neat and tidy, but the bed had ants crawling over it, which we had to take care of. The hotel offered free in-room wifi, however, the signal was not very strong, and the connection was not always very good. Breakfast was very limiting in choice, offering only soup noodles and dry pieces of bread. There were also a limited number of staff to respond to the needs of the customers. However, the value for money was very good, and its price is just right. Would recommend for a stay in Bao Loc, however, be careful with bugs in the rooms.

Title: Great Value for Money
Review: The Khach San Seri Seri Hotel is well-located near the center of Bao Loc. For the price of the room, approximately US$21 equivalent, the hotel offers excellent value. The room was clean and comfortable, the air conditioner worked well and was quiet, there was plenty of hot water in the shower. Each floor is serviced by two elevators. Check-in was easy, with the desk attendant able to speak English. Note that the staff does need to keep your ID card or passport, and in the case of foreigners, to take it to the police for registration. Wifi was included in the price and worked very well, though the its strength was much better in the hall than in my room. Breakfast, included in the price of the room, was a fairly basic choice of Vietnamese soup-like food (excuse my lack of cultural knowledge on this one), eggs cooked to order, and tasty fresh bread. I was in a rush, but assume tea and coffee would have been available. All things considered, Khach San Seri Seri Hotel offers very comfortable accommodation, particularly in relation to its cost. If you dine out, then I would recommend Quan an Bach Hy An restaurant, located at 147-149 Tran Quoc Toan street in Bao Loc. Tel: 063 386 8668. It offers excellent foods in a cozy, airy atmosphere. It is located perhaps 400 meters up a dirt street from the main road passing through Bao Loc.

Title: Hong Thai Hotel, Bao Loc
Review: This hotel was worth the $8 a night. However, it was a long way from the centre of town. This hotel offers no food, but there are numerous eating places nearby. The window view shown on the website was deceptive: there were no mountain views, just a view from the 5th floor down into a 2 meter square hole. The staff did not speak English and until I spoke Vietnamese they seemed almost suspicious and aloof. Neighbouring rooms seemed to be rented by the hour after dark with accompanying very loud noise. In its favour, the hotel was well cleaned, had an elevator and did allow smoking in the rooms. Next time I would look for something closer to twon.

Title: Don't trust the rating! Awful hotel.
Review: This is by far one of the worst hotels I have ever stayed in... Although my stay lasted less than hour as we soon went somewhere else. The service on arrival was abysmal, it took a while to be checked in and it seemed like we were being ignored. Then came the room... A room which was unbelievably bad for the price, a price which would get you a stunning room in the centre of Hanoi itself. It wasn't just small, rundown and old, but incredibly dirty. This included the bedding which I suspect had not been cleaned in a while. There was dirty on the sheets and unidentifiable stains. To top all this off, in 36c heat they had no AC. The manager claimed hotels In Tam Dao don't have AC. A clear lie. DO NOT stay here. Honestly its a joke of a place. Do your research better than I did this time and find somewhere clean and nice.

Title: Good hotel to stay in Tam Dao: beautiful sight view,cheap, professional service, friendly staff
Review: I came there with my friends on Sunday and stay here for only one day. But I am really sastified with this hotel. There are many kinds of room you can choose one you want. Some of them is 150.000VND/room/day, 300.000VND/room/day. Reservation is good. Staff is friendly and professionally served. There is a church near this hotel. You can walk to here about 5 minutes. A heaven gate is also near here. You can see a wonderful sight view here, filled with clouds, like a heaven here about 10 minutues for a walk. Moreover, there is also a waterfall about 15 minutues for a walk. You can enjoy it. The weather is cool here, about 26 degree C, and that is the wonderful place to come to visit.

Title: Most comfortable hotel in Tam Dao
Review: In this small hill commune with rice fields and vegetable gardens, the last thing one would expect would be a classy, designer hotel as the Ciao Bella. A 3 level, 7 room abode as close to what you would consider as private, new world and avant garde/bohemian in design. You will meet a very friendly owner who makes you feel very at home. The hotel comes with immaculately furnished rooms, clean, with large LED tvs, fantastic marble-tiled bathroom, (rainshowers) and lovely view of the countryside outside. The room rate was 1 million Vietnam dong which I was very happy to pay.

Title: The best hotel in Tam Dao
Review: The owner of this hotel is Ms Thanh. She is very friendly. The hotel has sense of art in decoration You should come there because its new, nice view and easy to go to the market The price is reasonable. But they should have good breakfast for customer I think

Title: Very nice family hotel
Review: I stayed there for a couple of nights and I has a great time. Room was clean and staff was helpfull. They provide a free breakfast at the opposite restaurant. Overall excellent experience, I will stay there again if I am in Tam Dao

Title: Very pleasant European style home hotel
Review: The hotel is rather new and foreigners-friendly. The rooms are not big but offers very good amenities, you will enjoy your Dunlopillo mattress and nice view. There is a common kitchen in the ground floor, so you can bring some food with you and prepare it here. Together with just opened Quan Gio terrace this hotel shows that Tam Dao is changing from a high cost low quality Vietnamese town to the same cost but very nice place to spend a weekend. Title: Full service resort with English speaking & polite staff, nice setting
Review: The Belvedere Resort high atop the mountain in Tam Dao offers very nice amenities, including large, spacious & clean rooms (with king sized beds, refrigerator, a/c, and expansive views of the valley below), pool (another awesome view), restaurant, and large meeting facility. The grounds are kept quite tidy, and the staff are really courteous + super helpful (many of them speak excellent English :). This is a popular destination for Hanoians during the summer months... Be sure to hire a taxi (250k vnd round trip) up to the town center, and sample the open air cafes where grilled foods are the specialty (these have tables with chairs beneath roofs, great for the damp weather)... the sticky rice cooked inside a hollow bamboo tube = yummy!! Enjoy :)

Title: Great View, Great Potential,...But Poor Management, Maintenance and Service
Review: Stayed there one night 08-09/08/15 with small family of 3. Based in Hanoi, we were looking for a short upscale weekend summer escape from the city. Knew the hotel and checked out the comments. Booked a Deluxe Mountain View Room with sales office Hanoi for around 90 US$ per night. Staff asked for 100% pre-payment, which we rejected, since we had given credit card to secure the booking. Overall, the best lodging option in Tam Dao, especially for foreigners. All other hotels in Tam Dao are local guest houses. Good points first. Resort is well appointed and designed, with main building and semi-detached villas assembled around a large courtyard and garden. Directly located at a mountain range with spectacular views over wooded hills and valley, certainly the biggest and one of the few outstanding assets of the resort. Small, but great infinity pool overlooking the valley. Now the down sides. Overall, the resort is an unfortunate and typical example of a locally owned and operated place, where much is invested in the beginning, but once open, not much else is done or cared for. A competent management was visibly absent. Staff's English is poor, no feeling of welcome, and hardly any smiles anywhere. The facilities may have looked good some years ago, but not much thought is given to maintenance. Rooms are clean and spacious, but lack furnishing and decor. Large restaurant menu, but food quality not good, service slow, waited 25 minutes for an ice coffee. Breakfast late, variety local, quality so so. Pool, kid's play, fitness room area are unattended, not in the best shape, or empty. No activities or entertainment in the resort. No shuttle to town. Could be a much better place if owners would know how to do or if they would care for.

Title: Breathtaking view resort
Review: I was there at the end of February 2013 with a friend. It was a low season so there was no tour bus to take you there, we had to arrange for a private van. It turned out that 2 of us were the only guests there that Thursday night (it did get busier on the next day, over the weekend). We had the resort and the full service to ourselves! The service was good, the food was good although a little pricey. However, what we loved most about the resort was the view from the resort! Located close to the top of the mountain, you could have a breathtaking view of the surrounding from a short few minutes walk. The air was cool and clean, slightly foggy before sunset that made the view even more romantic. If you have an appreciation for nature, the view here could bring some tears to your eyes! The resort is well kept but nature is still preserved, you can still find natural forest if you stroll for a walk. I absolutely love it!

Title: An excellent 2.5 hotel in Tam Dao
Review: Everything the hotel served during my family stay was perfect. I'd like to return again, and again in the coming time. Location is just 200m from the town market. Tam Dao is a small town, and no worry you don't need walking far to find interesting attractions. This is my ideal hotel because you can walk to Silver waterfall in 10 minutes, and to the town swimming pool in 10 minutes, too. How lovely the town swimming pool was ! It was nice located beside the stream. To me, it marks the downtown instead of the town market. My room is on the 6th floor with a very good view. You can see the flying clouds and fog beside the room window. Breakfast is NOT included in the room price (like other hotels in Tam Dao), but surely you can order this and pay this extra upon checking-in. Ask the help from hotel receptionists. It's a simple breakfast, but hot and tasty noodle. Staff speaks English rather bad, but I didn't mind. This hotel can reach 3-star in service because it's a modern hotel and very good service.

Title: A huge disappointment - definitely do not recommend staying here
Review: The hotel is only 4yrs old but in a terrible state. There has been water leakage in our room (818) so there was mould in the TV cabinet. We could not get hot water with the shower. The towels were threadbare. The carpet was filthy that I thought I would pick something up! The only 2 positives I have is that the bed was comfortable and the staff were extremely helpful and friendly. My Tho itself is a provincial township - it is interesting to walk around and get a feel of the lifestyle of people, however, it is not really a place I would recommend going out of your way for. The river cruise and island visits are so touristy to make them somewhat embarrassing. It does not give you any insight whatsoever into life itself - only into what is offered for tourists. If you have unlimited time - spending a few days just blending in with the life here would be good - otherwise I would skip this - there is so much to see in Vietnam.

Title: Could be Better
Review: Mekong My Tho Hotel Review No 1A, Táº¿t Máº­u ThÃ¢n Street, Ward 4 Má»¹ Tho City, Tien Giang, Vietnam Tel: +84 0733 88 7777 Dates of Stay: 02-14-17 to 02-23-17 and 03-19-17 to 03-23-17 (two different stays) Room:  Location: My Tho is located about 70 kilometers south, southwest of Sai Gon (HCM). The 70 kilometer trip from Ho Chi Minh City takes about 75 minutes via the expressway. My Tho town sits on the banks of the Song Tien Giang (Tien River), the northern branch of two river branches, the other being the Hau Giang (Hau River) the lower branch of the Mekong that splits up by the Cambodian border before reaching the sea. The hotel is about a 100 meters from the river. Why Come Here? But for aging relatives that still live in My Tho Town, my Vietnamese wife and I would have little reason to visit My Tho year after year. Yes, there are a lot of the one or two-night delta tours that come and go through My Tho, but that in itself is not why I would stay here. My Tho Town (pop. about 225,000) has a port not far from the MeKong Hotel, where seven to 10-day Mekong River cruise ships dock, embark and disembark passengers going either up river or down (from Siem Reap or Phnom Penh). IMO, the bulk of all one, two and three-day tours are poor. However, some say they enjoyed them. We have stayed in most of the larger hotels in town and one in nearby Ben Tre. This will be our seventh different stay at a hotel in this area, most of which are less than average in my opinion. The Mekong My Tho hotel labels itself as a 4-Star hotel but Iâ€™d say thatâ€™s stretching it a fair bit. This hotel is definitely the best of all the hotels we have stayed at in My Tho. In Viet Nam I always say hotels give themselves at least one more star than theyâ€™re worth. Yes, it has a pool, elevators, tennis court, exercise room and more, but it has some short-comings discussed below. Checking In Our driver picked us up near Ben Thanh market in HCM and delivered us to My Tho in around 75 minutes via the Expressway. We had a large Toyota Land Cruiser and the cost for the trip was 700,000 dong or about $31 USD at the time of this review. Uber also will drive you down here for about the same price in their Economy Uber, which most likely will be smaller than a Toyota Land Cruiser. Official check-in time is 2 PM but we arrived at noon and it wasnâ€™t a problem. We handed over our passports, which were copied and returned to us immediately. We handed over a copy of our Agoda booking voucher (not sure if required), and we were handed two electronic keycards for our room with two breakfast vouchers good for the entire stay. The whole process took less than five minutes. Elevators The eight or nine hotel floors are served by a bank of three elevators. Access to guest floors require a card key. There are two sets of buttons to access floors, one for guests that can see and another for those who are sight disabled (the first configuration Iâ€™ve seen). The elevator buttons for the blind have raise braille by each floor button. It was not clear to me how a blind person could use his card key to activate access to a guest floor. Iâ€™m sure there is an explanation. There are also many wheel chair ramps around the hotel. The Room When the hotel first opened about two years ago, I believe the double deluxe room was over $100/night with no breakfast. This town cannot justify charging that much for a room, even a more up-to-date room. There are a good number of mediocre hotels in town charging less than $20/night, all offering something to eat in the morning along with a clean bed and hot shower. The Minh Kieu comes to mind. Last year, I walked off the street and offered the hotel $60/night for a weekâ€™s stay (no breakfast) but they would not budge on the higher rate. Times change I guess. When I was getting ready to book a hotel in My Tho this year, I noticed the double deluxe rooms at the Mekong Hotel being offered at a much more reasonable rate with breakfast ($46/night including service charges and tax). I think the price is fair, all things considered. In the room, the queen size bed was nothing like your typical Vietnamese slab of concrete. It was semi-soft and provided good support. It had immaculate sheets, comforter, and four large and soft pillows. The linens still looked new. One morning I was lazy and stayed in the room to read. I allowed housekeeping to do their daily room cleaning, and they were in and out in a matter of minutes. An army of four people entered the room, all with different assigned tasks, and were finished in no time. Exiting the warm elevators on the sixth floor, we entered the floor hallway, which was very warm, even hot and humid. However, the roomâ€™s air-con worked well. We had to turn the thermostat up to a higher temperature in the evening because the room was too cold. The only closet in the room was a double-door, floor to ceiling affair about 4â€™ wide by 8â€™ high. It had sufficient shelving and an area for hanging clothes supplied with five hangers. Later, my wife asked for another 10 hangers and it wasnâ€™t a problem. The standard in-room safe was located on a lower, desk cabinet shelf and was not attached to anything. So instead of breaking into the safe immediately, a thief could just take the entire safe and work on it later at his leisure at another location. While the bathroom was tiled floor to ceiling The bedroom and closet areas were carpeted. While the carpeting might have been less expensive than good quality tile initially, it doesnâ€™t last long in a SEA environment. Our room carpet, which was probably less than two years old already had a couple small stains and what appeared to be a cigarette burn hole covered with the roomâ€™s sitting chair ottoman. The entire carpet will be a mess in three or four years. The small refrigerator was inadequate for the purpose of keeping snack foods or beverages really cold. Our first refrigerator was DOA (dead on arrival), so another was brought in. We complained that the second refrigerator didnâ€™t cool beverages and we were told â€œtheyâ€™re all like that.â€ Other guests I spoke to said the in-room refrigerator didnâ€™t work as well. I suspect it was one of those energy-saving jobs. Yes, saves energy but doesnâ€™t get cold. It also didnâ€™t contain a small freezer shelf to make ice cubes, so it was probably never designed to get very cold in the first place. The hotel also included a hot water kettle and a couple tea bags and glasses for making hot tea. At the end of our second stay, my wife boiled some water for making a glass of tea. When the kettle stopped percolating she poured some hot water in the glass with the teabag and a small crack developed on the bottom of the cup. The hotel said we had to pay for a new glass, which we refused. They supplied two glasses, tea and a kettle to boil water. What were we to use to make the tea if not the glasses the hotel provided? The front-desk manager remained silent. Then he said; â€œitâ€™s the rule.â€ I asked him where the rule was written that we pay for the hotelâ€™s stupidity but he could not provide a source or document. In the end, our room was paid for but not whatever they were going to charge for a new glass. Two separate stays totaling 10 days over five weeks and this is how guests get treated. Bathroom The bathroom is tiled floor to ceiling. I agree with other reviews (not on this site) that the bath hot water is not hot. Water will not be hot in the morning and not much better in the afternoon, so bathe or shower in the early evening, when the water might be a couple degrees warmer but it will not be hot. This hotel, like many others in SEA, have solar hot water tanks on the roof. When the temperature drops at night, so does the temperature of the water in the tanks. A clean room, bedding and plenty of hot water are the most important things to me when booking a room. On one occasion, I wasted quite a bit of water, letting it run to see if the water would ever become hot. After five to seven minutes, it grew appreciably warmer. This made bathing more tolerable but still not hot. It seems that most Vietnamese hotel bathrooms, except for the very, very best hotels, are susceptible to water leaking or draining on the floor, either from the sink, toilet, bidet, bath or shower. Thatâ€™s why they slope the floor and install a drain in every bathroom during construction. I noticed a trail of water from our bidet or toilet to the drain about five feet away. The bath tub was quite large, even for a person of 6â€™3â€. There was a shower head handle installed on the surface of the bath tub, which might be fine for some. Ours didnâ€™t work, so we called the front desk. A guy came up and flushed sand out of the line. Personally, I like to stand under a shower head. With a hand shower head one generally has to hold the unit with one hand while washing with the other hand. I suppose you could â€œsoap upâ€ with two hands and later rinse with one. As I approach 70, I am keenly aware of my physical shortcomings. Getting out of a tub is a challenge for me at 70, especially without handrails or grabs of some sort. Iâ€™m constantly aware of falling, and thatâ€™s one reason why I prefer showers, so I can stand to bathe, exit and dry safely. There was a duplex electrical outlet next to the sink, but I am not sure if it could accommodate an electric shaver because it had no markings. My electric shaver works with 120/220v, both 50/60 cycles, so no worries there. I generally charge mine before leaving home, and the charge will last for almost the entire trip. Bath amenities included two razor kits, two toothbrush kits, two combs, shower cap, cotton buds, sewing kit, soap, shampoos, conditioners, and bath gels, are more supplies than one will generally use. I should also mention there was an electric hair dryer in the drawer of the nightstand next to the bed. There were two hand towels, one medium towel and two bath towels, all with the hotelâ€™s named raised in the towel knitting, probably to discourage theft. They appeared new and in excellent condition. There were no odors coming from any of the bathroom drains that I could detect. Bathroom odors were a very common problem in Vietnam but now seem to be on the decline with more and more new construction. When using the pool during our first stay in February, we got our towels from the front desk. By the time of our second visit in March, they decided they had to be delivered to you at the pool area. Either way, it worked. Minibar The room was supplied with 2 - 355 ml bottles of Aquafina water daily. There were no other beverages or snacks in the room. The room refrigerator contained two 500 ml of Aquafina water each 15,000d if you consumed. A bottle of branded water on the street is one-third that. The refrigerator did not get cold. Internet and Cable TV The internet at this hotel works but without a VPN I would not use it for anything but casual browsing. The internet at this hotel is wide open (no password required). Internet throughput and speed was not good. In fact, it was abysmal. It could not load Speedtest on the first attempt, and it would time out. The bandwidth tests I preformed, most during prime time resulted in fairly poor results of less than 3 Mb/s. The stream to the LED TV was also pretty bad. Quite frequently, the screen would freeze or otherwise display terrible pixilation. There must have been a couple hundred channels, mostly Vietnamese. Oddly enough, I found many popular U.S. channels, like HBO and Cinemax being broadcast with Vietnamese over English, making viewing unusable for English only speaking hotel guests. There were a couple Australian channels being broadcast in English. There was no channel card listing in the room, so one had to step slowly through each channel to see instant content. I settled on a couple good football games being broadcast in English. Top Floor The top floor (the floor above the 8th floor) is divided in to indoor and outdoor sections. I guessed its main purpose is to serve as an entertainment and lounge area. The few times I went up there was to relax, read and take in the expanse of the northern tributary of the Mekong. The top floor lounge area offered lunches ranging from steamed rice at 10,000d, bowls of soup for 20,000d to stir fry dishes of squid, pork, or chicken generally from 60,000d to 80,000d. The lunch menu is served at both lunch and dinner hours with no price changes. One early evening, I had ordered the Seafood Hai San, mixed shrimp, squid, mushrooms, vegetables, sprouts for 70,000d. The presentation was great and food was quite good. It was even better than a similar dish I had at a local eatery up the street for the same price. Earlier in the day, I saw an expat family of five eating lunch off the same menu. After they had eaten I asked them how they liked it. They also agreed the food was good and had obviously ordered more dishes for their group. Generally speaking, I would opt to eat at a place outside the hotel, where there are many locals dining. One day I went up to the top floor and ordered a cold beer off the menu and noticed the price was 25,000d a can. A day earlier, I had ordered the same beer for 23,000d, another day it was 24,000d. Now really, 1,000d - 2,000d is hardly worth mentioning but some menus have prices lower than others. So consistency gets negative marks. Go figure. Pool For many years, I had hoped a hotel of this caliber would be built with a nice pool. I am guessing the pool is about 30â€™ X 70â€™ in breath and width. At the shallow end the water is about 3â€™ deep and a little over 5â€™ at the deep end. It has a raised circular spa that is about 12â€™ across and a couple feet deep. There were 10 jacuzzi style water jets. The water seemed to be the same temperature as the pool. Connected to the main pool and separated by a wall under the waterline was a 2â€™ splash pool for children. The pool and the area surrounding the pool is not without problems. First, there is a massive deck around the pool but there is little shade for guests to sit under. There are only two umbrellas with two loungers under each and hardly enough covered loungers for potentially dozens of bathers. There were many wicker tables and chairs but they were all in the sun. The ultraviolet radiation is terrible in these parts, and the wicker chairs, tables, and loungers were all starting to break apart from UV exposure eating up the plastic vinyl wicker. Once in the refreshing pool water, I noticed a lot of black algae growing in the seams of tile mosaics below water level. Having owned a pool for many years, I learned that black algae is a condition that exists on surfaces and in water that is not maintained with a proper pH level (chemical balance level). I suspect this pool is NOT properly maintained with proper levels of chlorination and use of an algaecide, nor is it brushed daily to further prevent the spread of algae and keep grout lines clean. This lovely pool will fall into disrepair if the problem is not address quickly and effectively. Breakfast Breakfast is served daily from 6:30 AM to 9 AM on the second floor. The dining area is a large room, seating perhaps 75 guests. There is also outdoor seating under umbrella tables. Tables were spacious and placed well apart from each other in a very clean and shiny tiled dining room. The first few days we took breakfast a little after 8 AM. Even though there were only a few people eating, we notice many of the food trays were depleted or empty. The next morning we arrived around 7:30 AM and the place was bedlam, which may have been an aberration caused by the hotel hosting a seminar or some other event. The local event, if that what is was, left little food for guests actually staying at the hotel. However, we noted that food trays and chaffers did not get refilled much after 8:00 AM everyday during our stay. For our second visit of four days in March, there were fewer people than in February. One morning at breakfast, my wife and I were a two of five diners between 8:15 AM and 9 AM. This is not nearly a 4-star hotel in my opinion. Here is a list of foods and beverages that were being served during both stays: Egg Station - Boiled, Fried, Scrambled, and Omelettes Pho - Noodle soup Bacon Sausages (more like American hot dogs cut on a bias) Plain congee Pork congee Steamed dumplings (previously frozen) Spaghetti Stir-fried Vermicelli noodles with vegetables Fried rice Bo Kho - Beef stew Banh Cuon Nong - Stuffed, flat noodle rolls Ham roll - sliced Lettuce Grape tomatoes Cucumber slices Watermelon slices Pineapple slices Jack fruit Dragon fruit Bread rolls - circular and smaller cigar-shaped rolls but not the big baguettes typically available on the street Dry chocolate looking cereal in a dispenser (for kids?) Tiramisu (saw only one time in over a week) Flan (served most days) Longan/Lotus berry dessert (saw only one time in over a week) Fresh Watermelon juice Fresh Pineapple juice Orange juice highly diluted with water Purified water Ice Tea Milk for coffee Coffee Tea Butter Jam Honey for sweetening if you didnâ€™t prefer refined sugar Donâ€™t except to see all the foods served daily. More than half of the above items were served on different days. However, wee left breakfast every morning satisfied with what was served. We met some vegetarians while staying at the hotel, and they had a hard time finding enough food to eat in the morning that met their dietary needs. We also invited two other friends over to the hotel for breakfast, and we paid 100,000d each for their breakfast. Positives: Good size room Good room air-conditioning Comfortable mattress with clean sheets, comforter, and soft pillows A reasonable number of electrical outlets to charge gadgets. We had two outlets each on both sides of our queen bed above the nightstand, and there was one other wall mounted wall outlet behind the cushioned chair. Learn where they are Negatives: Lack of really good hot water in the bathroom. Use at your own risk No dead bolt or swing lock on the room door Management bickering over a 35-cent glass they supplied for making hot coffee or tea, which cracked but did not break when we filled it with hot water Summary: 3 marks and 4 if they fix all of the above problems and not hassle customers over a 35-cent glass that cracked due to the hotel management stupidity. Title: INDULGENT ISLAND LODGE - MY THO
Review: We recently stayed at The island Lodge with our friends as part of our joint celebratory holiday - oh we were so pleased we did! Title: a welcome restful place
Review: we stayed at Island Lodge half way through our 3 week trip. It was the perfect place to unwind and relax for a few days. Our river view room looked out over the Mekong and sitting on the balcony with a glass of wine watching the boats sail by was delightful. The staff are a joy. So friendly, nothing is too much trouble. The fact that there is no traffic you can only get there by a golf buggy type vehicle makes sure it is peaceful and quiet. Title: Absolute gem only 2 hours from Saigon airport
Review: We just spent 3 fantastic nights at this hotel, relaxing, exploring the island, and eating fresh, delicious food. Can't rate this highly enough, and it's easily accessible from Saigon and the airport. Having said that, we were a bit disappointed as we passed over the huge bridge to Thoi Son island. In my mind, we were heading to a rural idyll, and I didn't see how the island could be rural when it has a motorway passing through one end of it! But 10kms later, after driving through the fruit trees down the one road suitable for cars, we arrived at the Lodge. And the setting is beautiful and quiet, surrounded by lanes through the fruit plantations and houses, and with a view of the ever-changing Mekong. Everybody we interacted with at the Lodge was friendly and helpful, and service was always with a smile. Some of the staff didn't have great English, but there was always someone around who did. The staff make the place, and we were really charmed by them! A special thank you to Giao, one of the waitresses, who remembered our orders from previous days and was always kind and friendly. The Lodge itself is wonderfully designed, with a huge open communal area which is subtly divided into bar and dining areas. The whole place is beautifully furnished and oozes style - I would like to transplant everything from the bar area into my house! We loved that there were so many different seating areas around the grounds, including a couple of pagodas, sofas, riverfront tables and a table right out on the pier for watching the sunset. The pool is warm, long, and spotlessly clean, with plenty of loungers and huge fresh towels. Bedrooms are clean and comfortable, and as stylish as the downstairs area. There were so many other places to sit and enjoy the view that we didn't really use the balcony, but it is a relaxing place to be. The food was unexpectedly good. There is a French and a Vietnamese menu, and food is fresh and well presented. They bake their own bread and croissants on site, and the smell of it in the morning and before dinner was a treat. It's an odd thing to recommend when you're in Vietnam, but the quiche lorraine was one of the most delicious things we ate on the whole trip! It's on the starter menu, but is big enough and rich enough to enjoy for lunch with some of the fresh bread. We also enjoyed the duck, and the tuna. And breakfasts were sublime, with everything made to order. There is a comprehensive wine list, and we also appreciated the fact that the house wine was very reasonably priced and very drinkable - thanks Michel! The Lodge offers tours, which we didn't do, but instead we took bikes out on two afternoons and explored the lanes and bridges of the island on our own. It's hard to believe that the big city of My Tho is only a few kms away when you're cycling around under the shade of the trees, over bridges that are 2 feet wide. At the very far end of the island, as far as the road goes, we stopped and had a drink at Mr Thanh's little waterfront bar and chatted to him about tourism on the island. He was an interesting man with superb English, and his wife makes a delicious cold lemon juice on a hot day. The only negatives: At a Lodge with eco credentials, I would have liked to see drinking water available as refills, rather than endless 500ml plastic bottles. And just be aware that the Mekong view is of a busy waterway full of commercial and industrial traffic, with industrial buildings across the water. In actual fact we really enjoyed watching the traffic and the change of the tides so this wasn't a problem at all, but we hadn't realised it wasn't looking out on to countryside. Thanks to all the staff at the Island Lodge. This really is a gem, and we were so pleased that we stayed for 3 nights rather than rushing through.

Title: Relax in luxury, get insights into life on the Mekong
Review: The view from the bedroom terrace, swimming pool and restaurant is fascinating, watching all manner of river traffic passing by, and ideal for boat trips on the Mekong river. The staff were very welcoming, friendly and helpful, and booked trips and transfers for us. The restaurant food was really excellent for both lunch and dinner - both the Vietnamese and French menus offered good choice and portions were good, although the wine is very expensive (typically Â£25-40 per bottle, although a Â£18-20 one was fine). Breakfast is 'unlimited', with hot and cold choices, coffee, juices etc. plenty of fresh fruit and breads. The room was large and comfortable, with a good shower with plenty of space. The coffee machine was a pleasant touch, as was complementary water, and the terrace a great place to sit in the evening (mosquitos permitting). The pool is big enough for lengths, or just keeping cool. There are plenty of places in the gardens and restaurant/bar areas to sit and read quietly or for quiet conversation. The hotel is two hours' drive from Ho Chi Minh City airport (a bit less from the city centre). As we arrived late (10pm) we pre-ordered dinner and the restaurant was kept open for us. On the (slightly) downside: The bar/restaurant took last orders at 9.30pm and all the lights were generally off by 10pm, which took some getting used to. We tended to order a bottle of wine at the end of the meal and take it to our terrace. The hotel is fairly isolated, ie not particularly close to a village where you could walk or go for a meal as an alternative, although perhaps this could have been arranged if we'd asked. As we were there for just three days this didn't matter, but if you were here for longer you might want to get out more. The boat tours offered (with a guide) were good, although each stopping point involved people trying to sell local products, some at quite high prices. Overall though these were a good opportunity to see more of the delta. There were only three coat hangers in the room (though we could probably have asked for more) although plenty of shelf space for clothes and suitcases.

Cons: - Poor insulation: for both noise and air-con. Thin room wall, non-glass door and open bathroom ventilation mean you hear every single thing that happens right outside your room. Title: Superb!
Review: I stayed at the Island Lodge with my wife and two young kids as my first hotel upon arrival in Vietnam, with the idea of using its relaxing environment to acclimatise to the weather and time zone. It fulfilled this brief perfectly. We were picked up at the airport in HCMC and transferred to the hotel which was just under 2 hours drive away. On arrival at the hotel we were treated with a refreshing drink and delicious canapÃ©s while we checked in. Michel had previously suggested pre-ordering a meal as we arrived around 9pm after travelling all day. This was a great idea and was a lovely start to our 3 night stay at this hotel, and was our first insight as to the thoughtfulness, service and high quality that was typical at this hotel. The food here was consistently excellent (as to be expected from Michel and FranÃ§oise who hail from France's gastronomy capital - Lyon) and was a highlight of our stay. The wine selection was also excellent and on reflection was great value for Vietnam. Breakfast was a treat to look forward to every morning, with the Eggs Benedict a particular favourite. Also, I was delighted to find that good european style coffee is served! The hotel itself is beautiful, and decorated with an Indochine theme. We stayed in a River View room, which was lovely with a nice comfortable balcony to sit on and watch the activity on the river, however the garden rooms also looked very nice and I would have been happy in either room type (FYI river room views are on first floor and so persons with mobility issues may prefer garden view room). The staff at the hotel are excellent - friendly, attentive and obviously well trained and professional in their service. The overall highly positive experience of our stay here allowed us to relax, get over our jet lag and energise us for a great holiday in Vietnam. The only negative about staying here as our first hotel in Vietnam is that we found ourselves comparing all subsequent hotel stays against this one, and they all fell short! For a stay in the Mekong Delta area I would absolutely recommend that you don't look any further than The Island Lodge.

Title: Delightful respite
Review: We totally enjoyed our overnight in Mekong Delta at The Island Lodge. We arrived mid-afternoon, about the hottest time of day but felt cool and relaxed as soon as we stepped off our boat. The staff was professional and very helpful in dealing with a passport/visa issue. The room was very clean, well layed out and the decor was ever so tasteful. We were able to make last-minute arrangements for spa treatments in spite of the late time of our arrival. The grounds are well-kept and provided a delightful area to meander and relax. Our dinner orders were taken upon arrival which, while unusual, did allow us to make a special request for extra small portions as we have small appetites. We were especially happy to be presented the requested small portions of each dish and were delighted by the wonderful meal. A special mention to the chef! While English is not spoken fluently by everyone on staff, that only added to the charm as we recognize we speak only five words of Vietnamese. Communicating is part of the adventure of traveling. We enjoyed a short conversation with the owners who, it is clear, love what they have created and seem to want to ensure their guests have the best experience. The only thing I found a bit less-than-perfect is the volume of the A/C unit. Normally I do not like to sleep with the A/C on but the temperatures made that impossible. Each room has its own unit which is loud enough that we were not able to enjoy the normal night sounds through the screened openings which, during our visit, consisted of thunder and socializing geckos. I definitely recommend this property if you have the opportunity to stay in the Mekong Delta.

Title: Fantastic, but I have several nitpicky
Review: Amazing place. Very clean, comfortable, and beautiful. Excellent staff is so many ways. The owners are always and asking how things are. The breakfast was fantastic. The food I had from the Vietnamese menu was great, the French food I ordered I did not particularly enjoy. Instead of listing all the good, I do want to write about a few of the negatives/suggestions for improvement, as I think the lodge can easily take another step to be even better -the pool. The lodge has a ton of staff standing around during the midday when everyone is at the pool. They need to dedicate someone to (1) come around to take drink orders at the pool, (2) clean up used dishes around the pool area, and (3) remove used towels on pool chairs and replace them with new ones. In my several hours at the pool, I did not see anyone come around to take drink orders (which would have made owners more money) or cleanup used dishes others had left out, and despite a limited number of pool chairs, abandoned chairs with used towels were not cleaned up so someone else could come use the chair. This is a pretty simple fix that would greatly enhance the lodge. Similarly, sitting in the bar area, no one will come take your drink order, you need to go directly to the bar to do so -the room. It would be nice to have a clothes line to hang wet bathing suits on. The bathroom is amazing, but you cannot fill the bathtub. There simply isn't enough water pressure. Obviously not something that can be fixed, but it was disappointing considering how beautiful the tubs are -dinner. I love the dining room. As a humorous point, the tables were too short for me to fit my legs under, which was awkward. But more seriously, I'm not sure why the drink/wine menu isn't offered with dinner. Instead I drank beer which was on the menu. The full drink menu needs to be brought out with the dinner menus, I definitely would have spent more money on wine had it been -there was music playing all day from a neighboring area. Not sure if this was normal or just part of Tet. With how often the owners came by to say hi, it would have been nice for them to have acknowledged the situation and given an idea of when the music would stop (it stopped around 10pm). Obviously they can't stop the music, so not a problem of theirs, but just ignoring the problem is no solution -everything up to here as been nitpicky, and a suggestion for improvement. This is a FANTASTIC lodge. But this comment is my one serious negative point. I booked a Mekong Tour, and my tour guide spoke no English. Not a single word. This was entirely obnoxious and should not happen, or I should at least be told this before hand. If possible, I would have paid extra for a guide that spoke English, or seen if I could have paid a staff member to join us and interpret. But again. This is a great place! Definitely stay here. I just hope the owners are interested in feedback, because this place can be even more incredible than it already is

Title: True Exotic
Review: Visited late September 2015 I truly felt that I was at an exotic destination right out of a 1920's film (and actually the destination is exotic). The common area has an amazing floor plan that opens to a pool right on one of the Nine Dragon sections of the Mekong River. I would start my day (after breakfast) by riding a bike through the local villages, and then taking a boat (about $0.68 usd) across the river and into the main town of My Tho. A nice ride along the riverfront where I would then have a mint soda to cool down while watching the world go by. On other days I would ride the length of the island enjoying the little villages along the way. This is the area where I purchased my conical hat! The island is easily reached by bridge. From the bus (Can Tho to HCMC route) take a taxi the remainder of the way (about $6.80 usd). The road from the bridge is nicely paved, and has virtually no traffic. It is about 6 km from the bridge, and there will be a concrete trail from the road to the resort (about a 3 min walk). I feel a sense of relaxation by just reminiscing about my time at The Island Lodge. This was one of my highlights during my month in Vietnam!

Title: One of the nicest hotels we have ever stayed in
Review: We (my wife, 7y/o daughter and I) stayed at the Island Lodge for 3 nights, and it was absolutely fantastic. The hotel is owned by a French couple, who greet you personally and also always enquire if everything is ok during your stay. This as well as all the small details really make the difference of this kind of owner operated boutique hotel to international hotel chains. The whole hotel is a blend of neo French colonial style with South East Asian elements. There are so many small design details which really make the hotel a special place. The staff is also very friendly and again great attention is paid to detail, like always being welcomed with a cold towel and a glass of water after returning from an excursion. Not all staff speak good English, but please remember that this is Vietnam. This also means that one has to relax there and not expect to have a breakfast served and eaten in 10 minutes. There are many things to do there to wind down: relax in the infinity pool overlooking the Mekong river, nap in the deck chairs, have a massage treatment. Also, there is a nice programme of different excursions where one can explore the Mekong river and nearby attractions. These excursions are very individual and are also great for children. The only small room for improvement that I would see is in the Vietnamese food menu. Here a little more diversity would be good. What I don't understand is why this hotel only has an official 3star rating. In my opinion it is definitely worth more. The price value relationship for this hotel and what you get there are excellent. To sum it up, if you want to stay in the Mekong delta away from the tourist masses, relax in style, explore the sights and not get poor doing so, the Island Lodge is the place to choose.

We had a very pleasant afternoon boat tour round Unicorn Island before settling down on the terrasse with an ice cold beer to watch the evening light on the river and the boats of every size and shape. Swimming early in the morning in the large 24 m pool with the Mekong just a few metres away was surreal.

Title: After a Year, Only Average
Review: Cuu Long Hotel, My Tho 81-83 30/4 Street, Ward 1 My Tho, Tien Giang, Viet Nam Tel: +84 (0273) 6 266 666 Email: Date of Stay: 03/05/19 to 03/10/19 Location When searching for this hotel on TA, is appears as a â€œSpecialty Hotelâ€, when the type of hotel is really no different than any other hotel in My Tho. It should be moved to the general hotel listings so people can find it more easily. The hotel is just over a year old. We stayed here last year, just after soft opening, and I reviewed it then. So how does it fare after one year? Have there been any changes for the good or bad? The hotel is one of the newest in the few that are located around this area. It sits across the street from the Tiá»n River, the northern branch of the Mekong River. There are many river-facing rooms on the upper floors offering excellent views of the river and life along the river. There is also a park across from the hotel, where night vendors setup their rolling trinket and food carts, selling all sorts of tasty treats. From Sai Gon, it takes about 90 minutes to get here and 700,000d-800,000d (give or take) in private car, more if you want a 5-7 passenger van. We booked a Double Room with Balcony, including breakfast for two, facing the river through an online agent for 4,275,000d for five nights (about $184.26), including all taxes and service fees. This is a fair rate, all things considered. As a reference point, you can buy the room online with or without breakfast. If you buy the room without breakfast, it will cost 75,000d per person or 150,000d ($6.46) for a couple after the fact. While this hotel doesnâ€™t have a pool (few do in this area), I still consider it the best for the money for what you get. We make a pilgrimage to My Tho annually, and we have stayed at various hotels here, including the Chuong Duong, Minh Quan, Minh Kieu, Song Tien, Tien Giang, and Mekong My Tho. Another reason for staying a night or two in My Tho is that most of the upstream and downstream, 7-day, Mekong River cruises start or end here. Iâ€™m talking about those luxury river boats that travel between Viet Nam and Siem Reap, Cambodia. So with an extra day or two going or coming, you could also incorporate a more intense day excursion into the delta mangroves, etc. I probably would do the stop on a downstream cruise but not up. Arrival Check-in was not smooth. Front desk staff spoke even less English than we encountered last year. So much of the conversation had to be in Vietnamese, which my wife speaks fluently, as she was born in this town. We immediately had a disagreement over the type of room we had booked and the room they were going to give us. I blame part of this on booking company. The description of the room I booked was, amongst other things, was a "River View" room. Whose definition of "River View"? The hotel wanted to give us a room facing a side street with a partial river view. This was not the same room I booked last year at a lower rate. We argued back-and-forth. I wouldnâ€™t relent and they wouldnâ€™t either. I pulled out my computer, got their WiFi password and logged in to the online booking companyâ€™s site, where I found the same size room (albeit with two double beds instead of one queen) for $2 a night less with a river view. At this point, I had them. It was difficult for them to argue. Thereâ€™s a lesson here, like really bring along the booking confirmation that provides detailed information about the view, which booking companies and hotels always seem to exaggerate or omit. Do note, many booking confirmations do not include the view you purchased along with the room. Beware of tricky room descriptions like Superior beach view and Premium beach view. What does that mean? Many of what I classify as small hoteliers in this country still donâ€™t get it when it comes to customer service and customer satisfaction. Many talk about it but relatively few provide it in my opinion. They really donâ€™t seem to care about you. No thanks for coming back to stay with them, even for a week-long stay. Absolutely no recognition. This seems so typical in this country. At least the big, big chains thank you for coming back because they track that information, and a thanks for coming back to stay with us cost absolutely nothing, zero, no money! Cuu Long, My Tho seemed to care less that we had returned again this year. If fact, the entire front-desk staff, including their new manager, were all hired after we left the hotel last year. This hotel keeps your passport at check in. For some this is an irritant, while others donâ€™t care. By now, most have just made a copy of your mug shot page and hand it back to you. I supposed some smaller hotels are afraid some clients might leave and skip the bill. Our booking was prepaid but we are familiar with the drill. Just donâ€™t check-out of the hotel without your passport! The Room Last year, we stayed in a room one floor above the one they assigned us, 504. The wife and I prefer showers to baths. So ask about the bath when you arrive or make sure it is detailed in the booking. Access to the room is via electronic key. We were given only one key. When we entered the room, it was quite warm. You need to place the electronic key in the slot by the door to activate lights, air-con, TV, and more. I supposed most hotels only want you to have one key is so you donâ€™t use a second key to keep the room cool when you go out. It makes economic sense but doesnâ€™t enhance the customerâ€™s experience while waiting 30 minutes for the room to cool down after being outside most of the day. Consider the room rate. Our room ended up being a Superior Twin of approximately 280 sq ft. It seemed about that size. Part of the space was consumed by a relatively small but and clean bathroom (alas, I didnâ€™t initially see the ants on the sink vanity). On the right, as you entered the room was a large bench for luggage, a tall armoire containing a half dozen clothes hangers a cabinet containing a mini-frig, two mugs, two coffee cups, two spoons, two complimentary bottles of water, two tea bags, two instant coffee packets, and a water cooker. There was also a chargeable cup of noodles and a can of chips. There was a box of tissues on the adjoining table with a tall upright chair. Like last year, the room did not have a safe. Next, there was a flat screen on the wall with a nest of two smaller tables below. Toward the back of the room another table and chair, mirror, table lamp, and hair dryer. The furniture in the room was of average quality and still looking fairly new after a year. The room contained two double beds, both with typical, hard mattresses, my least favorite. It would really be nice if the hotel had a few rooms with thicker and softer mattresses for those unaccustomed to really hard beds. There was only one small pillow on each bed. I asked for and received an extra pillow. There were three places in the room with duplex outlets where I could charge gadgets, including a small nightstand between the two beds.Other amenities in the bedroom included flip-flops. (I find wearing flip-flops that somebody else has worn kind of disgusting.) During this visit, I noticed the mini-frig contained a fewer number of beverages for sale.Outside the room, facing the river, there was a balcony that paralleled the width of the room and offered views of the river and street below. Entry to the balcony was through a sliding door. Almost the entire width of the wall facing the river was windowed and covered with sliding drapes. The Bath We chose a bathroom with a glass enclosed shower and no tub. It was on the small side, containing about 60 square feet. The metal hose shower handle could be used to move the shower manually or just inserted in the wall but it sprayed the water high, perhaps over six feet. The head end of the hand shower exploded on our last morning just as I finished my shower. There were several towels and enough for a couple. The towels were of average wear. Amenities included a small container of bath gel and one of shampoo, a sewing kit, earbuds, two plastic combs, two toothbrushes, a plastic razor, and a small, circular bar of soap. There were also a couple toothbrushes, combs, a razor. My complaints to management were ignored last year as there were no shelves (metal or otherwise) built into the shower walls to hold shampoos and soaps while you were showering. You either did your best to hold the soap while rinsing or just dropped it on the shower floor. Same with shampoo bottles. Outside on the mirrored vanity, we saw ants crawling around all week but they never seemed to leave this area and enter the sleeping area. Coffee Shop The 8th Floor (top of hotel) opened since we were last here. It seems to be operated by an outside company called Viva Star Coffee. Itâ€™s a spacious place, offering wide vistas of the Mekong River. There is no outside balcony as everything is enclosed by walls or glass windows. In contrast to the two-story windows of the ground floor lobby area, the windows on the eighth floor were quite dirty and did not appear to have been cleaned in quite a while. What can you get here? First, there is no food here, at least there was none offered in the menu provided. The menu is made up entirely of specialty coffees, traditional coffees, Frappuccinos, smoothies, ice coffees, Italian sodas, and teas, most priced around the 30-35,000d and some up to 50,000d. There was no alcohol in the menus but if you asked, you could get Tiger or Heineken beers in 300 ml cans starting at 30,000d. That was it. On my first day back since we last visited, I decided to visit the coffee shop for a beer. Once ordered it was quickly delivered. After that, nobody came by my table to check to see if I wanted another beer, the bill or something else. Staff were all chatting up by the coffee bar, more interested in other things rather than assisting customers. This is also pretty typical in Viet Nam unless you are staying at a much higher level of hotel. Even then, itâ€™s no guarantee you will get good service. Oh yes, they will offer you peanuts with your beer but be aware they will at another 30,000d to your tab for a very small dish of these nuts. In many places they would be complimentary with the drink. Breakfast Buffet breakfast started at 06:30 and was included in our room rate. Here is a list of most of the foods we encountered: Há»§ Tiáº¿u Má»¹ Tho BÃºn riÃªu (vermicelli noodle soup w/pork) Vietnamese beef stewFried eggs or omeletBÃ¡nh cuá»‘n cÃ  Fried seafood balls (bland) Fried noodles Curry shrimp Fried rice Steamed yams Baguette slices Bread slices Jam Peanut butter Watermelon slices Guava slices Small Mandarin orange slices Bananas (small variety) Green apples (small variety) Salad of lettuce, onion, tomatoes Vinaigrette dressing Rice congee (plain) Salted egg Sausages (really hot dog slices) Purified water Orange juice (boxed) Coffee Condensed milk for coffee Soy milk Tea (cold and hot) West Lake soup Congee Like most breakfast buffets, many foods were on rotation and not served daily. Oddities at the buffet included the lack of butter, while there was jam and peanut butter but no dairy butter or margarine. There was only one choice of juice, orange juice that comes in big boxes and poured into a container. For juice, one was expected to use the tiny coffee cups. I asked for and received a proper glass, actually a mug, for the juice. In a country where there is so much tropical fruit, it is hard to believe that fresh squeeze juices were not readily available here. Like last year, there was still no dry cereals that children generally eat with milk or soy milk. The best time to take breakfast is before 7:15 am. By 7:30 am, there seemed to be many people coming down for breakfast and the only juice they offered was no longer available and nobody was replenishing it for guests that still continued to arrive. Breakfast would not be over for almost 90 minutes. Again, pretty bad customer service. Internet and Media There were a large number of WiFi appliances installed throughout the hotel, which made it fairly easy to connect to the hotel's open Internet (no SSID password) . Because the hotel had few guests the observed bandwidth was fairly predictable and even throughout our stay of five nights. The best ping time experienced was 190 ms. All tests were performed with my VPN with the proxy located in Hong Kong. 3/6/19 19.05 Mbps down and 9.44 Mbps up at 11:15 am 3/7/19 27.26 Mbps down and 6.29 Mbps up at 13:30 pm 3/8/19 30.02 Mbps down and 6.09 Mbps up at 11:22 am Last year, the rooms did not have TV channel cards. At the time, the General Manager said they were being printed. As of this review, there are still no channel cards for the room. If you want to search channels offering English, youâ€™ll need to scan hundreds of channels to find them. Iâ€™ve made a shortlist of channels below broadcasting in English. The vast majority of broadcasting was in Vietnamese. I also found several Chinese, French, and Indian channels. Higher numbered channels appear to be HD quality. The channels broadcasting in English included these: CH 28 Blue Ant Extreme CH 29 Chelsea TV (Football) CH 30 BOX Movies CH 31 FOXlife CH 32 Planet Earth CH 34 FOX MOVIES CH 52 KIX CH 66 f (FTV) CH 72 National Geographic CH 781 VTC (movies) CH 788 FOX Sports CH 855 Planet Earth HD CH 856 National Geographic HD CH 857 Hollywood Classics HD CH 858 FOX MOVIES HD CH 859 KIX HD CH 860 Blue Ant Extreme HD CH 861 BOX Movies HD CH 862 FOXlife HD Also, when using the Internet in Southeast Asia, I always recommend using a VPN. The network at this hotel is open, so it will probably be pretty easy for someone with a bit of skill to hack your computer. Summary It seems the Cuu Long was less enthusiastic about receiving guests this year. The manager we knew from last year had quit. The hotel still offers value but donâ€™t expect great customer service. Rooms are still under $40 a night including breakfast but there are even cheaper lodgings in this neighborhood, including a hotel right next door. It all depends what you are looking for and care about the most.

Title: Lovely stay!
Review: We had a great couple of nights at Happy Farm! The hosts were kind and helpful. They helped us arrange a private car to and from HCMC, as well as a whirlwind day tour of the area (including a visit to a rambutan farm!). We ate both dinners there and the food was delicious and plentiful. The rooms were basic but comfortable. The outdoor bathrooms were fun - clean, modern plumbing and the cold showers were welcome given the heat. We were worried about sleeping in the heat (having only stayed in air conditioned places during our previous two weeks of travel) but we were comfortable under our bug nets with the fans on us. Between the fans and the cicadas we had plenty of white noise and our three kids slept soundly. Happily recommend as a great escape from the busy big city.

Title: Perfecte homestay voor dierenliefhebbers
Review: Leuke homestay om te verblijven, vooral als je van dieren houdt. We hebben hier twee nachten geslapen. Er waren heel veel kleine katjes en dat was erg leuk. We mochten ze zelfs melk geven. Ze hebben paarden, ganzen, eenden, kippen, katjes en honden. De tuin is heel groen. Je hoort geen verkeer hier, maar wel dieren :-) De kamers zijn een beetje primitief. Je slaapt in hutten met rieten daken. Er is geen airconditioning maar er zijn wel ventilators. Geen warm water, wel lauw. De eigenaren zijn heel aardig en behulpzaam. Je zit wel beetje in de middle of nowhere. We hebben vanaf deze homestay een tour gemaakt met een boot in de Mekong Delta en een chocoladefabriek bezocht. Je kan bij deze homestay ook blijven eten. Dat is wel handig omdat er weinig restaurants in de buurt zijn.

Title: Average Hotel
Review: Minh Kieu Hotel Review Period of Stay: 02-23-16 to 02-28-16 Address: Sá»‘ 2 Thá»§ Khoa HuÃ¢n, PhÆ°á»ng 1, tp. Má»¹ Tho, Tiá»n Giang, VietnamPhone: 073 626 2288 (in country) GPS Coordinates: Lat: 10Â° 21.371â€™, Long: 106Â° 21.721â€™ This is a review of the hotel and room  a Double Room We make an obligatory trip to My Tho annually to celebrate New Years with older extended family. We were last in My Tho town almost a year ago, when we stayed at the Tien Giang Hotel. In previous years, we have also stayed at the Song Tien, Minh Quan and Chuong Duong Hotels. Unfortunately, My Tho isnâ€™t full of great hotels in my opinion. There is a new 4-star hotel in town but it doesnâ€™t command the over $100/night prices for a room in a small delta town. The Minh Kieu is probably the best hotel in My Tho weâ€™ve encountered to date. Like many other hotels in Viet Nam, this one is also dimly lighted. As you enter the hotel, you may get the feeling it might be closed or there is a power outage. Common areas and reception appear almost morgue-like. Common areas on the first floor and hallways above need new carpeting or new tiles floors. The worn, torn, stale, old red carpets need to go. As Tet was over, there were plenty of vacant rooms at the Minh Kieu. We chose the least expensive room facing the street on the third floor, a Double Room. The rate was 500,000d per night including breakfast and taxes. That worked out to $22.31 (USD). (Pictures of rooms on most web sites are taken with very wide angle lenses giving one the impression the room is much larger than it is in reality.) Read the number of square feet or meters of the room you are buying to calculate what the true size of the room might be. 20 sq. meters or less for a room is pretty tight when you consider it probably includes the bathroom. The information is typically available on sites like agoda.com under â€˜room infoâ€™. I think the room we chose was around 25 sq. meters. Room So room  is on the third floor. However, it was actually four floors off street level. The reception area and the area used to serve morning breakfast is up one flight of concrete steps up from street level. Our room contained a few pieces of the standard wooden furniture, probably popular almost 100 years ago, including one small night table, two wooden chairs, a small coffee table, a small dressing table with mirror, a cabinet with a refrigerator inside stocked with canned beverages and a lockable armoire with keys. An LED flat-screen TV sat on top of the cabinet that contained the refrigerator. The refrigerator was stocked with a few beverages and on the lowest setting before it would be turned off. I move it up to the next to highest setting to cool some of my own beverages brought in from the outside. There was a thick build up of ice in the small freezer containing a small ice tray. Here were some of the prices of drinks for cans in the refrigerator: Half liter bottle water - 10,000d (none in refrigerator) 1.5 liter bottle water - 20,000d (none in refrigerator) 333 beer can - 20,000d Heineken can - 30,000d Pepsi, 7-Up, Twister cans - 15,000d Red Bull can - 20,000d The two cans of 333 beer in refrigerator had brew dates that were eight months old and certainly not fresh. I found it odd the hotel does not supply two free bottles of water a day per room but there were none even to be purchased from the refrigerator. The room was cheap but a small, decent bottle of water should cost the hotel no more than 3,000d or 13 cents! The included WiFi was pretty decent at this hotel with consistent 20 Mbps down and up speeds, the best encountered in My Tho to date. Internet speeds can vary if you donâ€™t connect to the right wireless AP in the hallway. Try several and run speedtest.net . Ideally, the one on your floor will offer the best speeds. The room description and features listed on agoda.com for the date of stay were accurate. Bathroom The bathroom is pretty standard for this type of hotel and quite small (see photos). This room only had a shower, which was fine with us. As an added bonus, it had a rain shower head in addition to the hand unit. The bathroom had a standard flush toilet with a bidet hose. Two medium and two large bath towels for two people a day. Amenities included a small tube of shampoo and bath gel, a plastic comb, two toothbrushes, and cheap earbuds. There was also a wall-attached two cup holder for two glasses in the bathroom and one was empty. But most important, the bathroom was spotlessly clean and did not stink. Inclusive Breakfast The room rate included a basic breakfast in the morning. The included breakfast consisted of one entrÃ©e from the breakfast menu, like baguette and fried eggs or noodle soup and one drink. Hereâ€™s a sampling of the breakfast items with prices if you wanted more than one or extras: 1-Há»§ tiáº¿u Má»¹ Tho (rice noodle soup, My Tho style), or 2-Banh Canh Suon Heo (noodles with pork rib), or 3-BÃ¡nh canh sÆ°á»n heo (stir fried noodles with beef), or 4-MÃ¬ gÃ³i xÃ o náº¥u bÃ²/trung (instant noodles with beef/eggs), or 5-BÃ¡nh mÃ¬ á»‘p la (fried eggs with bread), or 6-BÃ¡nh mÃ¬ cÃ¡ mÃ²i (bread with sardines) If you wanted more than one of the above, the extra was priced at 25,000-30,000d. And, one of the following from the beverage list: 1-Black coffee with cream or sugar (Vietnamese style coffee with condensed milk), or 2-Lemonade (something like a soda chanh but without the soda), or 3-Tea (Lipton tea bag and hot water), or 4-Soy milk Alternatively, there was an excellent CÆ¡m táº¥m place across the street (Quan Com Nam Trieu). For 15,000d or about 67 cents, one can get a take away styrofoam box filled with rice, pork, shredded carrot, cucumber, daikon radish and small packet of fish sauce on the side. Itâ€™s not a buffet, if that whatâ€™s you are looking for, but a basic meal to get your day started. Positives: 1-Clean bed linen 2-Clean bathroom and adequate towels 3-Plenty of hot water for bathing 4-Bath amenities including toothbrushes, plastic comb, shampoo, bath gel, very small soap bar, earbuds 5-Adequate LG air-conditioner 6-Hot water cooker, teapot, and small cups 7-Clean, smooth tile floors (no dirty, stained carpets) 8-No sewage smell coming up through bath floor drains 9-Fairly decent room lighting (LED) 10-Cable TV had dozens of local channels (Vietnamese) and selection of western channels including: 25-FOX Sports HD 26-FOX 2 Sports HD 27-HBO (Vietnamese speech over subdued English - irritating) 28-Starworld 29-Discovery 30-CINEMAX 31-Movies HD 32-Cartoon Network (Vietnamese speech over subdued English) 36-VTV 49-AXN HD 62-HTV 7 69-National Geographic 74-Animal Planet 75-MTV 76-f Limited channels in French Negatives: 1-Standard rooms are pretty small but adequate for a few overnight stays (get the triple room if there is more than two of you) 2-Armoire type closet with lockable door but did not function properly 3-No room safe 4-Hotel staff would not provide a second key in the event one person was out and the other was in but sleeping 5-Free bottles of drinking water not offered and none for sale in refrigerator (but liters bottles on the street and bring back to the hotel) 6-Little English spoken here but you can probably get by asking questions during daytime reception desk hours, when somebody get the idea of what youâ€™re asking for Summary Of all the hotels Iâ€™ve stayed at in My Tho, this one has been the best so far. It deserves a solid three stars on average and a fourth star for value. Yes, the common areas and hallways have that crappy, dark red, stained, worn out carpet, but thatâ€™s trivial to the value proposition. For me, a room needs to have a clean bed with clean sheets. Ideally the room will have tiled floors. (I hate rooms with tired, dirty, moldy, stained carpets!) The bathroom needs to be spotless or as clean as possible. Drains should not stink. It needs to deliver adequate hot water day or night and a minimum of two towels per person per day (one medium and one large per person). A working and reliable internet service is also a must but I stress reliable. This hotel provided all that. If you need something better, the new MeKong My Tho Hotel is waiting for you just around the corner. Itâ€™s nice, itâ€™s new, it has a pool. Rooms start at around $115/night with taxes and service. This room, as I said earlier, offered a lot for less than $25/night, net, net. It is probably the best of the five hotels weâ€™ve stayed at thus far. Itâ€™s a solid 3-star hotel for this area, and I would stay here again if only based on value for money. As I always say, unless you have some compelling reason to stay in this town, move on to Sai Gon for the evening.

Title: If you stay in My Tho this is a good option.
Review: What other reviews say about the Song Tien Annex is accurate in terms of the noise and such but if you stay in My Tho you can expect to have significant noise regardless of where you stay. What I will say is that the service here was outstanding. I stayed at this hotel for almost 2 weeks and became ill for a few days during my stay. The hotel staff brought me soup and checked in on me. The security guard made sure I was ok when I was finally able to venture out for coffee. They greeted me everyday with a smile and the staff spoke very good English. There is a nice balcony you can sit and watch the Mekong river traffic. No, it is not a 5 star hotel but if you find yourself in My Tho it is a clean, safe hotel and appeared to be the better option of the 2 Song Tien hotels.

Title: Good location, great rooms
Review: The hotel is centrally located close to the central area where you can catch a boat tour to the floating markets. Rooms are spacious and very comfortable.
