Title: A very happy and comfortable 11 day stay
Review: I was traveling with a group and we all had a lovely stay. The guestrooms are simple but I loved the hardwood floors vs. carpeting. The rooms were bright and happy. The bed linens were clean but old. The bathroom was a bit challenging; a lovely claw foot tub with a broken foot and no shower curtain and the bathroom door did not fully close. Toilet paper is scarce, and it is advised against putting it in the toilet. It seemed as though were were at the front desk every morning for another roll! and the front desk staff was always lovely and accommodating. The air conditioning worked well. We never turned on the TV but the wifi worked very well. We did have a few little crawly visitors in the bathroom (not a huge deal) and some tiny geckos every once in a while. All of these things could be overlooked as the staff was very pleasant. We ate breakfast as a group each morning on the 6th floor rooptop with lovely views of the river and the city. The breakfasts were hearty and delicious and the coffee was good. We also had some dinners at the hotel and they were very good. The hotels overlooks the river which is quite dirty but just seeing the water and the lovely buildings made us happy. The location was great. We could walk to the market, get delicious street food at any time of day and walk to other sights. I took a cab from the hotel to the Catholic Church for Sunday mass and the cab fare was .79 (yes, under $1.00 USD). There is a lovely man who can be found in the hotel area who will give city tours or take you anywhere in his rickshaw. So much fun! He has been in the city for 40 years and can give a wonderful tour. All in all - we loved the hotel.

Title: I will stay again
Review: This is a great budget hotel. The staff are great and helpful. They don't have safes in the rooms so you can leave valuables for short periods at the front desk (like a laptop) if you're going out of the hotel. We stayed in the Superior Double Room and it was huge. For the price charged a very real bargain. Standard were the bed (nice mattress though), tv, and standard furniture. Also was a desk and chairs, two bedside tables, plenty of working plugs for recharging the phones and laptop, new and clean bar fridge. Most surprising was the bathroom. Huge by vietnamese standards. Tiled throughout. Western styled, marble style counter and counter top. Water efficient toilet. New faucets and fixtures, clean throughout, hotel supplied shampoos, toothbrush, and other items in Song Tien red and white boxes. Laminate floors throughout the room. The only negative comment I have is the front door. The frame and deadbolts are obviously damaged from attempts by people to break in. The entrance to the room is on the 5th floor, the access to the 5th floor is through the lobby so security must be lacking sometimes. They have a complimentary breakfast at the Song Tien Restaurant. It is a great breakfast.

Review: I have stayed at the Cong Doan on each of my eight trips to Vietnam and, unlike almost every other hotel, the staff was incredibly friendly, helpful, knowledgeable, honest and trustworthy. I am lucky enough to have made several very good friends there and My Tho is my favorite vacation spot for life. It is not the newest or cleanest hotel in My Tho, though it is the cheapest option if privacy and security are your priorities. Other hotels in the area have fancy rooms but come with a premium and less trustworthy staff. Most of the Cong Doan's employees have spent many years working there and petty theft is non existent, which was a problem almost everywhere I stayed in Vietnam. If you are passing through My Tho and want a safe and friendly place to stay, the Cong Doan is your very best choice.

Title: Going Downhill
Review: Song Tien Review - 02-16-13 Period of Stay: 02-07-13 to 02-14-13 This is a review of the hotel and Room  My wife and I have stayed at this hotel several times during the last three years, as we visit My Tho town once year to see and visit with relatives. We have previously stayed at the Chuong Duong and Minh Quan. The hotel was renovated a few years ago, and we were anxiously waiting for a hotel offering a better standard of room and service. Sadly, the service and state of the rooms has declined since our first stay. Our room facing the SÃ´ng Báº£o Äá»‹nh (Báº£o Äá»‹nh River) was large (estimated at 25 sq. meters excluding large bath). River facing rooms have a small balcony that is not very functional, as morning sun is hot, and if the air-conditioner is running it will be very uncomfortable being out on the balcony. Unfortunately, the balcony flooring was constructed at the same grade as the room so monsoonal rains have drenched the carpet in the room, seeping in from under the door that separates the room from the exterior balcony. The aluminum framed door leading to the balcony had no ridge on the floor to make a water barrier, so there has been significant water damage to the carpet, including what I suspect is mold. Other parts of the carpets have been stained and not properly maintained since renovation. A better, albeit more expensive choice would have been to tile the entire room. Because we were staying in town for a week, we requested more wire clothes hangers, and a couple additional pillows for our double bed, which was reasonably comfortable and free of bugs. Our room, and I suspect most others, had no soft or hard-backed chairs. You either lay in bed to watch TV or sit on an 18â€ four-legged stool (two in our room). We had to ask twice for the extra two pillows and one decent sitting chair. After a second request, we received two extra pillows but no comfortable sitting chair. A relative delivered a decent chaise lounge chair to our room. Upon arrival, the small beverage refrigerator in the room was turned off. I opened the door and there was water in a tray that had melted from the small bin used to make ice cubes. The refrigerator contained two small bottles of water that are not included in the daily rate. On arrival, I wanted to store my laptop computer in the safe while we were out and noticed there was no way to lock it. The safe is an odd affair that apparently uses a key along with a push-button lock but there was no key and no instructions of how to activate the box. We called downstairs and were given a number of excuses of why nothing could be done about it, that we should simply leave our valuables at the front desk, where little English is apparently is spoken or conveniently not understood. I enlisted my Vietnamese speaking wife to express our concerns and she received the same uncaring response. That lack of room security perhaps speaks to KhanhHSâ€™s concerns and post of 2-24-12. The next day, I cornered the hotel manager, who gave me his last two keys to the safe along with a simple instruction to key a six sequence of six numbers to close it, and then I could reset to my own set of numbers. This didnâ€™t work and there no further assistance provided to rectify the problem with the room safe. I reverted to using my Pac-Safe backpack, probably a better solution in the first place. I have to plug Pac-Safe here because they make a pretty decent alternative for hotel rooms that do not have safes or functional ones. PM me if you need more info. The attitude of staff toward the visitor speaks to krapperâ€™s post of 7-9-12. On our last morning at the hotel, some family drove down from Thá»§ Dá»©c and had breakfast with us. After we were finished, our guests went back to our room, while I waited for the check. The bill was much higher than expected. I asked my wife to query them in Vietnamese to understand why we were being charged nearly double the posted prices for food. Their only explanation was something related to the New Year, even though the posted prices were almost less than half. You have to remember that my wife and I have stayed at this hotel no less than four, perhaps five times. This is the attitude and treatment repeat customers receive? The river-facing rooms are the most expensive, offered at 500,000d/night including breakfast ($24/night at this writing) if you book in advance. I spoke to one backpacker on a bike that paid 500,000d but did not get breakfast included. Other rooms on the floor without windows are offered at about $4-$5/night less. I suspect they may also be smaller buy may not have the carpet â€˜moldâ€˜ issue. One should make sure breakfast is or is not included in the rate. The included breakfast consists of one item combination from a list of about 10 items, for example rice noodle soup with a cup of coffee. Thatâ€™s it. If you want a baguette and fried eggs, that will be extra. If you want juice and coffee, you will pay for one or the other. Granted, the extras by western standards are inexpensive. For example, my wife and I each chose a bowl of noodle soup and coffee as our included breakfast meal and then each ordered a baguette and two fried eggs for an extra dollar each. Positives: Large room, albeit balcony rooms probably have more carpet mold than non-river facing rooms Fairly large, clean bathroom with small claw foot tub, wash basin and toilet Typical amenities including two tooth brushes, plastic comb, shaving razor, shower cap, shampoo, bath foam, although we didnâ€™t get the last two items replaced twice during our stay. Apparent, clean bedding (no bug bites and no observed critters in our room during our stay) Good air-conditioner Cable TV Good hot water Free wifi that was strong in room 601 and on the top floor adjacent, dining area (Internet speedtest from this hotel here:  ) Negatives: Dubious and pretentious service, especially for minor requests Over-charging Room upkeep Black, moldy carpets (wear flip-flops or sandals in the room) Security, antiquated keyed door locks and no working in-room safe Poor lighting in bathroom Had the service related to the room safe been addressed, I would give the hotel a 4-star rating for this city. In addition, if the rooms had at least one or two sitting chairs and clean carpets, I would have given it a 5-star rating. Unfortunately, the property deserves no more than a 2-star rating due to staff attitude, over-charging in the hotel restaurant, room security and moldy carpets (a potential health hazard). Hotel service and security are the overriding issues here, which speak to the issues previously posted for this hotel. If there is no compelling reason to stay in My Tho town (my extended relatives live here), I would consider staying at the Ham Luong Hotel in Ben Tre, the adjacent city. The Ham Luong has a swimming pool, which no other hotel in My Tho has to my knowledge. Check out the Tripadvisor reviews before booking. Alternatively, if moldy carpets, and lack of room security are not an issue for you, stay here by all means. Richard

Title: Good hotel in best location in My Tho
Review: We were 2 nights in this hotel. On arrival we got the twin room which is big as described 'Superior Twin', however it does not have any window so we asked for another room with window. We got the room 606 on the 6th floor, but it is not a twin room, it is a room with a double bed. We went straight to bed but due to the noisy airconditioning unit we could not sleep. We complained and then we got another room, a double bedroom next to the lift on the 5th floor with a little river view on the corner of our tiny window. The rooms are relative big and clean, the bed is more like a king-sized bed and not a small double bed. Our room is next to the lift, but fortunately the lift is very quite so we were quite happy with the third bedroom. For breakfast you get a voucher which you present to the cafe next door on the first floor. The choice of breakfast is quite limited, but you can choose the one breakfast you prefer: from noodle soup to bread & jam, etc... The location of the hotel is the best in My Tho as you can walk only 2 minutes to the central market and you can also walk along the Mekong river for sightseeing. This hotel has also a restaurant and a cafe next door. For the scale between 1 and 10 points I can give this hotel 8 points for its location, its good-sized bedrooms, services, etc... Unfortunately I cannot give 9 or 10 points for this hotel due to the lacking of a computer for free internet connection and also due to the smoking policy of the hotel (smell of cigarette smoking in the hotel). Sightseeing/Attractions Tip: The location of this hotel is perfect for the visit of My Tho: Go to the market, take boat trips to the islands, sightseeing along the Mekong river, Enjoy the noodle soup 'Hu-Tieu My-Tho' which is special noodle soup of this town MyTho... By the way, don't forget the food 'Ca Tai Tuong' (in English: Elephant Ear Fish) and 'keo dua' (Coconut sweet bonbon) and 'ruou dua' (coconut wine).

Title: Great hotel with great prices
Review: We went to Song Tien Hotel to look for a cheaper alternative to another hotel along 30/4 street, and thank god for that. We stayed in a double-bed room for 350 000 dong for a night, which included breakfast for both of us. The rooms were luxurious-looking, and they offered a full suite of conveniences, such as a hot water boiler, coffee cups, sanitised glasses, toothbrushes, combs, etc. The beds were large and comfortable, similar to those you can find in a 3 or 4 star hotel (depends on which country you're in). The bathroom was big and clean, with a bathtub set in one side. There were even bathrobes in the wardrobe. There is a great view of the river from the corridor and the cafe at level 6, where breakfast and other drinks are served. Breakfast is either a decent bowl of noodles (with some small prawns) or the usual baguette. 350 000 was an excellent price for a hotel of such standard, and I'll recommend it to anyone spending the night in My Tho. However, the hotel brochure available at reception stated its prices to be 30USD and 40USD for the 2 types of rooms they have. If I'm not mistaken, they're having a soft opening, so be sure to grab hold of it while its still available. According to a private tour operator by the river who speaks excellent english, the hotel was recently renovated and reopened.

It appeared to is though it hadn't been washed since it's previous usage. Later in the day I found a very large cockroach clinging to my lonely planet guide which I managed to squash (not sure how it got in, but probably not the hotels fault, just saying the facts) The young guy on reception didn't speak a word of English so had to use a translator App on his phone when we asked for a map (which they couldn't provide) and for our passports back. The location is poor - it's at least a 25min walk to the town centre, and the eateries near by are very local, and don't have English menus. The aircon didn't work very well, but there was a wall mounted fan. We didn't have a good night sleep, partly due to the bed but also because there were loads of big kids running around the hotel screaming and banging doors. My girlfriend twice got up to ask them to keep the noise down but to no avail. I ended up banging on their door at 1am and that seemed to work. I understand that this issue was out of the hotels control, but it still made an impact on our stay. We would have told the hotel of our negative experience before reviewing them, but we weren't asked, and no one that was present spoke any English! Would not recommend!

Title: Pleasent stay!
Review: Tai Phat hotel is perfectly located in the middle of the centre. A two minute walk to Bui Vien street, for cheap food/drinks on the street. Clubs are around as well, but way more expensive. Rooms are fine, toilet and shower in your own room and air condition + fan in the room. Personnel is really friendly, not everyone speaks fluently English though. Been to this place twice in the same month, both good experiences!

Title: Another Poor Hotel
Review: Tien Giang Hotel Review - 02-17-15 Period of Stay: 02-07-15 to 02-16-15 Address: 6C, Rach Cam, 1 Ward, My Tho, My Tho GPS Coordinates: Lat: 10Â° 21' 15.4506", Long: 106Â° 21' 50.493" This is a review of the hotel and room  We have been visiting relatives that live in My Tho annually for many years. Things change slowly here. The hotels in My Tho are not really up to better hotels in Sai Gon and Ha Noi for the same price. Every year we visit, we try a different hotel but we never come away satisfied. This time was no different. We stayed at the Tien Giang Hotel, and it was one of the worse. Previously, we had stayed at the Song Tien, Chuong Duong, and Minh Quan. Like other hotels in My Tho, this one was not well maintained. I also believe itâ€™s a government hotel, which speaks volumes about the lackadaisical and indifferent staff. As one enters the dimly lit lobby, you get the feeling it might be closed or there is a power outage. Electricity is expensive everywhere in the world, but apparently this place seems to think it doesnâ€™t exist. Upon arrival, the front desk confirmed our booking but suggested the room was small and maybe we would like a larger one in a batter position inside the hotel for $9 more a night. We had originally booked a standard room on Agoda ($27), as they only advertised a standard room or a triple (one double and one single bed). The standard room was small, very small. The walls needed painting and the carpet drastically needed replacement. It was depressing. So I was shown the triple, albeit we didnâ€™t need the extra single bed. (Pictures of rooms on most websites are taken with very wide angle lenses giving one the impression the room is much larger than it is in reality. Read the number of square feet or meters of the room you are buying to calculate what the true size of the room might be. 20 sq. meters or less for a room is pretty tight when you consider it probably includes the bathroom. The triple room, even with the extra space taken up by the single bed, looked larger and more airy. There was more light, probably due to the larger front window facing Hung Vuong Street. Because we were staying in town for 10 days, I chose the larger room -  Frankly, at this point I would have considered looking elsewhere in town for a decent room but the hotel was pre-booked on Agoda (no refund) and this is one of the draw backs of pre-booking a room. Room So room  was obviously on the third floor. It had an expansive view directly up Hung Vuong Street. However, like the first room we were shown, the walls required paint and the carpet was dirty and stained. Like the dimly lit lobby below, this room also had poor lighting, possibly fed with the smallest wattage bulbs available. The room contained a couple pieces of the standard wooden furniture, probably popular almost 100 years ago, including a desk drawer with stool for a chair, a small dresser drawer on top of which sat the ancient, small tube fed TV. There were two upholstered chairs on either side of a small table. A nightstand separated the two beds. Against the wall was an armoire to hang oneâ€™s clothes. The armoire lock was broken. There was a key in it but it did not function. As there was no safe in the room, this armoire would be any last hope of locking up anything of value. We asked if somebody could come up and fix the lock. Shortly after, a guy came up, looked at it and played around a bit. After certifying that it was broken, he asked if we would like to make an official â€˜complaintâ€™. What!? No, I wanted the lock fixed! It wasnâ€™t going to happen. Also note the back-and-forth conversation was in Vietnamese. There are few English speaking workers in this hotel. The refrigerator was stocked with a few beverages and on the lowest setting. There were plenty of bottles of Aquafina drinking water but none were offered free with the room. I have stayed in many less expensive hotels in Viet Nam that included two free bottles of drinking water a day. How much is water - about 2,000d or 10 cents for a cheap brand? Our three person room had an expansive window that looked up the entire length of Hung Vuong Street, where preparations were being made for New Years. The one-foot ledge in front of the windows was cracked and weathered. It required maintenance and refurbishment years ago but again, nobody seems to care. On top of that, there was half smoke cigarette butt and a dead cockroach lying upside down on the ledge. Not a pleasant site. The included WiFi was pretty much useless in this room. We had to go out into the hallway floor to access the Internet. The wireless access points are installed at either end of the hallway and the range is poor. The circuit to the local ISP (a government ISP?) is extremely slow. I suspected something like ADSL or worse. The few times it seemed there was more bandwidth, a lot of websites appeared to be blocked. In retrospect, I believe the connections were just timing out due to low bandwidth. I tried changing DNS to no avail. The same experience was had in the hotelâ€™s common areas, like the Cafe or lobby. Again, we complained but they said no other room like ours was available for better reception. Bathroom The bathroom was pretty standard for this type of hotel. It had a tub and hand shower above which was an electric water heater that came on when the water was being used. I also presumed this water heater also fed the faucet at the sink, which would only drip water when turned to left (hot) position. Standard flush toilet. Two very thin, standard, bath towels for two people a day and three per day for three-bedded rooms. Amenities included small tube of shampoo, bath foam, comb, ear buds, and toothbrush. Inclusive Breakfast The included breakfast consisted of one item from the following: 1- Broken rice (Com Tam Suon), or 2- Hu Tieu My Tho (local favorite soup), or 3- Beef Pho (Vietnamese standard soup), or \ 3- Omelette (actually two fried eggs with a small baguette) and, one of the following from the beverage list: 1- Black coffee with cream or sugar (Vietnamese style coffee with condensed milk was an extra 3,000 dong), or 2- Lemonade (something like a soda chanh but without the soda), or 3- Tea (Lipton tea bag and hot water), or 4- Soy milk Not a buffet if that whatâ€™s you are looking for but a basic meal to get your day started. Positives: 1- Clean bed linen for our stay 2- Fairly clean bathroom 3- Typical bath amenities included tooth brushes, plastic combs, shampoo, bath foam, and a small box of ear buds 4- Clean bedding but foam mattress was fairly hard for someone seeking a little bit more softness 4- Good air-conditioner 5- Hot water cooker, teapot, and loose leaf tea for making hot tea in the morning 6- Cable TV had a couple dozen local channels (Vietnamese) and selection of western channels including HBO, two FOX Sports, HBO HD, Starworld, Discovery, CINEMAX, Star Movies, Cartoon Network, AXN HD, Chinese channels and more Vietnamese channels 7- Resident lizard in the room (I think some sort of Gecko) made short order of flying or crawling critters, an added plus Negatives: 1- Standard rooms pretty small but adequate for an overnight stay 2- Dirty, stained, and torn carpets on hallway flooring and coming out of the elevator 3- Dirty and stained carpets in hotel room (really needed replacement long ago) 4-Armoire type closet with lockable door did not function. Housekeeping unable to help with a broken lock and asked if we wanted to file a complaint 5- No room safe 6- Poor lighting in bedroom and bathroom 7- Bathroom sink did not dispense but only a dribble of hot water 8- No shower curtain in tub to prevent shower water from landing on bathroom tiled floor (fairly typical of 1 or 2-star hotels) 9- Slippery bathtub will pose danger for elderly people trying to exit the tub onto tile floor that might be wet 10- Hotel staff would not provide a second key in the event one person was out and the other was in but sleeping 11- Poorest WiFi connections of any previously visited hotel in the city. Unusable except for text email. Tried changing DNS IPâ€™s and more but nothing really could fix the poor Internet connection, especially in our room ( 12- Free bottles of water not offered 13- Little English spoken here. Best if somebody in your party speaks Vietnamese if you plan to stay at this place As I said last year, unless you have some compelling reason to stay in this town, move on to Sai Gon for the evening. (There is light at the end of the tunnel however. A new hotel that will be called â€˜The Mekongâ€™ will be opening allegedly in April 2015. Donâ€™t hold your breath. Title: Tussen de Vietnamezen in prima hotel
Review: Volgens ons is dit hotel 1 van de betere plekken om te verblijven in My Tho. Het ligt in het oude centrum en vlakbij de rivier waar bootjes verhuurd worden. Het hotel staat op veel grond. Toen wij aankwamen, werden er al heel veel terrasstoelen buiten gezet. Wij vermoedden dat er een grote groep toeristen zou komen. Later bleek dat om 17.00 heel veel plaatselijke bevolking komt om op het terras wat te drinken. Echt heel gezellig om te zien. Echt een paar honderd mensen. 's Avonds heb je daar overigens geen last van, want iedereen is vroeg weg. De kamers waren prima, bedden schoon, goede WIFI en badkamer oke. Wij hebben zelfs een lekker flesje (franse)wijn genomen op het terras van het hotel tegen een voor Vietnam goede prijs

Title: Best Centrally Located hotel in My Tho
Review: Back again after 2 years. Room rates are reasonable and all rooms have balcony with magnificent view of the river. Early morning starting from 5.30 am one can see intrepid swimmers frolicking in the Mekong River. They will swim till 7.30 am . Hence don't forget to wake up early to see this unique sight of My Tho. Do order Hu Tiu My Tho for breakfast. Hu Tiu My Tho is a Rice Noodle specialty of this town consisting of shrimps, pork, liver, squid and ribs. The hotel is also an embarkation point for boat cruise to the nearby island of Con Phung and Con Thoi Son. Both have fruit orchards and one can take photos with Python or feed the caged crocodiles with lumps of decaying meat. A trip worthwhile. Once again relatively this is the boondocks and hotel rooms standard cannot aspired to be that of Ho Chi Minh City.

Title: Acceptable, nice riverside location

Title: Chuong Duong Hotel Restaurant Attempts Rip Off
Review: So for our last night in My Tho, Vietnam, my wife and I decided to stroll along the river and find a place to eat outside. We ended up at the Chuong Duong hotel, where they have outside dining, which is great. My wife and I ordered three dishes to share. You have to understand the scheme here. When you order a dish, it may come in three sizes, prices adjusted for small, medium, and large dish. If you have never seen a medium or large dish, you will not know if you are being served the right size for the price you paid. So my Vietnamese wife ordered the smallest size for all three dishes (smart move wife). When the bill came, she notice that we had been charged a higher price for one of the dishes. There was no reasonable explanation since the server acknowledged we had ordered the smallest dishes. The insult came when we paid the bill after it was adjusted and the hotel short-changed us 50,000d for a 130,000d bill! Again, the bill went back to the front desk where it was â€œadjusted appropriatelyâ€. Even in this small town, you need to keep your guard up. If I ever come back to this town, I will never stay at the Chuong Duong or eat at either their inside or outside restaurants. These folks are out to rip you off! Avoid at all cost! Richard

Title: Basic
Review: We stayed here as part of a tour of the Mekong Delta. We were already told that it was a 2star and very basic so we didn't mind all the things about it. The room and bathroom was old but had a good aircon and a balcony looking over the water. The beds were hard which is fine with us as we prefer them. The bathroom was ok. Was old but had a separate shower compartment (which did overflow after each shower). The wifi was free but unfortunately it wasn't very good, kept cutting out. We slept fine as we were exhausted but light sleepers may find it hard as there were lots of families gathering at the restaurant underneath singing karaoke till late. In the morning you get a wake up from the boats starting up too! There also isnt a safe in the room so we took our valuables and padlocked all our luggage. Breakfast at the restaurant downstairs was good, had bread and noodle soup which was tasty.

Title: WHAT A VALUE !!!!!!!
Review: Stayed here twice in the month of October for a total of 2 weeks. Stayed in room 208 both times. Good size room with 2 twin beds,wifi,fridge and wonderful A/C. The wifi can be spotty at times but the value for the room is fantastic. Breakfast is included with the $22 a night price.Our room had a balcony facing the river also. Location is excellent. Many locals bring their families by the river so you really get the feel of small city Vietnam. Cafe Seo is close by for a coffee or a smoothie. The staff is very efficient and also friendly and always willing to help. I will stay here again!

Title: Inexpensive, clean hotel with good location
Review: On work-related trips to the Mekong Delta, I've stayed in Chuong Duong Hotel several times over the years. Somehow, our research partners would book us here. We just request a room on the right hand side of the second floor. That is to be away from the restaurant noise. The hotel is along the Tien Giang river, one of the two branches the Mekong river, which makes the view from the upstairs bedroom window and balcony quite scenic. The river is a major thoroughfare for both business and tourism. The $24/night room rate is for a large room with a queen-size bed, split-type aircon, TV, refrigerator, an electric kettle, tea set, a small coffee table with two heavy wooden chairs, and an ensuite bathroom. The floor has wall-to-wall carpeting and a balcony. It also comes with breakfast and wifi. I must warn that the wifi can be on and off at times. If you must send an important email or visit an important website, you can bring your laptop to the reception counter near the main router. For anyone going to Mytho, I would recommend this hotel any time. Despite its budget hotel rate, it is comfortable, clean, safe and has a good location.

Title: Friendly!
Review: The best two star hotel you can get! Fantastic staff! The staff here are so kind and patient, but also be patient with the staff because YOU ARE IN VIETNAM. The rooms are cool (considering every room has A/C), but the beds are stiff. Each room has up to two complimentary breakfast passes. The breakfast is delicious. Traditional vietnamese breakfast or just eggs if you prefer. This hotel has an INCREDIBLE location in My Tho. The hotel is located ON the Mekong River (the only hotel in My Tho that is on top of the water next to the park). And right next to the boat launches for tours. Also, this hotel has a coffee shop next to it as well (strawberry smoothies? YES!). Overall, this hotels only flaw is the stiff bed.

Title: super cheap,clean with good location
Review: A local friend of our booked the room for us so we didn't know what to expect. It was $20 USD per night- first bonus but it is situated right on the mekong river. My tho is not a big place and you don't have many choices but this was more than adequate. Boats on the mekong can get noisy at odd hours though. Ac rooms worked super well. Beds are rock hard mattresses but I actually like that. I was with my husband and they only had 2 twin beds. Not even sure if they have queen mattresses? Rooms are small and have a fridge with drinks. Didn't buy their drinks just bought some drinks at local stores and stocked up ourselves in the fridge. I asked about internet and the front desk guy said down the road. I see from another traveler there was wifi in the lobby. We didn't try so I can't confirm. We walked a block across the street and went to a cafe to use internet for 50c an hour. Breakfast is included in price at restaurant next door from a fixed menu. Eggs or pho and both good but the iced milk coffee was delicious although served a quarter of the glass. Just wait for the ice to melt then drink. Boat tour offices to the local islands right next door and lots of tour buses use. For the price--- this place is clean and comfortable. Bathroom a bit dated but completely functional. Ac and hot water. No pool or frills but good for a day or 2.

Title: Best in My Tho probably- I guess
Review: If you have the misfortune to be going to My Tho or are one of those intrepid adventure types then this is the place for you. The city itself offers very little in the way of attractions and is one of the staging posts for those souls going to visit the nearby industrial park or continuing on to further south in the delta. The Chuong Duong hotel is 400,000 per night from what i heard (we didn't pay). It is worth the money, really. Clean sheets that are tucked in with the professionalism of a hospital matron. Clean shower and toilet, soaps and toothbrushes. Plus! tea and an electric kettle - actually this is above what they need to provide in a 2 star. The view onto the Mekong is good, the hotel restaurant is filled with locals who come in - a very good sign. Free wifi, ice cold beers at good prices in the lobby. All in all, good value for the $20.

Title: Best spot in My Tho
Review: There is not much luxury in My Tho nor many hotels to chose from. This one is the biggest hotel in the best location. It also offers boat tours, souvenir shops, etc. The grounds of the hotel are quite expansive, well groomed, and beautiful. We took a lot of pictures there too. The hotel staff was excellent by Vietnamese standards. Laundry service was fast and CHEAP. The rooms are cheap to, around $20US per night and had air conditioning. The key and the fob to activate the air conditioner could be separated to leave the air on. The rooms were not huge but not too small as to be cramped. The bathroom and shower were small and nothing to get excited over but there was plenty of hot water and they refreshed the toiletries daily. There was a dresser and a huge closet to unpack our clothing. I don't think it had an in-room safe. The free breakfast is decent but choices are fairly limited. The restaurant opens to non-guests for lunch and dinner which is much better. Many local as well as tourists also ate there and it was usually busy which is a good sign. The dining room is river view and the front of the hotel also has outdoor tables for lunch and dinner. The outdoor dining is in a beautiful garden area. If you visit My Tho I would say this is your best bet.

Title: A mixed experience...
Review: "My Tho's most luxurious accomodation..." according to the Lonely Planet. I think this says more about the other accomodation on offer in My Tho than it does about the Chuong Duong as it certainly doesn't fall into the luxury category. That said, it does have some redeeming features. First, the not so good: The hotel is dated and in despearte need of some updating. Levels of cleanliness are somewhat suspect and the staff hardly friendly and welcoming. It turns out that this is mainly a business hotel and doesn't cater to that many tourists. In fact very few tourists stop in My Tho at all, preferring to visit in a day trip from HCMC or to continue on to Can Tho. However, the hotel is on the banks of the Mekong and all rooms have balconies and magnificent views over the river. Stunning. Also, although it doesn't look much the food served up in the restaurant is fantastic and very cheap. This is just as well as there aren't many other options within walking distance of the hotel. Dishes can be ordered small, medium or large but even the small portions are massive. Just watch out for the occasional rat or cockroach! Across the road from the hotel and down the the road to the right where the river bends is a really nice bar which has cocktails and live music with English menus (but no food).

Title: Used to be better

Title: Rang Dong 2
Review: Stayed here for a couple of nights as part of a motorbike tour round the Mekong Delta. We also encountered the travel agent offering the boat trip as below reviewers have. Overall, not a bad place for a cheap stay, but you will probably want to keep your stay short.

Title: Nice rooms, difficult staff
Review: We stayed here for two nights as part of a family trip to Vietnam in January this year. We were attending a wedding in Bien Hoa so the location was perfect for us. The rooms are small but nice, comfortable and air conditioned. The bathroom was spacious although the lighting was terrible. We stayed on the eleventh floor and unfortunately as non smokers our room was on a smoking level. The hallways were clouded with cigarette smoke which also made it under our door and into our room. When we arrived the staff requested a $2000USD deposit and they would give back whatever we didn't spend- this didn't go down well! We had five adults and a child in our group in three rooms so this request for such a large amount was completely unreasonable. Luckily my cousins wife is Vietnamese and managed to get us out of this ridiculous situation. They instead kept our passports until we left, despite already taking copies. Be careful with money here, they won't take "old" US notes (whatever they are) and VN Dong that has a slight tear or rip. It will also take them about 10 minutes to break a noted for change after it swaps hands several times to be checked by 'accounting'. Don't get me wrong, the staff are very polite but some of the systems in this hotel make simple things very difficult (check in, payment etc). Breakfast was nice, a good mix of Western and Asian food. We came back to Bien Hoa at the end of our trip to again visit family but we stayed at another hotel.

Title: The only one worth staying at in Bien Hoa

Title: A Lucky Stopover with a Beautiful Family
Review: We stopped at the Lu Khach Quan Homestay by chance while riding our motor bike from Hanoi to Saigon as it was getting dark and we were not going to make it into the city for the night. We learned about his familly, his culture, his religion, his incredible volunteer work, and various other topics. When we arrived he had just returned from a trip where he delivered pigs, chickens, and cows to poor families so that they can begin to earn money for themselves. We enjoyed our time with Sang so much that we asked him to meet us in Saigon to hang out. If you are heading north from Saigon, it would be well worth your time to stop into Lu Khach Quan for a few nights. You will see such a beautiful side of Vietnamese culture and family life.

Title: Another face of Vietnam
Review: If you have the opportunity to spend 2 days out of Saigon, I really recommand Sang's place. You won't probably never find Bien Hoa in the tourist books as it is commonly said there is nothing to do there. This is true, you might be disappointed if you start comparing Bien Hoa with Halong Bay. Actually, what you can find in this town and at Sang's place is dramatically different. First, Bien Hoa has a long christian history and has dozens of churches. As a result, its atmosphere is different from the rest of Vietnam. Second, Bien Hoa surroundinds include lovely sightseeing places - such as waterfalls or forest - easy to reach by motorbike. Personnally, I spent 1 nice day fishing on a lake with Sang. Third, about Sang and his family, as I stayed 3 days with them, I can just say they are lovely hosts and strive for making you feel like home. Actually, Sang's home is more a homestay than a guesthouse as you litterally live with the familly (share the food, discussions...). The place is clean, spatious and well equipped (with AC). Finally, Sang's home is a particuliar business as it is generosity-based (it means there is not rate for the rooms). This completely reflects the Sang's family mentality. So, hope you will enjoy.

Title: Lu Khach Quan: A Vietnamese Highlight

Title: Hidden treasure just outside of Saigon
Review: We'd heard about this place from other travelers, and decided to take the 1h bus from Saigon to Bien Hoa. I can't say enough good things about sang, his hostel and his family they showed me (and my friend) the true Vietnamese experience and i can't wait to go back and visit my new found family.

Title: Fantastic Hotel
Review: Wow, my experience at the Diamond has been amazing. Coming from Australia to stay close to my sister in laws family I wasn't quite sure what to expect, but I couldn't have asked for more. I have stayed here for 5 days and the service has been above and beyond the whole time. The rooms are simple but clean and very comfortable. The air conditioning, the TV, fridge and bathroom facilities work perfectly. The pool is crystal clear and the whole resort is maintained beautifully. A couple of the staff speak English and those who don't respond really well to google translate. There is a security guard on the grounds all the time, though I can't imagine he has too much to do other than watching over people's vehicles, crime is low in Vietnam and people are generous and kind. If you want an everyday urban experience outside Saigon then you need to come here. 10 minutes from Bien Hoa and 30 to 45 minutes from HCMC you are close enough to tourist areas but far enough away to not see another Westerner for days. The Diamond Resort is well worth the stay and I recommend it highly.

Title: Peaceful setting but ...
Review: Lovely little hotel set in the middle of Giang Dien park, the main attraction being the waterfalls (not massive, but pretty enough in the middle of this totally landscaped park). It's only an hour from HCMC so there is no need to stay over, but when it's not a public holiday, it's a lovely place to escape and get some peace as it's really quiet and night. However it's very basic, rooms aren't cleaned daily and the restaurant for breakfast is a 5 min walk and they have only three choices. We came last year, and this year the hotel is a year shabbier ... Certainly overpriced compared other accommodation in Vietnam.

Title: Not excatly crowded
Review: I was the only guest during my stay at the Tulip Hotel and so was given the VIP room which seemed like some 1970s relic provided for the visiting overlords. I paid 350,000 dong per night for a huge room with fridge, double bed, cable tv with a tiny tv and a large bathroom with a bath and shower. The staff spoke no English so communication was certainly an issue but as I had no complaints this wasn't an issue once I'd checked in. There is little nearby and it was a bit of a challenge finding things to eat but it did give an insight into normal day-to-day Vietnamese life.

Title: Basic hotel
Review: We've stayed at this hotel several times, mainly because it's very close for visiting family and friends, and partly because the city of Bien Hoa lacks choice where hotel accommodation is concerned. There is no lift but there are only two floors and the stairs are very wide and shallow. The rooms are large, very clean, but fairly basic; the beds are very comfortable with beautfully clean bed linen. Television reception isn't great, internet connection is usually adequate but does go down quite often. A kettle is usually provided, along with tiny cups and a teapot, but complimentary tea and coffee are not - we usually take a supply of these with us. The main problem with most of the rooms we've stayed in is the lack of electrical outlets, and those that are there are nearly wlways on one side of the room only - that opposite the bed. So, the ancient pre-war bedside lamp is useless as there's nowhere to plug it in! Likewise, the TV has to be unplugged in order for the kettle to be used. It's quite funny really - just one of those little quirks. The bathrooms are large with plenty of hot water for showers, but some of the older bathrooms have only cold water taps at the basins, and sometimes no plug which can make shaving a bit tricky. We've found this to be quite common in Vietnam so now we carry a universal plug. The notion of a Western breakfast hasn't yet reached this city, so the hotel doesn't provide much in the way of a hearty breakfast for us Westerners. The ubiquitous omelette can be made to order, but don't expect toast, or toast making facilities - the fresh bread is good, though. Occasionally you may get fruit. I'm afraid we don't like either the tea, coffee or milk - it's just not to our taste, so again, we take our own downstairs to the dining room and use the hot water supplied. This isn't a complaint, just an observation which may help future guests. This hotel seems to be the Go-To place for weddings and parties, which are loud colourful affairs. As they usually finish by about 9pm we've never been inconvenienced or disturbed by them, as we have in some hotels in other cities. The staff are so friendly and helpful and will go out of their way to make your stay a pleasant one. We have always been made very welcome, and yes, for a basic but clean, comfortable hotel, I would recommend it.

Title: HORRIBLE PLACE. STAY AWAY.
Review: Man at the front desk claimed he did not have a reservation for us, without even asking for our names. Only when I produced a confirmation paper from booking.com did he reluctantly give us a room. He was extremely rude and surly and did not look at or speak to us directly...only to our guide who was dropping us off. If we had any other choice besides sleeping on the street, we would have just walked away. The room we were given was on the 8th floor. The door did not have any security locks...only the type of lock you might have in an interior door of your home, where you just push the button in the center of the doorknob. Pictures below don't show how bad it was but bathroom sink was dirty as was the toilet. Inside of fridge was filthy. One of the towel bars was falling off the wall. The shower gel and shampoo containers were super-glued to the sink which was about six feet away from the shower. Very low water pressure and water only got lukewarm. Motel is in a very bad location and if I had not been traveling with my husband I would not have felt safe at all! We got out of there as fast as we could the next morning.

Title: An ideal homestay experience
Review: Homestay Ngoc Sang, located in a quiet corner of Vinh Long's very laidback An Binh island, offers an ideal homestay experience: comfortable sleeping quarters, out-of-this-world food, and attentive but not overbearing service. My decision to spend two nights there was one of the happiest I made during my travels through Vietnam. The scenery surrounding the homestay was green and gorgeous, the hammocks on the front porch were cozy enough to spend an entire afternoon in, and everyone on site was incredibly warm and friendly. I will be dreaming about their fried fish spring rolls until I have the opportunity to return to An Binh and have them again. I highly recommend considering a night or two (or more!) at Homestay Ngoc Sang if you are planning a trip around the Mekong Delta.

Title: Very nice place for a short stay
Review: After a chaotic bus trip from Saigon to Vinh Long it was great to arrive at this peaceful homestay. The people are very welcoming. They will meet you up at the ferry which will take you to the island. The rooms are ok (we had one that was 'private' ). The bathrooms are Vietnamese style but very clean. The food was amazing and so much to eat (diner at 6.30 so don't have a snack before) !!! They have bikes you can take to wander around the narrow alleys of the island, I strongly suggest you pick one to have a look at the peaceful life around the Mekong. Their boat trip across the highland is very nice (it'll cost you 200,000dg and start at 6am finishes at around 12pm), worth doing. Overall very good for a couple of nights only (we stayed one night as we thought there was not much to do after bike and boat trip) Ps: keep your mosquito repellent handy !!!

Title: Amazing value for money
Review: We found this little place in our guide and texted the owner to book (you can also email-> details on his Facebook page) and it was exactly what we wanted to finish our 2 weeks in Vietnam. Basic rooms but with mosquito net and fans (we didn't need to use the fans) 2 shower/toilets that are shared (only 5 rooms in this Homestay so never had to queue) rooms were very clean and family was very cute ! The grandma is cooking for us each night some amaaaaazing fishes, chicken, veg, fruits... We felt so good we decided to stay 2 nights. One day we took their bikes (don't expect the last model - Homestay means green tourism where you stay with locals to help them improve their standard of living so investing in bikes for them is like buying a car for you) but it's more than enough to discover the island with its beautiful landscape and colonial houses. Just test the bikes before and if you need adjustment just ask someone will always be willing to help. The next day we just relaxed in the hammock in the morning and at 12.00 we took their boat and they took us around the island for only 200 000 each. They picked us up from the main bus station and dropped us back and organised our trip back to Saigon. We paid 250 000 each (per pers per night) for bed diner and breakfast (bikes are free too and pick up as well) so it as an amazing value for money and we really saw a different part of Vietnam that really made our holidays. Will defo recommend you to visit this little family.

Title: Local homestay in a dirty surrounding
Review: We stayed only one night at Ngoc Sang Homestay. It was offered by the owner of the homestay as he approached us at the regional bus stop. The homestay was oke, nothing special. The dinner and market tour was included in the price of 250.000 dong per person. We took bikes from the homestay and drove around the island which was very poor, full of garbage but with friendly locals. The dinner was good but quite small. We understand that the family tries to make a living but found in the end the price quite high for what was offered. Especially because the morning market tour was very poor. The couple who did the tour took ages to get to some huts were you felt that you had to buy something while it was actually bad quality and service. The floating market was quite a joke, we sailed through the 15 boats without stopping. Only relatively good thing was a local boat which another women paddled through the small canals. Overall, the homestay was oke but the surrounding with market not worth staying. Other places in the Mekong Delta have more to offer.

Title: Dodgy Experience
Review: We stayed here as part of a boat-trip and Homestay we arranged with Nam whilst staying at the Phung Hoang Hotel in Vinh Long. It's wasn't a cheap trip, but we were only there for a short time and like most people wanted to pack in a boat trip and take a look around An Binh island, so considered it worthwhile. The boat trip itself was pretty average, no English communication and you are shown the waterways and visit what amounts to a few shops dotted around the islands. The unique atmosphere of An Binh is an attraction however. Afterwards we were dropped at Ngoc Sang Homestay and the trouble started when we where asked what we wanted for lunch and presented with a bill. Nam had given us the sales-patter at the hotel, telling us that the trip fee included everything, boat-trip, homestay and food. We complained that we did not expect to pay extra for food (only drink) and Nam was summoned to the phone. He told me that it was only breakfast that was included in the price. We were really annoyed, and we decided to leave as we felt this was a con. With bags packed we were stopped by a family member and asked to wait as they phoned Nam again. After a quick discussion they changed their mind and all food was now included. We where asked not to mention this to the other guests as they had agreed to pay for their food. We later learned that Nam and his sister sell the tour and homestay at the Phung Hoang Hotel and the neighboring Phuong Hoang hotel on Hung Vuong street. Some other guests who had bought the tour through Nams sister also did not expect to pay for extra for food (lunch, dinner) whilst at the homestay. We feel there is some deceit going on here, as they capitulated when we threatened to leave and then in hushed tones asked us not to mention we were not paying to the other guests. Be careful, if you take this tour be very specific about the food situation as we feel they are taking advantage of people once they are on the Island.

Title: Beautiful oasis in the heart of the Mekong
Review: We spent 3 nights at Phuong Thao Homestay and were immediately delighted with our choice - it was the perfect place to relax after a busy few days in Saigon. Phu was extremely helpful when we called the day before, arranging to pick us up by motorbike from the harbour at An Binh. On arrival, we had cold beers in the hammocks on the deck and pre ordered our dinner, which turned out to be a delicious feast every single night, including elephant ear fish, huge tiger prawns, Vietnamese pancakes, spring rolls, rice noodle soup, chicken in lemongrass and a whole array of local fruits. Phu speaks excellent English and all of the staff are polite and helpful. They arranged two boat tours for us: one of the Mekong including a floating market, a local market and a coconut candy/rice paper/rice wine producer (4 hours, 175,000 VND per person) another of local fruit plantations where we gorged on lots of delicious unusual fruits then visited some fish farms (3 hours, private tour, 200,000 VND per person). It was extremely interesting to see the different industries that are thriving in the An Binh area. Our rooms were clean with mosquito nets and a fan. There are plenty of shared showers with hot water and western style toilets. There are also free bikes for rent and we spent a few enjoyable hours exploring the local countryside, stopping to enjoy a bowl of Pho for lunch at a local eatery. Overall, this guesthouse highly recommended for a peaceful and authentic stay in the heart of the Mekong.

Title: Loved It
Review: My family and I stayed here along with our friends who are also a family of four and had a wonderful time. Mr Phu, who runs the place, speaks good English and was very helpful and accommodating. One of the highlights was hiring a couple of scooters and following a hand-drawn map that Mr Phu gave us. It was an epic adventure and really good fun. The food here is basic and there isn't a huge amount of choice, but what we did have was delicious. All in all this homestay is very relaxing and I recommend it to anyone wanting to spend a few days in the Mekong Delta.

Title: Excellent honestay
Review: Phuong Thao is a great homestay near Vinh Long. They arranged to collect us on motorbikes (20 mins, 50k each) from the ferry on the island. The room was comfortable, with 2 fans and a small bathroom. Food was plentiful and not really as expensive as some of the reviews in here make out. Drinks are on a "help yourself" basis from the fridge. Simply write down what you take. We borrowed mountain bikes to go out in the afternoon. They provided us with a very basic map which was reasonably helpful! The surrounding countryside is beautiful and seeing village life up close was great. This is the real Mekong Delta. Next morning, we went on a boat trip to Cao Be floating market (very small) and the excellent food market nearby. Highly recommended. The trip also took in a clay pot factory, and a candy/rice wine factory. And a trip on a rowing boat. Just a few dollars - excellent value. The owner and his staff are really friendly. They paired us up with others to share a car to Can Tho, but we wished we could have stayed longer.

Title: Remote location.  No river view.
Review: Motorbike met me at the bus termal from Ben Tre. I was charged 50k dong for the 25 minute ride which was exremely uncomfortable. Possibly the worst ride on a motorbike that I have ever experienced. If you come from Ben Tre, I suggest you don't take this option. When I arrived, I was shown to my room. The room is small, with just a double bed with a simple foam mattress. No other furniture. The room is clean, but open at the top, so therefore no air-con. There is, however, a fan and a mosqueto net. There is a shuttered opening to the outside, but there is no view, just the wall of the accommodation block next door. I had to go and ask for a key, because I wasn't given one when shown to my room. The bathrooms are at the back of the accommodation buildings. The shared wash basins are in public view, but there are lockable shower cubicles, some with a toilet. There is some toilet paper, but no shower gel is provided. The buildings are constructed in the local style using traditional materials. The beer is 25k dong for a bottle. That's more than I paid in Ho Chi Minh. I have just come from Ben Tre, where I was paying 8k dong for a beer. There is no view of the river. There is just a dirt trackway, and beyond that a swamp. However, the river can be seen from further along the trackway. There is a pleasant garden surrounding the property. I asked about going into the town. I was told that it's a 10 minute bicycle ride to the river ferry to get to the town. (bikes can be borrowed at no charge). Actually it's at least 20 minutes to the ferry. The ferry is busy, and you have to wait maybe 15 minutes or so for it to arrive from the other side. Fare is 1000 dong. There is a good market in the town (turn left from the ferry and the market is on the right). Behind the market is the bus station. Buses to Can Tho leave every hour at 19k dong. Take care about returning to the accommodation after dark, because the riverside pathway isn't lit. I slept well. It was very quiet. However, with no ceilings, noise carries easily from the other rooms. Breakfast was a selection of fresh fruit, an omelette, bread and a pot of coffee. It was a good breakfast. Transfer to the ferry by motorbike after check-out is provided free of charge. I'm not clear why this is called a homestay. There is nothing homely about it. It's a hostel in a poor location with rather inflated prices. The staff were pleasant, which is very nice when other things are not to your liking. I had booked to stay another 3 days on my return from Can Tho, but I decided to cancel the booking. I expected the accommodation to have a river view, and to be within walking distance of the ferry.

Title: A perfect few days
Review: We had such a perfect stay at Mr Phu's homestay. A driver picked us up in HCMC (only about $10 more than the bus for all three of us) and brought us directly to the ferry in Vinh Long, which was super convenient. A short ferry ride brought us to An Binh Island, where Mr Phu's staff picked us up on motorbikes for the short ride to the homestay. The location is incredible, surrounded by fruit trees and right on the river. Beautiful flowers everywhere, and so, so green. Definitely a remote getaway! Mr Phu arranged boat trips for us on the two days that we were there. The first day, we went to the Cai Be Floating Market, the coconut candy factory, and some other more touristy spots. The second day, we wanted to do something different, so we went on a boat (arranged 100% through the homestay) through the countryside. We even brought bikes on the boat with us so we could go for a ride through the winding dirt roads! Breakfast was served on the boat each morning, and both boat rides were very relaxing and lovely. We ate dinner at the homestay both nights, which ended up being a bit pricey but totally worth it. Unfortunately, there aren't many other options for dinner in the area, so the dinners are definitely something to factor in. However, the food was amazing and eating dinner at the homestay was such a wonderful experience. After dinner, we could just relax in the many hammocks before turning in for the night. The overall atmosphere of the place is amazing, and Mr Phu and his staff are all super friendly and helpful. Prepare to not have great phone service or wifi--all for the best, because who needs wifi when you can read a book in a hammock next to an adorable sleeping dog and baby ducks!? Highly, highly recommend this place for anyone looking to escape hectic HCMC and just have a completely peaceful couple of days. Do note that the bathrooms are shared and the rooms are quite basic, so don't expect anything too glamorous. DO make use of the open-roof showers--nothing quite like showering under the stars!

Title: The rooms were basic, the restaurant food was terrible
Review: After our tour bike ride of one hour along the canal and back country, we had reservations for lunch here. I was a bit surprised when it was time to place our order that there was no menu or at least one presented to anyone in our group. There was no menu and the host/hostess would come around to take your order and they would let you know if they could make a dish you wanted and there was also no mention of the prices. I have never visited a restaurant that did not have a menu card. The first dish I ordered was the fried noodles with chicken. This dish had no flavor and only a few vegetables. I had to add a ton of soy and vinegar sauce and this still did not help the flavor. The second dish was spring rolls. The rolls were terrible. They were filled with the local equivalent of a potato puree. I attempted to eat two of the eight rolls and I had to stop as they were so bad. More than 85% of our group did not like the food (even the soup) and then they hit you with the second surprise which was the high prices they charged for the food. So we were stuck out in the middle of nowhere, with no other options to eat. What a rip-off. Several of us mentioned to our tour guide and to our host/hostess about the poor taste and over-priced food. They both did not know how to respond to the criticism. This was one of three restaurants on my entire Vietnam adventure where the food was simply bad. I do not like to write such a negative review, but there were so many things wrong with the way this restaurant was managed, no menu, bad taste and high prices.

Title: Best Homestay ever!
Review: This is one of the best Homestays that we have been to and surely the best in Mekong Delta. The owner Phu and his family (including the 3 dogs) are super friendly and they help you with everything. We stayed there for two days and if we had more time we would stay much longer. He picked us up at the ferry in Vinh Long for free and we had an awesome first 15 minute boat trip. You can rent a bike for free and have a bike tour on An Binh island and see a lot of local fruits and plants. Very interesting! We also highly recommend the tour to the Cai Be floating market and the rice/coconut handicraft factory. We learned a lot about the local way of production and got free samples and jasmine tea as well. A nice bonus: You can have your included breakfast directly on the boat, while you cruise through the Mekong Delta canals. For dinner and/or lunch you can have a really good 5 course dinner for 5$. It was very delicious! They really know how to cook and you get a good impression of the real vietnamese food. All together it was the perfect holiday because we love the non-touristic sites of the country. And thats exactly what you get at Phuong Thao Homestay. It's an awesome Vietnam experience!

Title: One of the best options
Review: The questions isn't if you should stay here, it's more if Vinh Long should be on your itinerary. If you do visit, this homestay is definitely a great option, though I'm still a little undecided about Vinh Long to be honest. While its undeniably a beautiful window into the Mekong Delta, I do wonder if exploring one of the islands is a better option. Anyway, this homestay is beautiful and serene. The rooms are spacious. The dinner is a lovely and interactive experience. The boat tour is a must-do. All in all a great escape from the city bustle. I would recommend that you take the room with all three meals included since there are no good restaurants in the area and the chefs here are truly involved. The only drawback is that no room has attached toilets and the common toilets were not as clean as I'd have liked. This isn't meant to deter travellers, only a warning for the very particular ones out there.

Title: Nice athmosphere
Review: We stayed at the "homestay" for two nights and had a good experience. It is more like a guesthouse or hostel than a homestay, but you still get to spend time, cook and talk with the family that mostly lives on the same property. The rooms are bare bones and open to the fresh air, but sufficient. Same counts for the shared restrooms and showers. Just the urinals were stinking quite badly. The food is great and plenty, drinks are available for a bargain as well. We did a boot tour which did the same stops as other commercial tours, but as we are right in the action we always seemed to beat the crowd which was quite pleasant. In the afternoon we took two of the free bikes and discovered the island with their friendly locals. Overall a great stay even though the term "homestay" seems a little misleading, especially since they keep expanding the property.

Title: Beautiful scenery, commercialized homestay
Review: Ba Linh's Homestay is a very beautiful and relaxing place. The rooms are very basic, but the beds are comfortable. Mosquito nets are available and needed. In the common area it is nice to hang out in the hammocks. The free bikes are definitly a plus to explore the lovely surroundings. However, the shared bathroom should have been cleaner for the price you pay for staying. Furthermore, the set diner menu (basically the only option you have nearby) is lovely, but quite expensive for backpackers who live more on a budget, (150 000 VD/p). Very nice accommadation, bit overpriced, and it doesn't qualifies as a real homestay anymore. Watch out for the following scams: 1. On arrival from the ferry from Vinh Long city, motorbike drivers will be waiting for you saying that they are from the Homestay and will bring you for free ('no money, no money'). When you arrive at the homestay, the owner will tell you, you have to pay for the motortaxi. We refused to pay since we had asked repeatedly if it was really free. After a minute or two, the motorbike drivers drove away and we were welcomed in the homestay anyway. 2. Local bus Vinh Long City to Can Tho (every half hour, duration +- 1.45h). According to the owner of the homestay the price is 50 000 VD/p. However in the busstation the price is clearly listed as 19 000 VD/p. Nevertheless, the driver will ask 50 000VD/p claiming this higher price is for your bags (making it 31 000 VD per bag). We refused to pay and we bargained to 60 000 VD for two persons and two bags.

Title: Wonderful traditional Mekong experience
Review: Convinced by Ba Linh's excellent rating on TripAdvisor, we decided to stay here for two days in between Saigon and Chau Doc. We couldn't have wished for for a better place to discover the Mekong Delta tradition. Our host and his family were incredibly hospitable and interested, sharing their family history and chatting away after dinner. We were proposed a boat tour to the floating market in Cai Be and through the little canals surrounding the island. We also learned how to cook Vietnamese with the whole family, which was a lot of fun. The sons came to pick us up at the ferry when we arrived and dropped us off again when we left. Our host also arranged our bus ride to Chau Doc. The rooms have no windows so there's a natural airflow that keeps them cool. My personal highlight was waking up to all the surrounding animals sounds in the morning, we felt like we were in the jungle! The only downside (altough minor compared to our entire stay) was the lack of hot water in the shower. Would give 4,5/5 it that were a possibility. I ABSOLUTELY RECOMMEND THIS PLACE.

Title: Great stay!
Review: I stayed here during a group cycling tour. The room was bare-bones, but the rest of the site was absolutely beautiful. The rooms were in a structure that was similar to summer camp cabins, and the bathrooms were located across a courtyard. The doors on the rooms had locks, which was something I was concerned about since I was a woman traveling solo. There's no air conditioning, but there is good air circulation, and the fans cool you very well, even when you're using the mosquito netting. If you're afraid of nature, you might want to look into other options. The rooms were pretty open, and there were a lot of animal sounds (and gecko visitors on the walls!). The food was delicious, and the staff was very welcoming.

Title: Authentic experience with an extremely friendly family
Review: My partner and I stayed at the Ba Linh homestay for three nights in October 2016. The host family is extremely welcoming, and after traveling in Vietnam for three weeks, it was probably our favorite place to stay! The setting is quite rural and peaceful, and itâ€™s a nice place to relax. The homestay is situated across the river from Vinh Long, in the An Binh area. The hosts picked us up at the bus station, and transported us by motorbikes back to the homestay. They also gave a lift to the ferry when it was time to depart. The food was excellent. We were given simple, yummy breakfasts, and delicious feasts for dinner. My partner eats fish and seafood, but not other meats, and the hosts kindly adapted their meal offerings to accommodate her. They also offered us a cooking lesson each night, where we learned how to prepare different traditional dishes. The sleeping accommodations were comfortable, with a rustic feel. The homestay is equipped with a row of private guest rooms that share a common roof and porch. The roof does a perfect job of keeping water out, and there are openings in the walls and windows to let air flow in. We slept on a spacious double bed under mosquito nets and the room was cooled by an oscillating fan on the wall. During our visit, they were constructing a new building, which eventually will contain air conditioned rooms. It's a shame that this kind of luxury has been requested by other tourists, since to us, the whole point of a homestay is to experience the way locals live, and the accommodation we had was more than comfortable. The communal bathrooms are equipped with flush toilets and showers (with warm water). There is also a covered patio area for guests that have tables for eating, and hammocks that are perfect for reading and napping. The homestay lends the use of their bicycles for no charge. My partner and I took the bikes out on each of our two days there. It was tricky to navigate through the An Binh area, but it was fun to explore. But be aware that there are not very many cafes on the island, so lunch options were somewhat limited. Itâ€™s possible to arrange tours and such from the homestay, but the area is fairly un-touristy. So donâ€™t go with an expectation of sightseeing all day. However, if you are open-minded and up for a little adventure, you will stumble upon some authentic experiences of life in the Mekong. I would recommend this homestay to anyone interested in seeing an un-touristy part of Mekong Delta, and who is looking for a rustic, authentic experience with an extremely friendly and helpful family.

Title: Great place to experience the Mekong delta
Review: We stayed at Ba Linh Homestay for two nights and had a really great time. The family and especially Truong, the owner, is super nice and helpful. Title: Homely delightful experience in the Mekong Delta
Review: What can I say... we booked a 3 nights stay at Mr. TruongÂ´s homestay (officially known as Ba Linh homestay) guided by previous positive reviews of guests we had found on internet forums. I guess it is also posible that you can end up at this place as part of an organised Mekong Delta tour with some tour agency - we (my girlfriend and I) were lucky enough to book on our own and I believe we had the best posible experience about life in the Mekong Delta and a very kind and personal treatment from the whole family. Ba Linh homestay is located on An Binh island, a stretch of land in the southeastern part of the Mekong Delta. You would get easily to the nearest big city - Vinh Long - by one bus of the various companies that operate from Ho Chi Minh City. It is a roughly 3 hrs journey overall. From the city, you will need to cross to the island by ferry. Mr Truong had organised two members of his family to come and pick us up on their motorbikes at our arrival time, and they took us (and our bags) to the river ferry crossing to An Binh island, and from there to the house. They were extremely accommodating, since we arrived into the city at almost 10pm and they were very happy to wait for us, and prepare dinner after our arrival. From the very first moment, we felt very welcomed and they really made sure that our comfort and needs were fulfilled. The accommodation consists on a set of wooden rooms, with thatched roofs, located adjacent to the house. They are very spatious and comfortable. The windows are not glazed, just shaded by curtains inside, which means that you can feel almost like sleeping outdoors. It is a very pleasant experience, and especially considering the mosquito nets which protects us from those unwanted bites, and the fan which provide sufficient air movement to provide a comfortable sleep. The hightlights of the stay were undoubtedly the food, which was absolutely fantastic, with 5 or 6 course dinners of Vietnamese typical dishes, that we were also given the opportunity to learn to cook with them (the spring rolls on the ultra-light rice paper were the best I have ever tried!). The homestay also has bicycles available to take and explore the island, were you will observe and experience the traditional daily life and images, from fruit tres plantations, poultry farming, fishing, local cafes and markets, children coming in and out of schools - and we were always confronted by smiley people who would greet us everywhere we went to. The homestay also offers the possibility of booking a boat trip to visit the nearby floating market, factories of coconut Candy, rice wine, puffed rice, fruit gardens... really for a couple of days, we could not ask for more things to do! If you are coming from Ho Chi Minh City, I am almost sure you would love the quiet rural life that you would be able to experience here. The communication with the family members was easy, since they would all speak English to a certain degree and are used to interact with foreigners. They were never too intrusive and we always felt that we could have space and time for us everytime we wanted to sit on the tables, hammocks, or wander around the grounds and the garden. At the same time, you may appreciate you should also be respectful with them and let them carry on with their normal lives... but they would never be too hassle to help and dedicate time to you for anyof your needs. Mr Truong helped us out with booking our return tickets on the pone (my Vietnamese knowledge does not go farther beyond Â´pleaseÂ´and Â´thank youÂ´), and of course they were ready to take us back to the city by motorbike to catch the bus at the time we needed to be. There are also some Buddhist and Cao Dai temples in the island that you can visit. If you have a passion for it, you can also do some stargazing (coming from London, it always amazes us being able to see so many stars in the sky), searching for fireflies at night, or visiting the nearby crocodile farm (you can freely come in and out, since they are kept well secured in a concrete walled pool compound). We will always remember this stay as one of the highlights of our Vietnam trip, and perhaps something we would like to repeat at another time in our lives.

We also did a boat tour to the floating market which is easily organised by Mr Truong. We would definitely recommend staying here. Think most of the homestays in Vietnam now expand and it does feel more like a guesthouse but the whole family is really friendly at this place and the food is amazing. This made a big difference for us. Thank you Mr Truong and family!

Title: Great spot and facilities, but definitely didn't feel like a homestay
Review: We spent two nights in a Ba Linh homestay in September 2014. Booked a day before by a phone and staff was really helpful and picked us from An Binh ferry in Vinh Long. Place itself was beautiful with small canals and gardens and fireflies at night. Rooms were quite basic but comfortable: single or double rooms with a fan, thin walls and shared bathroom and toilets. Nights were a bit noisy with all the sounds of the jungle and nearby dogs barking, but that is expected when living on the countryside. We were hoping to get to eat with the family but they were only our humble waitresses. The food itself was very good. We did one boat tour, 4 hours around the river and visiting small floating market and some local "factories" (rice paper, rice wine, coconut candy and popping rise, all made in the same space), this was also disappointment since we waited something bit more authentic. So if you are looking for a homestay you might want to look from elsewhere but if you are looking a cosy place to relax, eat well and spend some time off from hectic towns this will be a good place.

Title: Worth the journey
Review: We had spent a night in chau doc and can tho prior to visitng this homestay and almost have it a miss...we are so glad we made the effort to travel to this beautiful part of the Mekong delta. The owner was very quick to respond to my emails and arranged for a motorcycle pick up from the ferry. The scenery on the island is beautiful! My partner and I borrowed bikes from the homestay and cycled down the narrow paths along the small canals and under the shade of orchards. It was unlike anywhere else we have been in Vietnam. Back at the homestay we relaxed in hammocks and helped make spring rolls before getting a feast for dinner of spring rolls, fish, chicken, soup and fruit. We spent a lovely evening chatting to another couple. The room was basic, but large and very comfortable. This type of accommodation is probably most similar to a bed and breakfast - the interaction with the family is a bit limited, but having said that they were all very friendly. Title: Great place to relax
Review: We stayed for one night and organized our stay independently.
