As mentioned in most reviews, the whole An Binh Island offers homestays, but they are all not real homestays, BUT here we felt closest to one as the owner spent time with us. This place is in business for 12 (!) years and still they put a lot of effort in it. The rooms were clean as the towels provided, the communal showers were also good and clean. The food and its presentation is very good, the kitchen area beautiful and very clean, and you actually can watch how the ladies prepare the food and even learn a recipe of spring rolls (hands-on cooking!) included in the homestay price. The price is actually a little higher than other homestays, but the nice, more remote setting with a flower filled garden, nice rooms, and great food are well worth spending some extra money. They rent bicycles and we spent the morning cycling around, between the picturesque canals. Check the bycicles before you set off. Ours broke down, but the owner brought another one and we could continue our trip. This is a nice service! One suggestion for the independent travellers like us: when calling for reservation make sure there is no big tour group staying that night, as â€“ like all the homestays â€“ they also cater to groups. And then, it is probably less idyllic and you get less attention from the friendly owner.

Title: Lovely experience
Review: I recently stayed for 2 nights at Ba Linh homestay. I was picked up from the ferry by the nephew by his moto and upon arrival I was made very welcome by the whole family. That afternoon I walked the round route near by the homestay. It was a lovely walk with plenty of opportunities to take wonderful photos and interact with some of the local people. Next morning I shared a boat ride with two other people to visit a nearby floating market. There was really only one boat selling fruit so not sort of floating market experience I was looking forward to. We also visited a place where they make rice paper, coconut candy, popping rice and on the way home a garden nursery. Short journey was also made in sampan. In the afternoon I rented a bicycle to explore the An Binh Island. Itâ€™s easy to get lost but locals were very nice to point me to a right direction when I asked directions. I truly enjoyed my ride, I took some wonderful photos, I saw a cock fight and I must have said hello to each and every child on the island ;) Both evenings guests were invited to help with the dinner. We got to make our own spring rolls. I have wheat intolerance and they provided 100% rice paper to do mine which I also cooked in a different oil from other spring rolls. During my second night we also got to cut up some vegetables. I had hoped we could be little bit more involved with dinner preparation but it was what I was. Nice experience regardless. During the first night most of the people decided to eat among their own group only, one couple even had their dinner on the other side of the building from the rest of us which seemed little bit weird but each for their own. During the second night we all eat together which for a solo traveller was much more nicer experience. We all ended up staying up quite late chatting away and 5 of us made plans to meet up in Can Tho for another floating market experience. The food served was delicious, beautifully presented and there was plenty to eat. They had kind of honesty bar/cool box from where guests could take cold drinks and pay them at the end of the stay. My room was big, clean and comfortable even if very basic and they provide mosquito nets in rooms. Toilet and shower were shared but clean and well kept. During my stay they were building another accommodation block to expand. There is free wifi. I truly enjoyed my stay, it was very relaxing and would be more than happy to stay again.

Title: A fun experience in a beautiful location
Review: We visited this homestay as part of a cycling tour of the Mekong Delta. It was a lovely way to see this region and we were really happy with the quality of accommodation. This place is run by two brothers and their families. It's mostly in one big old house that's divided into different sections, with a number of little buildings around it. The house has a lot of memorabilia from the war on display. Beautiful spot, accessible by boat and with lots of fruit trees around. The room was a pleasant surprise - private room with double bed (we did see four-bed rooms there too though). Looked beautiful, with dark wooden walls, high ceilings and a mosquito net over the bed. No A/C but fan is provided. Toothbrush/tooth paste and soap provided (in the cupboard). Bathrooms are in a separate building, domitory style. They provide all your meals and you can go into the kitchen and sit down with the family to help make the food. It's good fun. Food was perfectly good quailty, set menu style meals. Drinks cost extra, as with everywhere in Vietnam but they had a good selection of beers and non alcoholic drinks. While there was another family there, we were set up at a separate table in a pagoda on the other side of the house. I don't know if it was set up that by the request of our guide or the other family but we thought it might have been nice to eat with the others, instead of totally alone but maybe you can request that. One of the women makes these adorable figures out of cucumber which sit on each plate of food at dinner. A fisherman was on the plate of whole fish with the end of his fishing line attached to the mouth, a figure carrying baskets of rice was on the rice plate, and a man in a row boat was with the spring rolls. A fun and personal touch. They were so cute! For breaksfast, you get a mixed spread - some fruit, some cooked things, bread and spreads, and local coffee. The family who run the place have varying English levels so we muddled through but it was worth getting an explanation for how to make the coffee. We found this a great way to eat local food (they ate the same as us), see it being cooked, meet some local people (we even met the grandparents) and experience something kind of authentic in a slightly rustic but very comfortable setting. A break from the usual tourist trap in many popular spots in Vietnam.

Title: Exactly what we were looking for
Review: Lovely little authentic resort, literally on the delta. We wanted a few days here to relax and enjoy the nature and that's exactly what we got. Stayed in the river suite, which is a hut on the water. Slight word of warning - the river is quite busy and has boats going up and down all night which could wake you if you are a light sleeper. The food is delicious - highly recommend the chicken curry with rice noodles. The restaurant is also on the water, so you can sit and watch the world go by as you eat. Lastly, Thuy was our main liaison. He speaks good English and is knowledgeable about the area. He took us on a river tour to markets etc and generally made our stay very easy.

Title: You can't get closer to the Mekong than at this place
Review: This is a great little accommodation right next to the river. You can't get closer to the Mekong and enjoy the life on the river than here. Several standard rooms and one riverside cottage. I stayed at the cottage. It is quiet basic and slightly overpriced at 40usd per night but I guess you pay for the location and the view. It was clean and the bed was comfortable. Waking up with the sounds coming from the river - priceless. There is a nice swimming pool but I didn't have time to use it. There is also a restaurant and they serve the food on the terrace right next to the river. The food is great and this is a good place to taste the Vietnamese delicacies. The owners, a Finnish-Vietnamese couple, and the whole staff were very friendly and welcoming. I will stay here again on a next Mekong adventure planned for 2018 or 2019, just I think I'll opt for one of the standard rooms this time.

Title: Fantastic place right on the river
Review: Our group of 7 people stayed here for two nights. It's a little difficult to get to, we organized a bus from ho chi minh through the owners of the guest house which cost 100,000 vnd. You actually have to get bus, then a mini van (free) and finally a motorbike taxi (25,000). Once you arrive it is definitely worth the trip and feels a lot like an adventure. The guest house itself is very beautiful, has a nice swimming pool, small gym, pool table and the restaurant on the Mekong river has got to be seen. The rooms are all very clean, no air conditioning just fans. Bathrooms for standard double rooms are shared but close by. Staff were very friendly and they do their own half day and full day boat tour of the Mekong including floating market, rice paper factory and small boat tour through the wilderness for a very reasonable 200,000 vnd. I only have one issue with this place and that is the restaurant service. There is only 1 waiter and on the 1st day of our arrival we waited nearly 3 hours for our food. Fair enough they say in the menu to order at least 40 minutes in advance but the following days even when ordering in advance we waited over an hour and some people had finished their meal by the time others had even got theirs. I don't think they are set up to accommodate large amounts of people in the restaurant. It's a shame because everything else about the place is excellent. Special thanks to the young man working there, he seemed to never stop working in the restaurant and he also is the tour guide everyday. He seems to work from 6am to 11pm every day. He was every helpful and very patient with all the guests.

Title: Lovely place to stay
Review: As mentioned before, it is a bit of a trick to find this place but it's well worth the effort! We took a local bus (19) from Can Tho ($2 with backpacks) then a ferry to the island (11 cents) where the happy family guesthouse is. We had called to tell them we were coming, and there were bikes waiting to pick us up on the other side. The guest house is an amazing, clean and pretty place tucked away. The staff are all great fun, and work unbelievably hard. They sprint from place to place to see that everyone is looked after. We stayed in the suite built onto the Mekong and couldn't have asked for a more romantic room. Had a cheeky peek at the other rooms too, I'd recommend on of the roof top ones, they get a nice breeze and a view. The food is great too.

Title: Fijn en rustig paradijsje in de Mekong Delta
Review: Wat is dit plaatsje genieten zeg! In the middle of nowhere bevindt zich deze guesthouse. Een vrij riant verblijf met meerdere hutten en gewone kamers. De kamers zijn klein en eenvoudig en erg gehorig, maar dat hoort een beetje bij deze ervaring. De douche en de badkamer zijn publiekelijk en in ons geval moesten we dan ook de trap af om bij het toilet te komen. Dat was jammer maar goed, in je kamer ben je alleen om te slapen! Helaas werden de badkamers niet heel goed schoon gehouden. Wij hebben hier 3 nachten geslapen. Overdag hebben wij hier vooral gerelaxed. Er is een fijn zwembad, je kunt lekker poolen of gewoon in het zonnetje in een hangmat hangen genietend van de bootjes die over de rivier varen. Het is even totale rust hier zo na/voor HCMC. Leuke uitstapjes zijn het bezoeken van de floating market, snoepjes fabriek en andere plekken waar de eigenaar je mee naar toe kan nemen. Ook een aanrader is om een dag een fiets te huren via het verblijf, en zo lekker het eiland te verkennen. Het is een prachtig gebied. Absoluut pluspunt is het super lekkere eten dat ze serveren!! Als je naar een rustige plek in de Mekong Delta wilt is dit een ideale uitvalbasis. Zoek wel even goed uit hoe je er komt, want je zult gebruik moeten maken van de ferry en een motorbike taxi (mail even met de eigenaar).

Title: Peaceful place
Review: We booked late in the bus from Saigon and arrived late at Happy Family guest house. What a journey to get there ! But when we finally arrived, what an enchantment ! The place is just by the Mekong river, in a quiet tropical garden. It is very clean, and Toan, our guest, was very welcoming. There is a pool, a restaurant with river view, a billiard, a barbecue, and a "muscle center". You can rent bikes or motorbikes to explore Anh Bin island were people is so friendly. Toan can arrange daily tours by motorbike or by boat (floating market, etc...) Our room (cottage) was a tiny hut with no AC (ventilator instead), nice bed with a mosquito net, very typical, but not very cosy. The other rooms (hard built) are more cosy I guess. The bathrooms are shared but very clean. In a word, very nice place to stay if you want to get rid of the crowd of Saigon, peaceful and quiet, with great staff, good food, and many services provided.

Title: Hospitality Plus
Review: We were in Ben Tre and trying to get out to Happy Family Guesthouse. They arranged for a car to pick us up at a reasonable rate, not easy in the holiday season. The food was excellent and great drinks!! Restaurant is on the water and sunsets are a real treat. We had he front bungalow directly on the river so we could see everything, just beautiful. Title: Mekong Magic
Review: This treasure is a little difficult to find, (as mentioned in other posts) but once you are there you are glad you are off the beaten track. We are a family of 2 adults and 2 boys aged 11 and 9 and we thoroughly enjoyed being collected by welcoming strange faces that met our car, presented us with business cards from the guesthouse before piling our bags and the family on the back mopeds for the final leg of the trip to the guesthouse. The ride was great fun and the boys loved it. The grounds are tranquil, full of character, the rooms and bathrooms basic but adequate (pillows a touch hard), the pool is fantastic. The restaurant deck is right on the Mekong and is just a magic place to hang out and watch the Mekong traffic. The sunsets are amazing and the food delicious. We were treated to a great morning tour on the family boat to the floating markets. If you want to see the floating markets in all their glory and action you need to go at 3am. We chose the softer, easier, more family friendly option of leaving at 9. For this you get to see 1 or 2 boats that are probably there just for us, but the trip is still beautiful and the visit to the markets in Cai Be are some of the best we have seen. We were also taken to the honey factory and rice wine factory which was really fun, the kids had a great time, the day was made fun and special by our guide from the Guesthouse.... I have forgotten his name, but he was great fun. There are free bicycles for use and we rode around the island which is just magic, traditional Vietnamese life,,, in fact the bike ride around the local neighborhood was a highlight of my trip in Vietnam. The owners and staff are natural, welcoming, down to earth people and it was a real pleasure to spend time with them, as it was the other guests. I think it is a credit to the owners, the people this guesthouse attracts are my kind of people. It is truly family run with grandparents, kids and staff of all ages about, all friendly and beautiful.

Title: Idealic Guesthouse that is truely Happy Family!
Review: Thuy An, Trong and the rest of the family made our stay unforgetable. The guesthouse is located on a remote part of an island close to Ving Long, along the Mekong Delta. Rooms are basic (and clean!), but that is really all you need (a place to sleep). Do as the locals do and spend your time outdoors. The pool is great to cool off in, but when the tide is in, make sure you have a swim in the river! This really is a happy family guesthouse. We were invited to spend time with the family and they were always ready to help us with anything we needed. The location is gorgeous, though keep in mind that it's remote. They will assist in any way possible and arrange pick up from the ferry or the busstop. Just give the phone number to any Vietnamese local and they will be more than happy to help you out. In response to earlier reviews; Yes, food takes a while. This is because everything is made to your order. It doesn't get any fresher than that! Title: Relaxing stay by  the Mekong
Review: We stayed here as a family of four in July. This is a cheap travelling option. The garden and surrounding area is really lovely full of well tended trees and flowers with plenty of space for children to explore. The dining area looks out over the river which is busy and entertaining and offers an incredible view of the sunset. The family and staff are great and will help you even though there is not much English. The pool is the real draw here especially travelling with children. There is also a pool table and plenty of places in the garden to relax. The rooms are very basic though . We shared bathrooms with other guests which was fine but there was old shampoo bottles and wrappers which could have been removed. The bicycles are well maintained and we did a loop trip around the small roads/paths near the guesthouse which was good fun and sheltered from the sun by trees. The food is very good but not much choice if you are staying for three days. We had found it difficult to get to the guesthouse although they were very helpful explaining routes etc. We took the ferry from Vinh Long which is a scenic way to arrive although a distance from the guesthouse but it is possible to get there by car (not evident on google maps) so if you need this option get in touch with the guest house.

Title: Peaceful getaway, amazing food and great value for money
Review: A last minute trip, we didnt know what to expect. We booked the day before and as we were riding motorbikes from HCMC we needed directions and they were more than happy to meet us in Vinh Long and escort us to the Guesthouse location. Such a peaceful getaway on An Binh island - far enough from the hustle and bustle but close enough that its only a 15 min boat ride to the floating markets. We were the only guests in the hotel and treated like family. AMAZING food, some of the best I've had in Vietnam (And I've been living here almost two years), great service from Tong, Thuyan and the entire family. Lovely surroundings, rooms and shared bathrooms are SUPER clean, although the a/c could work a little better and TV to have more stations (but we weren't too bothered by it). Beds comfortable, could be softer but for the price, can't be beat. Bring mosquito repellant.They have their own boat so you don't have to go on the big touristy ones. All needs catered for in terms of food, drinks, tours, massages etc. They farm their own fish in the guesthouse pond - HIGHLY recommend the snapper and elephant fish. Spring rolls to die for. Chicken curry also good. The free breakfasts are simple but satisfying (choose the Hu Tieu, its really good). The best part: THE POOL! Not many places on the river can boast a pool and this was a welcome relief from the humid days. I think we spent half our time in there, drinking beers and eating ice cream. If you are a party person, this place isn't for you. There are no shops or bars close by. But if you want a peaceful getaway, a bit of R&R this is perfect. Would definitely come again. Thanks to Tong and the family for a great stay!!

Title: Nice surroundings far away from evrything
Review: The Guesthouse is located in a very remote area. You take the ferry from Vinh Long to the An Binh Island, then a motor bike taxi about 10 km to the north west corner of the island. The setting right by the river is wonderful, sitting in the open air restaurant right on the water surrounded by the rural landscape with banana, coconut, papaya and mango groves. There is nowhere else to eat, so we felt a bit disappointed with the short menu. Not much to choose from. And even less so as they did not even serve all that was on the list. Probably we were too few guests. The place felt a bit deserted. The food was OK - sometimes great, sometimes just ordinary. Breakfast is not included. There are bikes for rent. A bit too small for a European, but ok. Great fun to go bike riding through the small villages along the canals. The surroundings are great! The rooms and the shared bathrooms are very basic. The pool small, but clean and cool. On the boat tour we ended up at an ordinary market, which was very nice, but never got to see the floating market they told us we were going to. We also stopped at a very touristy place to see the making of honey tea, rice and coconut products. Interesting in a way, but the mission obviously was to sell us stuff we did not want. Rather would have had more time at the ordinary market. All in all a nice place, but I would rather choose a place a little closer to the ferry and a village.

Title: Mekong paradise!
Review: This Lodge is nestled into the side of the Mekong and feels as though it's far from civilisation. There are in fact lots of people and industries in the area that need the Mekong. The coconut factory turning coconut husks into twine and matting was a great example of this, it's a short boat ride away. A leisurely bike ride through the rice fields was so beautiful with all the lush green colours. Also a visit to the local market was interesting. The whole place is kept spotless by the wonderful staff. Do yourself a favour and stay here for something a little different that feels very authentic. Unfortunately we only had one day here, two would have been better. Oh and all the food is home cooked by the staff so it's really healthy and yummy!

Title: Oase in de Mekong Delta
Review: Deze lodge is een echte oase in de Mekong delta! Vijf traditionele huisjes gelegen in een prachtige tropische tuin, die uitkijken over de rivier. Vanaf je veranda met luie stoelen en hangmat kijk je naar de een na de andere boot, volgeladen met kokosnoten die voorbij komt. Vanuit de lodge kun je de omgeving verkennen op de gratis fietsen, maar er worden ook tourtjes georganiseerd per fiets of boot. Zo kun je de locale markt bezoeken of de kokosfabriek, waar je het hele proces van de kokosnoten kunt zien (kokosmatten). De tours zijn vooral leuk omdat je dicht bij de mensen komt, in ons geval zelfs bij ze thuis! Het eten bij Coco is uitstekend, prijzen liggen uiteraard wat hoger dan je in vietnam gewend bent ($12 pp voor diner), maar wij vonden het redelijk gezien de kwaliteit. Als ik een nadeel zou moeten noemen is het de bereikbaarheid: 3,5u rijden vanaf HCM airport. Coco biedt een transfer per luxe auto, maar dat is door de afstand behoorlijk prijzig. Een andere manier om er te komen is er niet. Voordeel daarvan is weer wel dat wij hier geen enkele andere tourist gezien hebben en je hier daardoor het Ã©chte Vietnam kunt ervaren.

Title: Beautiful, exquisite experience next to the Mekong River.

The room is set next to the river. It is romantic, elegantly decorated and one of a kind, hidden gem. Title: A great option for those wanting to see the Mekong
Review: Trung, the manager and host, is unbelievably friendly and knowledgable. You get the sense that everyone in the village knows and likes him, because everyone in the village seems excited to be introduced to you. The rest of his staff is equally attentive. The four bungalows are glamping at its best, sitting in a virtual garden cultivated by Trung himself. Orchirds, fruit trees, and ponds of fish abound. The meals were some of the best I had on my whole trip. The activities planned (biking and visiting in the village) feel authentic. Nothing feels overly set-up, or that anyone is putting on a show. It felt genuine and surprisingly friendly. By the the end of the first night we were drinking with the staff, Trung doing his best to translate jokes. ... And relaxing next to the bank of the river, watching the boats loaded with coconuts motor up and down was one of the highlights of our whole trip to Vietnam. I highly recommend staying here for your Mekong River experience, and wish I had spend more time there myself. (FYI the delta is about 3.5 hour drive from HCMC. Many people will promise day trips. 7 hours on the road, 3 hours at your destination. Your best bet is booking at a lodge, like this one, and arranging transport to the Delta through them.)

Title: A memorable stay
Review: This place is off the beaten track, but it is absolutely worth the effort to get to. Situated on a branch of the Mekong, I could have happily sat all day and watched the boats chugging up and down the river. But there was too much else to do! We did a cycle tour, which was a great experience. The locals were full of smiles - tourists are uncommon here (so far) - and there were great opportunities to see their way of life. We also did a boat trip and visited a local market - our guide bought some frogs for our evening meal while we were there (which was delicious!!). That leads me on to the food - excellent all round. The owner's family does the cooking, and it was unique in our holiday. An excellent experience. The cabins were great, and featured some serious mosquito nets for good measure. Even so, don't forget the repellent - the mozzies are pretty big by the river. Finally, I was amazed that the wifi worked so well. I was fully prepared for a few days off the grid, but that wasn't a problem. If you like getting off the beaten track a bit, while still having all your comforts, you can't beat Coco Riverside Lodge.

Title: Hidden gem in the Mekong Delta
Review: Coco Riverside is an exceptional place to stay, well off the beaten track, in richly productive countryside, with riverside views. It provided a relaxing and fascinating insight into life on the Mekong delta. The owner Hugh has managed to combine the luxury of beautifully appointed, spacious lodges with the rustic simplicity of an exotic garden setting, magically lit by lanterns at night. We sat and watched fisher folk and commercial traffic chugging along the river through a leafy curtain from our veranda, borrowed bikes to explore the surrounding countryside and villages with their duck ponds, rice paddies and market gardens. We took one tour on a small boat with his uncle visiting a small local market, passing coconut factories and seeing a variety of river traffic up close. Hugh was away but he provided us with a mobile phone incase of language difficulties with the staff who spoke little english. That worked perfectly and all our needs were translated and responded to. The food was fresh, delicious and plentiful and served by Hugh's charming aunt and niece who introduced us to various Vietnamese delicacies. Hugh arranged a special trip for us on bikes to Tra Vinh as we wanted to see a pagoda there, where we watched the monks at work, played with the puppies and enjoyed the architecture and setting amongst magnificent, mature trees. We had a wonderful stay in this delightful guest house and were made to feel totally welcome by his staff.

Although the staff didn't speak much English we had no trouble communicating and they were very kind and helpful. If you want a relaxing trip to the Mekong Delta and a chance to see how the local people live I highly recommend this place. Stay for more than one night if you can.

Title: Wonderful time but needs some tweaking
Review: The coco riverside lodge is an idyllic small family run home stay in a paradisaical setting. We had a wonderful two night stay at this home stay run by a Vietnamese local family that speaks almost no English. Fortunately our tour guide stayed with us in her own accommodations and was able to serve as our co host. Rooms are comfortable but lots of wasted space. The sitting room in the front was never used as it is open to the elements, has no A/C, hard wooded seating area (charming to look at but not to sit in) and susceptible to bugs. Bedroom was amply air conditioned (after AC in our first room broke after inhaling and de- tailing a salamander!). Mosquito netting was carefully placed around the bed in the evening. No real housekeeping during our stay. Shower only had cold water. Wifi only worked in restaurant until they lent us the wifi connector on our second night when we were the only guests. Outdoor riverside patios are great and relaxing with nice chairs and coffee set up. They should add more hammocks! Roosters will awaken you before 5 am if you don't bring ear plugs. Activities are great with highlights being the local school visit, pop rice making, cooking demonstration, and more. Beware of biking as the bridges are narrow and contain no guardrails. Bikes are mountain bikes without mountain bike tires which make them totally inappropriate for the off road rock laden trails. I flew over the bridge into the canal 10 feet below and suffered scratches and bruises (mostly to my ego)., and also lost my brand new digital camera. Food is incredible and ample except for breakfasts which were fine but not up to the other meals. Owners are so sweet and caring but not really able to communicate with you except for smiles! Grounds and setting are like your own Garden of Eden.

Title: Fabulous Local Experience in Top-Notch Location

Title: Mekong Delta magic
Review: We loved Coco Riverside Lodge - we were just disappointed that we visited at the beginning of our two weeks in Vietnam rather than the end because it's so peaceful and relaxing it should have been the antidote to the insanity of Hanoi's motorcycle mania. We booked our stay at Coco with the very helpful Queen Tours in Sydney. The booking included all meals (three a day) and activities for a two night stay - I suggest staying three or four. The bungalows are elegantly simple and spotlessly clean, and open onto the river; local river traffic putt-putts by all day. The activities open a window on real rural life in the Mekong Delta and don't feel over-organised - you can take it or leave it and there's still plenty of time to have to yourself. You do need a Vietnamese-speaking guide (helpful throughout Vietnam, really - other reviewers have already mentioned that Coco can arrange a guide for you); we were so lucky to be travelling with a friend who was born and raised in the region - he picked water hyacinth from the river and Coco's cooks were delighted to include it in dinner. The food was just superb at every meal - the best we ate in Vietnam - another reason we should have ended our holiday here! I would love to visit again.

Title: Perfect Paradise
Review: We stayed at the Coco riverside lodge for 2 nights and I can't praise this place enough! As backpackers this place was a little over our regular budget but it is not expensive at all especially for the experience you walk away with. The lodge is located just outside of Vung Liem and to get there the manager Hugh will email you with advice how to get there. The lodge grounds are in the middle of a local countryside community with no western faces or tourism in sight. There are a few local shacks selling drinks, snacks and smokes but if you want anything else you will have to cycle to the main road which can take over 30 mins. To us this was paradise. There are 4 lodges on the grounds and for our first night we were the only guests there. The lodges are large, comfortable and have a rustic feel to them but at the same time providing luxury. The main living space is sealed, there is a large bed, chairs, tables and other decor to make the room feel homely. The room also comes with A/C too. There bathroom is a good size and is covered but has an outdoor feel to it as it is not a sealed room. The bathroom was spotless and they provided a hairdryer and bathroom products. As you walk in the lodge there is a welcome seating area which is decorated lovely. This space holds a wardrobe and a fridge also. At the rear of the property is the river view which is amazing. Double doors from the main living space open up to a patio area which has a table with full tea/coffee making equipment, table and chairs as well as two deck style chairs to relax. The whole lodge is decorated using top quality furniture and all looks and feels brand new. Around the lodges there is a lovely garden at the front with the rear providing a peaceful riverside view. A hammock is providing also so you can watch the locals go by on there boats. Please note this is a river used by locals. The river is not busy, but there will be slight noise from the odd boat that passes. This did not bother us at all as it was nice to see the local people going about there daily life. There are no TVs or WIFI provided. You really are taken to tranquil paradise. The staff at Coco riverside are lovely and welcoming. During your stay you will be looked after by Queen. Although she speaks very little English you will manage to communicate enough to sort meals. Whilst staying at the lodges Hugh who speaks excellent English will call you on the phone and you will be able to arrange any tours or discuss anything you need during your stay. He will then advise Queen or any other members of his family (all the staff are Hugh's family). Hugh is a gentleman and is there for your every need. Although we never met Hugh, as he is not based at the lodge you feel as though he is a good friend who wants to do everything to make your stay the best it can be. It's also great that it is his family who look after you as it gives you that home stay feel. Queen and the woman in the family prepare and cook your food, his uncle is your tour guide and the local community are their friends who make you feel just as welcome as Hugh and his family. The food is delicious, fresh and plenty for just the two of us. We took part in a number of activities during our stay including, a sunset bike tour, watching poprice being made by locals whilst getting to sample and take away some of the produce. We took a boat trip down the streams to get to the poprice factory. We visited the local temple twice which was a great experience both times. Everyone at the temple made us feel so welcome and on our second visit we was invited to eat at the temple with some locals. We also got to visit the local school and interact with their oldest students who were 11 years old. We visited during their English lesson and was able to talk to the children and ask their teacher some questions. Visiting the school has been the best experience during our travel so far. To get around Hugh's uncle will show you the way. Again he speaks hardly any English except the basic hello and a few other words but as always you are able to communicate enough to feel comfortable and make sense of what's going on. We also used the lodges bikes to have a cycle around ourselves too. When you step foot out of the lodge grounds you are made to feel welcome by all the locals. You will get a lot of hello's shouted and sometimes a few children will cycle along side you to get a closer look. It is a obvious reminder that the people in this area are not used to tourism at all and a western face is still a new thing to them. I feel privileged to have been to such a untouched, local community which hasn't been turned into a tourism trap. I hope for the future it gets to stay this way. I can't express how much I loved this place and getting away from the hustle and bustle of Vietnam. Thank you to Hugh, Queen, Hugh's family and the local community for making our stay so special. I hope one day we can return.

Title: The real deal experience of vietnam
Review: There are a few ways to book this lodge, we booked through booking.com, but most visitors book a trip from saigon with a guide who comes with them. The latter is the easy option, the former is the one for those with a sense of adventure! It's not easy to get to....it is miles from anywhere..we were coming from the fabulous mango home stay in Ben tre, and had to get a private car ($60). However, it was SO worth the effort! The car dropped us at the roadside where we were met by the lovely lady, Queen, who led us down a beautiful lane to the lodges. There are 4 lovely bungalows, right on the river, with wrap around verandas. Beautiful! Luckily there was a guide there with 2 ladies, so he was able to tell us how things work, as no one speaks a word of English! Once the guide had left, we were on our own! Food is served in another building, fabulous lunch ($10) and dinner ($14), different each day, real home cooking. We went for a wander on the first afternoon and were immediately blown away by the hospitality of the villagers, there are so few places in the world where you are constantly waved at, invited for coconut, or invited to join a party, and for no other reason than to show you their home and speak a little English. We went for a long cycle one day, around the paddy fields and through tiny lanes. Everyone spoke to us, we felt so safe. We came home with coconuts and bananas! We were taken to a house by the home stay hosts, to see how they make pop rice, a little like pop corn but using rice, it was wonderful to go inside genuine homes, and we went for a sing song evening with some locals. The only thing that would have been helpful would be to have some info in the rooms about what you can do, we had a couple of phone calls with the owner who lives in hcmc to help us communicate. We LOVED this lodge, you won't see another westerner unless anyone else is staying, this is a unique part of vietnam. They will take you to a school normally, but it had finished for tet. I sat in the hammock one afternoon for a couple of hours watching the boats and taking great photos!

Title: Excellent Way to Experience the Mekong Delta
Review: The Coco Riverside Lodge is located in a tiny village in the Vung Liem district of the Mekong Delta. You can only reach it by riverboat or jungle path, so there's no street address. Unlike widely advertised homestays, the Coco Riverside Lodge offers clean and comfortable rooms but with a genuine Mekong Delta experience. In the three days we stayed, we didn't see a single Westerner. The rooms all front up against a wide, but relatively quiet river, with occasional coconut barges and fishing sampans gliding by. Sitting in the deck chairs looking out onto the beautiful river, you feel like you're in a movie or something. Just spectacular. The owner's mother cooks and the food is, simply put, incredible. We used to think Vietnamese food was mostly Pho and stuff like that. It's so much more: elephant ear fish, grilled pork on lemongrass skewers; stuffed pumpkin leaves, and then a whole bunch of dishes that I can't remember the names. The ingredients were all local (and organic of course) -- from the gardens and fields nearby, or the river. This was some of the best food I've eaten in my entire life. Our children got to participate in all kinds of activities run by the lodge -- learning how to make roofing with coconut fronds, making puffed rice cakes, climbing to pick coconuts, riding the lodge's bicycle boat. We also choose the option of visiting a local school, which was loads of fun. The Coco Riverside lodge was a once in a lifetime experience, that I'm just hoping I can make a "twice in a lifetime" experience for my family.

The bedroom was fantastic and much better than what you'd expect for the cost. The bed itself so comfortable that I decided to lay my head to five minutes and ended up falling fast asleep for several hours. The family didn't know where I was!

Title: I Traveled For A Year And This Was One Of My Favorite Experiences
Review: I stayed at My Hoa Mekong Homestay in March of 2013 (sorry for the delay writing my review!) and it was absolutely one of the best experiences I had while traveling. The whole story of this homestay is pretty funny, so bear with me: I booked this homestay while staying at a guest house in Can Tho. I presumed that the homestay was in Vinh Long, so I hopped on a bus to Vinh Long with no thought as to how I would find the homestay from there. Five minutes outside Vinh Long, I realized the homestay was located in Can Tho where I had just been. You can imagine the confusion of the locals nearby when I tried to signal with hand motions and maps that I needed to go right back from where I came. I almost cancelled my stay, but Tuan (the English-speaker of the family) talked me into backtracking far enough to a place where he could come get me on his motorbike. And boy am I glad I did. The homestay is located in the middle of little streams that make up the Mekong Delta. The paths along these streams are at most 3 feet wide, but motorbikes and bicycles zoom through them and pass each other like it's no big deal. When I arrived, I was surprised to find that I was the only guest that night, but Tuan introduced me to three neighborhood kids who kept me plenty amused. They lavished me with attention, led me on a bicycle tour of the area, and danced Gangnam Style for me. At dinner time, the women fed me an enormous meal of fresh fish, spring rolls, Vietnamese pancakes, and fried spring rolls. While I was finishing my massive meal, the house next door began to play music and people started flooding into the area. And so it was that I ended up at a Vietnamese wedding in the Mekong Delta, alone in a sea of South Vietnamese. Men crowded around round tables eating rice soup and duck while passing around two shot glasses and tossing back rice wine one after another. On the patio just a few feet away, two mounted disco lights flashed, a fog machine sporadically blasted fog onto the guests, and a man thrusted his hips while dramatically singing a Vietnamese song that sounded the same to me as the one before it. If the song was popular, other men rushed the stage and danced haphazardly, throwing their bodies to and fro to no apparent rhythm. As the person sung, other guests plucked branches from the surrounding shrubs and presented them as gifts to the singer. They sometimes tucked money into the leaves, and other times tried to find the most ridiculous shrubbery to elicit laughs from the fellow onlookers. This continued for hours, starting again the next morning with even more food and more karaoke. Being part of this wedding ceremony was a once-in-a-lifetime experience, but even without it, the homestay would have been wonderful. The area is absolutely beautiful, the house is clean, and the family and neighbors are welcoming and helpful (to the extent that they can be due to language barriers). Don't miss out!

Title: Great value for money, lovely family.
Review: Really loved the vibe of this place. They have hammocks all around. The beer they sell is Saigon red, 15k a bottle. They use the honesty system so just mark down what you get. The lunch and dinner is excellent. Lunch is 70k dinner is 100k When I saw the menu I thought we had to chose but you get ALL of it which is so much. For example. Lunch was 6 slabs of pork, rice, vegetables, soup and fruit. Dinner is even bigger with an extra starter such as a vietnamese stuffed pancake or fresh springrolls. You can look around for other places but I recommend just eating here. Room: 7/10. We had room 8, its a big room with 2 big beds, one of them without a matress since we were with 2. So plenty of storage space. 2 powers ockets by the door and a fan to keep you cool. Both bed have mosquito nets and you'll need them. The windows have no glass in them and a large part of the wall is build for air ventilation without mosquito nets so your room will be filled up with at least 30 mosquito's Bed: 6/10 The bed is big but hard. Has a good mosquito net without any holes. Cleanliness: 9/10 Rooms were clean, bathrooms cleaned daily. Bathroom: 8/10 Shared bathrooms, most are the combination kind but one has no toilet. There are six in total so you'll have no line. There's hot water and good pressure, no toiletries but you get a towel. The bathrooms are big, enough hooks to hang your clothes on. Location: 8/10 Its about 10 minutes walking from the Ferry, it can get really humid and hot, especially with your backpack. Area is nice and quiet except for the chickens etc but that comes with the territory. Service: 10/10 Great people, super kind and great service. The little kid is a good singer and not afraid to put up a show since we sat down to watch her perform her karaoke which was a lot of fun. They offer a boat trip for 200k each. Which takes up to 6 hours with several stops to see how people make candy (yes you may taste some) fruit garden, whiskey, bee farm and a floating market thing. (really small one) You usually get free tea and treats at every stop. Also free bikes. Breakfast: 7/10. Included. Baguette with egg and jam, coffee or tea.

Title: The best way to see something of the Mekong Delta
Review: We stayed only one night at Ngoc Phuong Homestay but I wish we had been there a little longer. Located on the island over the river from Vinh Long, this is a great place to chill out. The staff are really friendly and helpful and free bicycle hire is also included. Would definitely stay here again and recommend to others. I would also recommend their six hour morning river trip at 200,000 VND = $10 per person. A great value trip which gives you the chance to see the real charm of the delta by boat.
